CHAPTER 1 GENERAL PROVISIONS

SECTION 1.01.   APPLICATION.   The provisions of this Chapter apply to all provisions in the City Code. The City Code applies to all persons and property within the City of Red Wing, Minnesota, and within adjacent areas  as stated in specific provisions.

SECTION 1.02.  CITATION.  This  codification  of  the  ordinances  of  the City of Red Wing shall be known as the City Code and cited thus: "CITY CODE, SECTION."

SECTION 1.03. TITLES. A title or caption in any  provision of the  City Code is for convenience only and shall not limit, expand, or otherwise alter or control the content, wording, or interpretation thereof.

SECTION 1.04.	RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.

Subd. 1. Unless otherwise provided herein, or by law  or  implication required, the same rules of construction, definition, and application govern the interpretation of this Code as those governing the interpretation of State law.

 
Subd. 2.
gender as well.
 
Words  importing one gender  include  and  apply to the  other
 

Subd. 3. Words in the singular include the plural and words in the plural include the singular.

SECTION 1.05. DEFINITIONS.  Words  and  phrases  shall  have  their plain, ordinary, and usual meaning. Technical words and  phrases,  however, having a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be understood according to their technical import. For the purpose of this Code, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:

1.	"City" - the City of Red Wing, Minnesota, acting by or through its duly authorized representative.

2.	"Council" and "City Council" - the City Council of the City of Red Wing, Minnesota.

3.	"Council Administrator"  - the  person duly appointed  by the  City Council and acting in such capacity, or acting through a designee.
 
4.	"Finance Director", "City Clerk", "City Attorney", "Director of Engineering", "Police Chief', and "Fire Chief' - the persons duly appointed as "Officers" by the City Council and acting in such capacity.

5.	"Person"  includes  all  firms,  partnerships,   associations, corporations, and natural persons.

6.	"Written" and "In Writing" - any mode of representing words and letters in the English language whether by printing or otherwise.

7.	"Street" - the entire area dedicated to public use, or contained in an easement or other conveyance or grant to the City, and includes, but is not limited to roadways, boulevards, sidewalks, alleys, and other public property between lateral property lines  in which  a  roadway lies.

8.	"Public Property" and "Public Place" - any  place, property, or premises dedicated to public use.  Such public  property  or  public place may be owned by the City, occupied by the City as a lessee, dedicated to the City in a plat, or occupied by the City by reason of an easement,  including, but not limited to, streets, storm water drainage and utilities, parks, trails, or parking lots so owned or occupied.

9.	"Private Property" - all property not included within the definition of public property or public place.

10.	"Intersection" - the area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb line or, if no curb, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways or streets which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different streets joining  at any other angle may come in conflict.

11.	"Roadway" - that portion of a street improved, designed, or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. If a street includes two or more separate roadways, the term "roadway" as used herein shall refer to any such roadway separately but not to all such roadways collectively.

12.	"Police Officer" and "Peace Officer" - every officer, including special police, authorized to direct or regulate traffic and keep the peace, and appointed or employed for the purpose of law enforcement.

13.	"Misdemeanor" - the crime for which a sentence of not more than 90 days or a fine of not more than $700, or both, may be imposed.
 

14.	"Petty Misdemeanor" - an offense, which does not constitute a crime, and for which a sentence of a fine of not more than $100 may be imposed.

15.	"Conviction" - either of the following accepted and recorded by a court:

(a)	A plea of guilty, or;

(b)	A verdict of guilty by a jury or a finding of guilty by a court.

16.	"Crime" - conduct prohibited by ordinance for which the actor may be sentenced to imprisonment and/or fined.

17.	"Ordinance" - an ordinance duly adopted by the City Council of Red Wing, Minnesota.

18.	"Ex Officio Member" - a person who is not counted for the purpose of determining a quorum, and has no right to vote, but shall have the right and obligation, at the person's discretion, to speak to any question coming before the board, commission, or other deliberative body of which the person is such member.

19.	"Advisory Member" - a a person that is appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the City Council, who acts in an advisory capacity and provides input to a Board. An advisory member does not have the right to vote, make motions, or be counted for purposes of a quorum. An advisory member need not be a resident of the City.

20.	"May" - is permissive.

21.	"Shall" - is mandatory.

22.	"Violate" - includes failure to comply.

23.	"Premises" - any lot or parcel of land within a continuous boundary whether publicly or privately owned, occupied, or possessed.

24.	"Board and Commission" - the official advisory bodies established by the City Charter or by the City Council per the City Code.

25.	"Joint Powers Board" - legal partnerships between other governmental agencies that improve operational efficiencies through collaborative efforts.
 
SECTION 1.06. SEVERABILITY. If any subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, word, or other portion of this Code as now or later amended or its application to any person or circumstance is held invalid, in whole or in part, by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed severable, and such invalidity shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this Code that  can be given effect without the invalid provision or application.

SECTION 1.07.	REFERENCE  TO A  PUBLIC  OFFICIAL.	Wherever  an
appointed public official is referenced in the City Code, the reference shall include such public official or the official's designee.

SECTION 1.08. OTHERWISE UNLAWFUL. The City Code does not authorize an act or omission otherwise prohibited by law.

SECTION 1.09.	VIOLATION	A	MISDEMEANOR	OR	A	PETTY
MISDEMEANOR. A person who violates a section, subdivision, paragraph, or provision of this City Code, or amendment thereof, by performing an act thereby prohibited or declared unlawful, or by failing to act when such failure is thereby prohibited or declared unlawful shall be punished for a misdemeanor, or a petty misdemeanor upon conviction thereof, except as otherwise stated in specific provisions or amendments thereto. Upon conviction for a crime, the actor may be convicted of either the crime charged if it is a misdemeanor, or a petty misdemeanor as an included offense necessarily proved if the misdemeanor charge were proved.

SECTION 1.10.	PENALITIES FOR EACH OFFENSE.  When a penalty or
forfeiture is provided for the violation of a provision of this City Code, such penalty or forfeiture shall be construed to be for each such violation.

SECTION 1.11.	PAYMENT  INTO  CITY  TREASURY   OF  FINES  AND
PENALTIES. All fines, forfeitures, and penalties recovered for the violation of any ordinance, charter, rule, or regulation of the City shall be paid into the City Treasury by the court or officer thereof receiving such monies. Payment shall be made in the manner, at the time, and in the proportion provided by law.

SECTION 1.12.	CODE  ENFORCEMENT.

Subd. 1.  Police  and  Peace  Officers.  Police  and   peace   officers appointed by the City may enforce the provisions of this Code. In connection with such authority, police and peace officers may make arrests and issue citations in lieu of arrest in the manner provided by law.

Subd. 2. Employees and Agents.  The  following  city  employees  and agents, and their designees, may issue notices of violations and citations in lieu of arrest for alleged violations of the Code. These employees  and agents shall not arrest or otherwise take persons into custody.   The City Council shall identify and
 
approve designees by name annually.

A.  Community Service Officers.

B.	Parking Enforcement Attendants.

C.	Fire Chief.

D.	Engineering  Director.

E.	Public Works Director.

F.	Community Development Director.

CHAPTER2 ADMINISTRATION
 
SECTION 2.01. ORGANIZATION.
 
ADMINISTRATION	AND	DEPARTMENTAL
 

Subd. 1.  This  administrative  code  defines  the  authority   and responsibility of the Council Administrator and other officers and employees, provides for the coordination and control of activities, and creates lines of communication within the administrative services of the City.

 
Subd. 2.
following duties:
 
The  Council  Administrator   or  designee   shall   perform  the
 

A. Control and supervise all employees and affairs of the City government and to that end may investigate, examine or inquire into the affairs or operation of any department, division, or office of the City except as may be otherwise provided.

B.	Issue administrative manuals, orders, rules, directives and regulations consistent with the Charter, the City Code and State law. Such rules, manuals, orders, directives and regulations shall outline the procedures for City administration.

C.	Recommend to the Council such policies and procedures determined to be in the best interest of the City.

D.	Temporarily reassign personnel from one department  to  another  as needed.

E.	Make necessary purchases of material and supplies in accordance with the City's established purchasing policies and State law, provided that all purchases and expenditures are within budgetary limits.

F.	Provide administrative assistance to the mayor to perform or carry out mayoral duties.

G.	Perform all other duties prescribed by law, required by the City Charter, City Code, or assigned by the Council.



Subd. 3.   To provide for the economic and efficient service delivery, the City will be organized by departments and divisions. The organizational structure and   functions   of   each   department   and   division   will   be   represented   in  an
 
organizational chart that will be adopted by City Council.

Subd. 4. The City Charter identifies officers  appointed  by  the  City Council. Each officer shall perform all duties required by State law, the City Charter, the City Code, and the job description for the position as approved by the City Council. These officers will serve as a department or division head. All department/division heads including officers appointed by the City Council shall report directly to the Council Administrator.

Subd. 5. The City will be guided by City Council adopted organizational policies, including but not limited to the personnel policy, data practices policy, purchasing policy, and records  retention  schedule.  Departments  and  divisions may have additional  internal policies or procedures approved by the City Council Administrator or department heads.

SECTION 2.02.	ELECTIVE OFFICERS.

Subd. 1.	The elected officers shall be as provided by Charter.

Subd. 2.  Elective  Officer  Salary.  In  accordance  with   Minnesota Statutes, Section 415.11 subd. 2, no change in salary shall take effect until after the next succeeding municipal election. Effective January 1, 2017, Elective Officer salaries will be $307.70 biweekly/ $8000.20 annually.

Subd. 2.a.  Council Members shall receive a per diem of $75 per meeting for services performed for the Board of Equalization.

SECTION 2.03.	SIGNATORIES ON DEEDS.

Subd. 1. Purpose. The purpose of this Section is to clarify required signatures on deeds of conveyance on behalf of the City. While the Charter addresses required  signators for City contracts, it is silent with respect to those signatories required for deeds.

Subd. 2.       Signatories.  That every deed of conveyance in which the City is a grantor shall be signed by the Mayor and the City Clerk, with the seal of the City affixed thereto.

SECTION 2.04.	ACCOUNTS, CLAIMS OR DEMANDS.

Subd. 1. Generally. Except as to an annual salary, fees of jurors or witnesses fixed by law, or wages or salaries of employees which have been fixed on an hourly, daily, weekly, or monthly basis by the Council and which by law are authorized to be paid on a payroll basis, any account, claim, or demand against the City which can be itemized in the ordinary course  of business, the  Council shall not audit or allow the claim until the person claiming payment, or his agent,
 
reduces it to writing, in items, and signs a declaration to the effect that  such account, claim, or demand is just and correct and that no part of it has been paid in accordance with Minnesota Statutes, Section 471.38.

Subd. 2.  Discretionary  Exception.  The Council  may, in its discretion, allow a claim prepared by the City Finance Director prior to such declaration by the claimant if the declaration is made on the check or order-check by which the claim is paid as provided in Minnesota Statutes, Section 471.391, Subd. 2.

Subd. 3. Form of Declaration for Claim. The declaration provided for in Subdivision 1 hereof is sufficient in the following form as provided in Minnesota Statutes, Section 471.391, Subd. 1: "I declare under the penalties of law that this account, claim, or demand is just and correct and that no part of it has been paid. Signature of Claimant."

Subd. 4. Form and Effect of Declaration on Check.  The  declaration provided for in Subdivision 2 hereof shall be printed on the reverse side of the check, above the space for endorsement thereof by the payee, as follows: "The undersigned payee, in endorsing this check (or order-check) declares  that  the same is received in payment of a just and correct claim against the City, and that no part of it has heretofore been paid. When endorsed by the payee named in the check or order-check, such statement shall operate and shall be deemed sufficient as the required declaration of the claim in accordance with Minnesota Statutes, Section 471.391, Subd. 2.

Subd. 5.   Signing Checks.  All checks shall be signed by the Mayor and City Finance Director.

Subd. 6. As an alternative  to  payment  of  claims  and  obligations  by check, the City Finance Director may make payment by electronic or wire funds transfer provided the declaration set forth in Subdivision 1 above has been made.

SECTION 2.05.	FACSIMILE   SIGNATURES.	The   Mayor   and   City
Finance Director are hereby authorized to request a depository of City funds to honor an order for payment when such instrument bears a facsimile of either signature, and to charge the same to the account designated thereon  or  upon which it is drawn, as effectively as though it were a manually written signature. Such authority is granted only for the purpose of permitting such officers an economy of time and effort.

SECTION 2.06.	WORKERS'	COMPENSATION.	No	person	shall
receive coverage for workers' compensation except as provided in Minnesota Statutes, Chapter 176. Elected officials and appointed Board and Commission members shall be excluded from coverage.
 
SECTION 2.07.	EMERGENCY  MANAGEMENT.

Subd. 1.	Purpose.

A. This section shall be in accord with the Minnesota Emergency Management Act of 1996, Minnesota Statutes, Chapter 12, and is established to enable the City to perform local emergency management functions.

B.	Because of the possibility of the occurrence of natural and other disasters and in order to ensure that preparations of the City will be adequate to deal with such disasters, and generally to protect the public peace, health, and safety, and preserve the lives and property of the people of the City, it is hereby found and declared to be necessary: (1) to establish a local emergency management plan; (2) to provide for the exercise of necessary powers during emergencies; and (3) to provide for the rendering of mutual aid between the City and other political subdivisions of this State and with other states to carry out emergency management	functions; and (4) to institute training and public information programs to ensure emergency  preparedness

C.	It is further declared to be the purpose of this Section and the policy of the City that all emergency management functions be coordinated to the maximum extent practicable with the comparable functions of the federal government, of this State, of other states and localities, and of private agencies of every type, to the end that the most effective  preparations and use may be made of the labor supply, resources and facilities for dealing with any disaster that may occur.

Subd. 2.	Definitions.  For the purpose of this Section:

1.	"Emergency Management" - the preparation for and the coordination of emergency functions, other than functions for which military forces are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize, and repair injury and damage resulting from natural disasters as well as those caused by enemy attack. These functions include, without limitation, firefighting services, police  services, medical and health services, rescue, engineering,		warning services, communications, radiological, chemical and other special weapons defense, evacuation of persons from	stricken areas, emergency human services, emergency transportation,	existing or properly assigned functions of plant protection,		temporary restoration of public utility services, implementation	of energy supply emergency conservation and allocation	measures, and other functions related to civilian protection, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to preparation for and coordination of these functions.
 

2.	"Declared Emergency" - a national security or peacetime emergency declared by the Governor pursuant to Minnesota Statutes, Section
12.31 or an emergency  proclaimed  by the  Mayor as authorized
under this Subdivision and, in addition, includes disasters caused by fire, flood, tornadoes, wind storms, or other natural causes.

Subd. 3. Emergency Management Fiscal Procedure. There is hereby established in the City Treasury a special account to be known as the Emergency Management Fund. This account shall contain the proceeds of taxes levied for emergency management, money transferred from other funds, gifts, and other revenues of the Emergency Management Division. These funds shall not be used for regular and ongoing costs of the Emergency Management Division, but only shall be used in case of an emergency.

SECTION 2.08.	BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS GENERALLY.

Subd. 1. Charter Authorization. As provided by Charter, all Boards and Commissions shall be established by ordinance, which shall set forth their powers and duties, including the handling of funds. Except as otherwise specifically provided, all Boards and Commissions shall be advisory to the Council and neither shall they handle their own funds or accounting nor have the authority to contract for the sale or purchase of goods or services or financially obligate the City in any way except as authorized in the City Charter. Except as otherwise provided in this Chapter, all of the provisions of this Section shall apply to every Board and Commission.

Subd. 2. City Council Authority. The City Council has the authority to establish policies for Boards and Commissions. No Board or Commission, or any member thereof, may lobby, solicit, or attempt to influence any governmental entity on behalf of said Board or Commission or the City of Red Wing, for any purpose, without the prior approval of the City Council.

Subd. 3.  Membership.  All  Boards   and   Commissions   shall   be composed of three to fifteen members. Members may be removed by two-thirds vote of the Council; and terms of appointees to each Board or Commission shall be staggered to provide continuity. No appointed Board or Commission member shall be an employee of the City except those who are members by virtue of their office. Except as may be otherwise specifically provided by City Code, the City Charter, the Port Authority Enabling Resolution, or other law, no member of the Council shall serve on a Board or Commission. In addition to the regular members, the Mayor may appoint an honorary member to each Board or Commission on an annual basis to be known as the "Commissioner Emeritus." Such Commissioner Emeritus shall meet the same criteria for a regular member, set forth above, but shall not have a vote.
 
Subd. 4. Residency. Except as otherwise provided in this Chapter, all appointees shall have been residents of the City for at least six months.  If questions arise concerning the continued residency of a Board or Commission member, the Council shall appoint a subcommittee of the Council to gather facts pertinent to the residency question. The subcommittee shall make a recommendation to  the Council as to its findings. In assessing residency, the Council shall consider whether the individual at issue votes or is eligible to vote in the City, whether the individual lives within the City limits, and the address listed on the individual's drivers license as predominant factors of residency, though the Council is free to consider other evidence it determines is relevant to the residency question.

Subd. 5. Vacancy. Any Board or Commission member removed by the Council or whose seat is declared vacant by a lack of residency shall have their position filled as any other vacancy. All vacancies shall be filled  in the  same manner as an initial appointment, but only for the unexpired portion of the term.

Subd. 6.   Procedures.   The  Chairman  of  each  Board  or  Commission shall be chosen from voting membership, and may serve two consecutive  one­ year terms. Each Board and Commission shall  establish  its rules of procedure and establish its regular meeting time, all of which shall be approved by  the Council.

Subd. 7.  Compensation.   The  Port Authority  Board of Commissioners shall be paid a per diem in accordance with Minnesota Statutes, Section 469.050, Subd. 5. All other appointed Board and Commission members shall serve without remuneration, but may be reimbursed for out-of-pocket expenses incurred in the performance of their duties when such expenses have been authorized by the staff liaison before they were incurred.

Subd. 8.   Joint  Powers Agreements.    The  Council  may, as the  needs and interests of the City dictate, enter into Joint Powers Agreements

Subd. 9. Mutual Aid Agreements. The Council may, as the needs and interests of the City dictate, enter into mutual aid agreements with other public entities.

SECTION 2.09.	ADVISORY  PLANNING COMMISSION.

Subd. 1. Establishment and Composition. An Advisory  Planning Commission is hereby established. The Commission shall be composed of seven members.
 
Subd. 2.	Powers and Duties.

A. The Advisory Planning Commission shall have all the powers and duties defined or granted in Minnesota Statutes and the City Code relating to planning, zoning and subdivision regulation.

SECTION 2.10.	AIRPORT  BOARD.

Subd. 1. Policy. It is the policy of the  City to have an Airport Board pursuant to Minnesota Statutes, Section 360.038.

Subd. 2.  Composition.  The  Board  shall  be  composed  of  seven members; four of whom shall be residents of the City of Red Wing, one of whom shall be a Goodhue County, Minnesota, resident and taxpayer of the City of Red Wing or hangar lessee, and two who shall be residents of Pierce County, Wisconsin. Preference shall be given to residents of the townships of Isabelle and Trenton.

Subd. 3.  Purpose.  To  recommend  policy  and  guidelines  for  the operation and maintenance of the airport. To encourage economic, recreational, and community development, and to enhance strong local and regional involvement in these actions.

Subd. 4. Powers and Duties. The Board shall advise the Council in all matters dealing with the airport and its operation. The Board shall recommend an annual operating budget, report on the adequacy of facilities, recommend capital improvements, and serve as a forum for citizen input on subjects relating to the airport and its operation.



SECTION 2.11.	HARBOR COMMISSION

 
Subd. 1.
Commission.
 
Policy.	It  is  the   policy   of  the   City  to   have  a   Harbor
 

Subd. 2. Composition. The Commission shall be composed of seven members. Members shall be residents of the City in accordance with Section 2.08, Subdivision 4, of this Chapter, except that one member may be a nonresident who either owns real property in the City or has a slip at a City marina. The nonresident member shall be subject to nomination by the Mayor and confirmation by the City Council and the Port Authority. In the event that the Mayor does not appoint a nonresident, the Mayor can appoint a City resident as the  seventh member of the Commission and that member will be subject to confirmation by the City Council and the Port Authority. With regard to the members who  are residents, three shall be appointed by the Port Authority President and confirmed by  the  Port Authority  Board,  and  three  shall  be  appointed  by  the  Mayor  and
 
confirmed by the City Council. All members shall have the right to vote. A representative of the Port Authority shall serve as a non-voting liaison between the Port Authority and the Harbor Commission. A representative of the Red Wing City Council shall serve as a non-voting liaison between the City Council and  Harbor Commission.

Subd. 3. Purpose. The purpose  of the Harbor Commission is to (1) recommend policy guidelines for commercial and recreational activities related to the City's riverfront and navigable waters, (2) advise the Planning  Commission, Port Authority, and/or City Council on new development or redevelopment along the riverfront or navigable waterways; (3) suggest policies as it relates to navigable waters within the City, (4) recommend operational policy for the marinas that are utilizing City property, and (5) assist with marketing and communications  related to the Commission's activities.

Subd. 4. Powers and Duties. The Harbor Commission shall have the following powers and duties:

A. Make recommendations related to all riverfront development or redevelopment  projects.


B.	Assist with review, analysis, and updating of recreational leases.


C.	Assist  with  developing  policies that  affect  recreational  issues,  including but not  limited  to,  marina  pricing,  marketing  recommendations,  gas sales, waiting lists, etc.


D.	Develop and assist  with the implementation of marketing recommendations for recreational aspects of the river and for Ole Miss Marina activities.


E.	Communicate with  residents  and  boaters  the  rationale  for  various Harbor related policies.


SECTION 2.12.	HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION.

 
Subd. 1.
Commission.
 
Policy.	It is the  policy of the  City to  have a  Human  Rights
 

Subd. 2.  Composition.   The  Commission  shall  be composed  of up to nine members. Members shall be residents of the City in accordance with Section 2.08, Subdivision 4, of this Chapter, or nonresidents of the City drawn from within the  boundary  limits of  Independent School  District No. 256.   Such  nonresidents
 
shall have resided within the boundary limits of the School District for at least six months.	The number of nonresident members must not constitute a quorum or more of the Commission. The Commission is not required to contain a minimum number of nonresidents as members.  All members shall have the right to vote.

Subd. 3. Purpose. The purpose of the Commission is to secure for all citizens equal opportunity in employment, housing, public accommodations, public services, education and full participation in the affairs of the City by supporting the Minnesota Department of Human Rights in implementing the Minnesota Human Rights Act and by advising the Council on long-range programs to improve community relations in the City.

Subd. 4.	Responsibilities.  The Human Rights Commission shall have the following responsibilities:

A. Create and collaborate with individuals, agencies, and organizations to provide the community with opportunities for educational and cultural events and activities.

B.	Advise and inform the Mayor, the Council and other departments of City government on human rights and civil rights issues.

C.	Promote education and understanding within the Red Wing community regarding the Minnesota Human Rights Act.

D.	Provide information and referral services to people in Red Wing  who need assistance from the Minnesota Department of Human Rights.

SECTION 2.13.	SISTER CITIES COMMISSION.

Subd. 1.	Policy.	It  is the  policy  of  the  City  to  have  a  Sister  Cities Commission.

Subd. 2.     Composition.   The Sister  Cities Commission  shall consist of up to 15 members. Members shall be residents of the City in accordance with Section 2.08, Subdivision 4,  of this Chapter, or nonresidents  of the  City drawn from within the boundary limits of Independent School District No. 256.Such nonresidents shall have resided within the boundary limits of the School District for at least six months. The number of nonresident members must not constitute a quorum or more of the Commission. The Commission is not required to contain a minimum number of nonresidents as members. All members shall have the right to vote.
Source:  Ordinance 8, Fourth Series
Effective Date:  07-16-2011

Subd. 3.	Purpose.   The purpose of this Commission  is to promote the interests  of  the  City  and  the  United  States  by  encouraging  and  fostering  the
 
development of sister city relationships of a long-term nature between this City and cities of other countries. The establishment of this Commission will benefit everyone and enable the Sister Cities Commission to:

A.  Exchange ideas and personal visits with their counterparts;

B.	Develop a way for the many and diverse elements of every community to come together to enjoy and profit from a cooperative program;

C.	Open  new  dialogues  with  other  cultures  to  find  unique  solutions  to improving the quality of life; and

D.	Further global understanding and world peace.

 
Subd. 4.
powers and duties:
 
Powers and Duties.  The Commission shall have the following
 

A. Coordinate the establishment of official sister city relationships between the City of Red Wing and cities of other countries through Sister Cities International.

B.	Establish official contacts with our sister cities, collect and disseminate information	on these cities and host official visits of sister city delegations.

C.	Promote cultural, economic and educational understanding between the City of Red Wing and its sister cities and citizen exchanges.

D.	Provide contacts and liaisons for  the business community, public schools, and other interested groups with our sister cities.

E.	Address  the  Mayor and  City Council on all aspects of the City's sister city relationships.

F.	Promote internship programs, leadership development programs, newsletters, workshops and trade and economic development.

SECTION 2.14.	SUSTAINABILITY  COMMISSION.

 
Subd. 1.
Commission.
 
Policy.	It is the  policy  of the  City  to  have a  Sustainability
 

Subd. 2. Composition. The Commission  shall  be  composed  of  a minimum of nine members and a maximum of fifteen members. Members must be residents of the City in accordance with Section 2.08, Subdivision 4, of this Chapter,  or  nonresidents  of  the  City  drawn  from  within  the  boundary  limits  of
 
Independent School District No. 256. Such nonresidents shall have resided within the boundary limits of the School District for at least six months. The number of nonresident members must not constitute a quorum or more of the Commission. The Commission is not required to contain a minimum number of nonresidents as members.  All members shall have the right to vote.

Subd. 3. Purpose. The purpose of the Sustainability  Commission is to provide advice to the City Council concerning environmental issues and initiatives confronting the City. The Commission shall work with citizens, government, businesses and local community organizations to protect and preserve the ecological resources of the community so that they are in balance with the cultural, historic, recreational, and economic resources of our river and land for generations to come.

Subd.  4.	Powers and Duties.

A. Draft and recommend a sustainability action plan for City Council consideration and approval.

B.	Assist and advise the City Council, Advisory Planning Commission and other city staff in assessing the environmental impact of proposed undertakings that fall in part or in total under the City's jurisdiction and recommend changes that would lesson or eliminate the environmentally detrimental effects of such undertakings.

C.	Recommend to the City Council additional environmental policy provisions and ordinances for enactment, as well as actions and programs that will maintain  or improve environmental quality and conservation of natural resources.

D.	Request that the City Council authorize studies on matters pertaining to environmental quality and natural resources and recommend, when necessary, the employment of  professional  qualified  persons  to  carry out such studies.

E.	Establish educational programs and public forums that provide information to community residents, businesses, and other institutions about environmental issues and initiatives.

F.	Establish environmental  programs,  volunteer  opportunities  and initiatives in which community residents can take part.

SECTION 2.15. CODE OF CONDUCT.

Subd. 1. Purpose. The Mayor and City Council of the City of Red Wing determines that a code of conduct for its members, as well as the members of the
 
various advisory boards and commissions of the City of Red Wing, is essential for the public affairs of the city. By eliminating conflicts of interest and providing standards for conduct in city matters, the city council hopes to promote the faith and confidence of the citizens of Red Wing in their government and to encourage its citizens to serve on its council and boards and commissions.

Subd. 2.	Standards of Conduct.  No elected official or a city advisory board or commission member may knowingly:

a.	Violate the open meeting law.
b.	Participate in a matter that is before the city council or relevant board that affects the person's financial interests or those of a business with which the person is associated, unless the effect on the person or business is no greater than on other members of the same business classification, profession, or occupation.
c.	Use the person's public position to secure special privileges or exemptions
for the person or for others.
d.	Use the person's public position to solicit personal gifts or favors.
e.	Use the person's public position for personal gain.
f.	Except as specifically permitted pursuant to Minnesota Statute 471.895, accept or receive any gift of substance, whether in the form of money, services, loan, travel, entertainment, hospitality, promise, or any other form, under circumstances in which it could be reasonably expected to influence the person, the person's performance of official action, or be intended as a reward for the person's official action.
g.	Disclose to the public, or use for the person's or another person's personal
gain, information that was gained by reason of the person's public position if the information was not public data or was discussed at a closed session of the city council or committee.
h.	Disclose information that was received, discussed, or decided in conference
with the city's legal counsel that is protected by the attorney-client privilege unless a majority of the city council has authorized the disclosure.

Except as prohibited by the provisions of Minnesota Statute Section 471.87, there is no violation of item b. of this section for a matter that comes before the council, board, or commission, if the member of the council, board, or commission publicly discloses the circumstances that would violate these standards and refrains from participating in the discussion and vote on the matter.  Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit a contract with an elected or appointed official under the circumstances described under Minnesota Statute Section 471.88, if proper statutory procedures are followed.

Subd. 3.	Complaint, Hearing. Any person may file a written complaint with the City Clerk alleging a violation of the aforementioned standards of conduct. The complaint must contain supporting facts for the allegation. The city council  may hold a hearing after receiving the written complaint or upon the council's own
 
volition. A hearing must be held only if the city council determines (1) upon advice of the city attorney, designee, or other attorney appointed by the council, that the factual allegations state a sufficient claim of a violation of these standards or rise to the level of a legally-recognized conflict of interest, and (2) that the complaint has been lodged in good faith and not for impermissible purposes such as delay. The city council's determination as to whether to hold a hearing must be made within 30 days of the filing of the allegation with the city clerk, if possible.  The council may grant an extension to this 30-day timeline if additional time is needed to adequately investigate the complaint.  If the council determines that there is an adequate justification for holding a hearing, the hearing must be held within 30 days of the city council's determination.  The purpose of the hearing is to provide the person accused with the opportunity to be heard. If, after the hearing, the council finds that a violation of a standard has occurred or does exist, the council may, at the same meeting or a future meeting, censure the person, refer the matter for criminal prosecution, request an official not to participate in a decision, remove an appointed member of a board or commission from office, and/or any other action within the council's authority that the council deems appropriate.

SECTION 2.16.	FAIR HOUSING.

Subd. 1.  Purpose.  Discrimination in housing and  real property based upon race, color, creed, religion, national origin,  sex, sexual orientation, marital status, familial status, disability, and status in regard  to  public  assistance adversely affects the health, welfare, peace, and safety of the community. People subject to such discrimination suffer depressed living conditions, poverty and hopelessness, which injures the public welfare, and places a burden  upon the public treasury  to improve these conditions. It is the  purpose of this Section to foster equal opportunity for all  to obtain housing without regard to race, color, creed, religion, national origin, sex, sexual orientation, marital status, familial status, disability, and status in regard to public assistance.

Subd. 2.  Definitions.  The following terms, as used in this Section, shall have the following meanings:

1.	"Commission" - the Red Wing Human Rights Commission.

2.	"Commissioner"  - refers to a member of the  Red Wing  Human Rights Commission unless the context otherwise indicates.

3.	"Complainant" - an individual who is aggrieved by an alleged unfair discriminatory practice and who has filed a grievance either with the Minnesota Department of Human Rights or with the Commission.

4.	"Disability" - any condition or characteristic that renders a person disabled.	A disabled person is any person who 1) has a physical, sensory, or mental impairment which materially limits one or more
 
major life activities; 2) has a record of such an impairment; or 3) is regarded as having such an impairment.

5.	"Familial Status" - the condition of one or more minors being domiciled with a) their parent or parents or the minor's legal guardian or b) the designee of the parent or parents or  guardian  with  the written permission of the parent or parents or guardian. The protection afforded against discrimination on the basis of family status apply to any person who is pregnant or is in the process of securing legal custody of an individual who has not attained the age of majority.

6.	"Marital Status" - whether a person is single, married, remarried, divorced, separated, or a surviving spouse.

7.	"National Origin" - the place of birth of an individual or of an individual's lineal ancestors.

8.	"Person" - an individual, partnership, association, corporation, municipal	corporation, school  or school district, county, legal representative, trustee, trustee in bankruptcy, and receiver.

9.	"Real Estate Broker and Salesman" - a real estate broker as defined by Minnesota Statutes, Section 82.17, Subd. 4, and a real estate salesperson as defined by Minnesota Statutes, Section 82.17, Subd. 5.

10.	"Real Property" - real estate, lands, tenements, and hereditaments, corporeal and incorporeal.

11.	"Respondent" - a person against whom a complaint has been filed or issued for alleged unfair discriminatory practices.

12.	"Sex" - includes, but is not limited to, pregnancy, childbirth, and disabilities related to pregnancy or childbirth.

13.	"Sexual Orientation" - having or being perceived as having an emotional, physical, or sexual attachment to another person without regard to the sex of that person or having or being perceived as having an orientation  for such attachment, or  having or being perceived	as having a self-image or identity not traditionally associated with one's biological maleness or femaleness. "Sexual orientation" does not include a physical or sexual attachment to children by an adult.
 
14.	"Status with Regard to Public Assistance" - the condition of being a recipient of federal, state, or local assistance, including medical assistance, or of being a tenant receiving federal, state or local subsidies, including rental assistance or rent supplements.

15.	"Unfair Discriminatory Practice" - any act described in Subdivision 3.
The word "discriminate" includes segregate or separate.

 
Subd. 3.
practice:
 
Unfair  Housing  Discrimination.	It is an  unfair discriminatory
 

A.	For an owner, lessee, sublessee, assignee, or managing agent of, or other person having the right to sell, rent or lease any real property, or any agent of any of these:

1.	To refuse to sell, rent, or lease or otherwise deny to or withhold from any person or group of persons any real property because of their race, color, creed, religion, national origin, sex, sexual orientation, marital status, familial status, disability, or status in regard to public assistance;

2.	To discriminate against any person or group of persons because of their	race, color, creed, religion, national origin, sex, sexual orientation, marital status, familial status, disability, or status in regard to public assistance in the terms, conditions, or privileges of the sale, rental or lease of any real property or in the furnishing of facilities or services in connection therewith; or

3.	In any transaction involving real property, to print, circulate or post or cause to be printed, circulated, or posted any advertisement or sign, or use any form of application for the purchase, rental or lease of real property, or make any record or inquiry in connection with the prospective	purchase, rental or lease of real property which expresses, directly or indirectly, any limitation, specification or discrimination as to race, color, creed, religion, national origin, sex, sexual orientation, marital status, familial status, disability, or status in regard to public assistance, or any intent to make any such limitation, specification, or discrimination.

B.	For a real estate broker, real estate salesman or employee, or agent thereof:

1.	To refuse to sell, rent, or lease or refuse to offer for sale, rental, or lease any real property to any person or group of persons or refuse to negotiate for the sale, rental or lease of any real property to any person  or  group  of  persons  because  of  their  race,  color,  creed,
 
religion, national ong1n, sex, sexual orientation, marital status, familial status, disability, or status in regard to public assistance, or represent that real property is not available for  inspection,  sale, rental or lease when in fact it is so available, or otherwise deny or withhold any real property or any facilities of real property to or from any person or group of persons because of their race, color, creed, religion, national origin,  sex,  sexual  orientation,  marital  status, familial status, disability, or status in regard to public assistance;

2.	To discriminate against any person because of race, color, creed, religion, national origin,  sex,  sexual  orientation,  marital  status, familial status, disability, and status in regard to public assistance, in the terms, conditions, or privileges of the sale, rental or lease of real property or in the furnishing of facilities or services in connection therewith; or

3.	To print, circulate, or post or cause to be printed, circulated or posted any advertisement or sign, or use any form of application for the purchase, rental or lease of any real property or make any record or inquiry in connection with the prospective purchase, rental or lease of any real property, which expresses directly or indirectly, any limitation, specification or discrimination as to race, color, creed, religion, national origin,  sex,  sexual  orientation,  marital  status, familial status, disability, and status in regard to public assistance, or any	intent to make any such limitation, specification, or discrimination.

C.	For a person, bank, banking organization, mortgage  company, insurance company, or other financial institution or leader to whom application is made for financial assistance or for the purchase, lease, acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, repair or  maintenance  of  any real property or any agent or employee thereof:

1.	To discriminate against any person or group of persons because of their	race, color, creed, religion, national origin, sex, sexual orientation, marital status, familial status, disability, or status in regard to public assistance, or of the prospective occupants or tenants	of such real property in the  granting,  withholding, extending, modifying or renewing, or in the rates, terms, conditions, or privileges of any such financial assistance or in the extension of services in connection therewith;

2.	To use any form of application for such financial assistance or make any record or inquiry in connection with  applications  for  such financial assistance  which expresses, directly or indirectly, any limitation,  specification,  or  discrimination  as  to  race,  color,  creed,
 
religion, national ong1n, sex, sexual orientation, marital status, familial status, disability, or status in regard to public assistance, or any intent to make any such limitation,  specification,  or discrimination.

D.	For any real estate broker or real estate salesman, for the purpose of inducing a real property transaction from which such person, that person's firm, or any of its members may benefit financially, to represent that a change has occurred or will or may occur in the composition with respect to  race, color, creed, religion, national origin, sex, sexual orientation, marital status, familial status, disability, or status in regard to public	assistance, of the owners or occupants in the block, neighborhood, or area in which the real property is located, and to represent, directly or indirectly, that this change will or may result in undesirable consequences in the block, neighborhood, or area in which the real property is located, including but not limited to the lowering of property values, an increase in criminal or antisocial behavior, or a decline in the quality of schools or other public facilities.

Subd. 4. Unfair Discrimination - Aiding and Obstructing. It is unfair discriminatory practice for any person:

A. Intentionally to aid, abet, incite, compel or coerce a person to engage in any of the practices forbidden by this Chapter;

B.	Intentionally to attempt to aid, abet, incite, compel or coerce a person to engage in any of the practices forbidden by this Chapter;

C.	To intentionally obstruct or prevent any person from complying with the provisions of this Chapter, or any order relating to discrimination issued under state law, or to resist, prevent, impede, or interfere with the State Commissioner	of Human Rights or any of the Commissioner's employees or representatives in the performance of duty under state law relating to discrimination.

Subd. 5. Reprisals. It is an  unfair  discriminatory  practice  for  any employer, labor organization, employment agency, lessor, public accommodation, public service or educational institution or owner, lessor, lessee, sublessee, assignee or managing agent of any real property, or any real estate broker, real estate salesman or employee or agent thereof to intentionally engage in any reprisal against any person because that person:

A. Opposed a practice forbidden under this chapter or has filed a charge, testified, assisted, or participated in any matter in an investigation proceeding or hearing under this Chapter; or
 
B. Associated with a person or group of persons of a different race, color, creed, religion, sexual orientation, or national origin.

Nothing contained in this Section shall be construed to limit the right of any person to file a complaint with the Minnesota Commissioner of Human Rights or to limit the right of any person concerned or affected to a hearing of the facts and issues in any court having jurisdiction of cases involving discriminatory practices.

Subd. 6.	Exemptions.

A.	The provisions of Subdivision 3 shall not apply to:

1.	Rooms in a temporary or permanent residence home run by a nonprofit organization, if the discrimination is by sex; or

2.	The rental by a resident owner or occupier of a one-family accommodation of a room or rooms in such accommodation to another person or persons if the discrimination is by sex, marital status, status with regard to public assistance, sexual orientation or disability.		Nothing in this Chapter shall be construed to require any person or group of persons selling, renting or leasing property  to modify the property in any way, or exercise a higher degree of care for a person having a disability than for a person who does not have a disability; nor shall this Chapter be construed to relieve any person, regardless of any disability, in written lease, rental agreement, or contract of purchase or sale, or to forbid distinctions based on the inability	to fulfill the terms and conditions, including financial obligations of such lease, agreement or contract.

3.	The rental by a resident owner of a unit in a dwelling containing not more than two units, if the discrimination is on the basis of sexual orientation.

B.	The provisions of Subdivision 3 prohibiting discrimination because of familial status shall not be construed to defeat the applicability of any local, state or federal restrictions regarding the maximum number of occupants permitted to occupy a dwelling unit and shall not apply to:

1.	An unoccupied dwelling unit in any building in which at least a majority of the dwelling units are occupied by elderly persons or are unoccupied and available for occupancy solely by households of which at least one member is an elderly person; or

2.	Any owner occupied building containing four or fewer dwelling units; or
 
3.	An unoccupied dwelling unit in any building which is the subject of a valid certificate filed with the State Commissioner of Human Rights pursuant to the provisions  of  Minnesota  Statutes,  Section  363.02, Subd. 2 (as amended).

Subd. 7.  Filing with Building Official.   Owners of dwelling units exempt from the provisions of Subdivision 3 prohibiting discrimination because of familial status pursuant to Subdivision 68(3) shall file a copy of the election or certificate with the housing inspector for the City.

Subd. 8.   Grievance  Procedure.   The  Commission  shall  develop  rules and regulations for the establishment of a procedure to address grievances pursuant to this chapter. Said rules and regulations  shall  include,  but  not  be limited to, application for grievance hearing, information required, Commission response, deadlines, notification of result, and denial of services.

Subd. 9.    Notice to State.  The Commission may, in its discretion, notify the Minnesota Department of Human Rights of any unfair discriminatory practice which has come to its attention either by grievance or otherwise.

Subd. 10.	Construction.  Nothing in this Chapter shall be construed to:

A.  Mean the  City of Red Wing  condones  homosexuality  or bisexuality or any equivalent lifestyle; or,

B.	Authorize the recognition of or the right of marriage between persons of  the same sex.

Subd. 11. Criminal Code; Effect. Nothing in this chapter alters the provisions of Minnesota Statutes, Chapter 609 or, any other law relating to criminal penalties.

SECTION 2.17.  HUMAN RIGHTS AND DOMESTIC PARTNERSHIPS.

Subd. 1.	Statement of Legislative Purpose and Intent.  The City of Red Wing  recognizes that  nationwide  debate  has advanced  an expanded  concept of familial relationships beyond traditional marital and blood relationships.  This ordinance  creates  a  process  to  provide  two  non-married  but  committed  adult partners	to	declare	themselves	domestic	partners,	thereby	providing	a government-based  foundation  to  such  committed  relationships  which  positively contributes to the health, safety and welfare of the community as a whole.

This ordinance does not create or confer rights or privileges that are available to married persons under state or federal laws. The City of Red Wing does not provide legal advice concerning domestic relationships. Applicants and registrants  should  consult  with  attorneys  or  other  advisors  for  advice  on  such
 
matters  as  wills,  durable  powers  of  attorney,  health  care  directives,   medical matters, health care finances, or employment benefits.

Subd. 2.  Definition.  For   the  purpose  of  this  Section,  the   term "Domestic Partner'' means two persons 18 years of age or older, who:

A.	Are not related by blood closer than permitted under the marriage laws of the State;

B.	Are not married in a manner recognized in Minnesota;

C.	Are competent to contract;

D.	Have no other domestic partner;

E.	Affirm that they are jointly responsible to each other for the necessities of life;

F.	Affirm that they are committed to one another to the same extent as married persons are to each  other,  except  for  the  traditional  marital status and solemnities; and,

G.	At least one of the partners either resides or works  in the City of Red Wing.

Subd. 3.	Registration of Domestic Partners.

A. The city clerk shall accept an application to register  as  domestic partners from persons who state in such application that they meet the definition of domestic partners set out in Subd. 2.

B.	For all applications received in 2011, the city clerk will charge an application fee of $50 for the registration of a domestic partnership. After 2011, the application fee may be increased or decreased on an annual basis and will thereafter be set forth in the City's fee ordinance. The city clerk shall also charge a reasonable fee per document for providing certified copies or registrations, amendments or notices of termination. There shall be no charge for filing amendments or notices of termination.

C.	The city clerk shall provide each  domestic partner with a registration certificate. The registration certificate shall not be issued prior to the third working day after the date of application.

D.	This application and certificate may be used as evidence of the existence of a domestic partners relationship.
 
E.	The city clerk shall keep a record of all registrations of domestic partnership, amendments to registrations  and  notices of termination  received  by the city clerk. The records shall be maintained so that amendments and notices of termination are filed with the registration of domestic partnership to which they pertain.

F.	Upon production of valid, government-issued documentation and only to the extent of the rights and responsibilities established therein or elsewhere in this Code, the terms "domestic partnership" and "registered domestic partnership" shall include, in addition to domestic partnerships registered with the City of Red Wing, and regardless of whether partners in either circumstance have sought further registration with the City of Red Wing:

1.	Any person who has a currently registered domestic partnership with a	governmental  body  pursuant  to  state,  local,  or   other   law authorizing such registration. The term domestic partnership should be construed broadly to include same-sex civil unions or other such same-sex unions in which two same-sex individuals are committed to one another to the  same  extent  as  married  persons  are  to  each other, except for the traditional marital status and solemnities; and

2.	Marriages that would be legally recognized as a contract of lawful marriage in another local, state, or foreign jurisdiction.

Subd. 4.   Amendments.   The  city  clerk  may  accept  amendments  for filing from persons who have a domestic partnership application on file except amendments which would change the identity of the partners.

Subd. 5.	Termination of Domestic Partnerships.

A. Either person in a domestic partnership may initiate termination of the domestic partnership, by written notification to the city clerk on a form provided by the city clerk's office.
B.	A Domestic Partnership terminates when the earlier of the following
occurs:

1.	One of the partners dies; or

2.	Forty-five days after one partner sends the other a written notice of termination that he or she has terminated the partnership by filing a notice of termination with the city clerk.

Source:  Ordinance 7, Fourth Series Effective Date:  07-02-2011
 
SECTION	2.18.	DISPOSAL	OF	ABANDONED	MOTOR	VEHICLES, UNCLAIMED PROPERTY AND EXCESS PROPERTY.

Subd. 1.	Disposal of Abandoned  Motor Vehicles.

A.	Definitions.

1.	"Abandoned Motor Vehicle" - a motor vehicle, as defined in Minnesota Statutes, Section 169.01, Subd. 3, that has remained illegally for a period of more than 48 hours on public property  or lacking vital component parts, or has remained for  more  than  48 hours on private property without the consent of the person in control of such property, and lacks vital component parts, or is in an inoperable condition such that it has no substantial potential for further use consistent with its usual function, unless it is kept in an enclosed garage or storage building. It shall also mean a  motor vehicle voluntarily surrendered by its owner to and accepted by the City. A classic car or pioneer car, as defined in Minnesota Statutes, Section 168.10, shall not be considered an abandoned motor vehicle within the meaning of this Section. Vehicles on the premises of junk yards or automobile graveyards, which are licensed and maintained in accordance with the City Code, shall not  be  considered abandoned motor vehicles within the meaning of this Section.

2.	"Vital Component Parts" - those parts of a motor vehicle that are essential to the mechanical functioning of the vehicle, including, but not limited to, the motor, drive train and wheels.

3.	"Garage Keeper" - is an operator of a parking place or establishment, an operator of a motor vehicle storage facility, or an operator of an establishment for the servicing, repair or maintenance of motor vehicles.



B.	Custody. The City may take into custody and impound any abandoned motor vehicle.

C.	Notice of Taking Within Ten Days. When an abandoned  motor vehicle is taken into custody, the City shall give notice of the taking within ten days. The notice shall be sent by mail to the registered owner, if any, and to all readily identifiable lienholders of record. If it is impossible to determine with reasonable certainty the identity and address of the registered owner and all lienholders, the notice shall be published once in the official newspaper of the City. The notice shall set forth the date and place of the taking, the year, make, model and serial number of the impounded	motor   vehicle,   if  such   information   can   be   reasonably
 
obtained, and the place where the vehicle is being held,  inform  the owner and any lienholders of their right to reclaim the vehicle, and state that failure of the owner or lienholders to exercise their right to reclaim the vehicle, shall be deemed a waiver by them of all right, title, and interest in the vehicle and contents and a consent to the transfer or title to and disposal or sale of the vehicle and contents.

D.	Right to Reclaim.

1.	Payment of Charges. The owner or any lienholder of an abandoned motor vehicle shall have a right to reclaim such vehicle from the City upon payment of all towing and storage charges resulting from taking the vehicle into custody within 15 days after the date of the notice required by this Subdivision

2.	Lienholder. Nothing in this Subdivision shall be construed to impair any lien of a garage keeper under the laws of this State, or the right of the lienholder to foreclose.

E.	Public Sale After 15 Days.

1.	An abandoned  motor vehicle  is eligible for disposal or sale  15 days after notice to the owner  under this section.	An  abandoned  motor vehicle and contents taken into custody and not reclaimed under this Subdivision  shall  be sold to the  highest bidder at public auction or sale or electronic selling process following notice required under this Subdivision.	The  purchaser  shall  be  given  a  receipt  in  a  form prescribed   by  the   Registrar  of   Motor  Vehicles   which   shall   be sufficient title to dispose of the vehicle.  The receipt shall also entitle the  purchaser to register the vehicle and receive a certificate of title, free and clear of all liens and claims of ownership.  Before such a vehicle  is  issued a  new certificate  of title,  it must  receive a motor vehicle safety check.

2.	From the proceeds of the sale of an abandoned motor vehicle, the City shall reimburse itself for the cost of towing, preserving and storing the vehicle, and all administrative, notice and  publication costs incurred pursuant to this Subdivision. Any remainder from the proceeds of a sale shall be held for the owner of the  vehicle  or entitled lien holder for  90 days and then shall be deposited in the General Fund of the City.

F.	Disposal of Vehicles Not Sold. Where no bid has been received for an abandoned motor vehicle, the City may dispose of it in accordance with this Subdivision.
 
G.	Contracts and Disposal.

1.	The City may contract with any qualified person for collection, storage,	incineration, volume reduction, transportation or other services necessary to prepare abandoned motor vehicles and other scrap metal for recycling or other methods of disposal.

2.	Where the City enters into a contract with a person duly licensed by the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency, the Agency may review the contract to determine whether it conforms to the Agency's plan for solid waste disposal. A contract that does so conform may be approved by the Agency. Where a contract has been approved, the Agency may reimburse the City for the costs incurred under the contract which have not been reimbursed.

3.	If the City utilizes  its own equipment  and personnel for disposal of the abandoned motor vehicle, it shall  be entitled to  reimbursement for the cost thereof along with its other costs as herein provided.

Subd. 2.	Disposal of Unclaimed Property Other Than Motor Vehicles.

A. Scope. Except as otherwise provided in Minnesota  Statutes,  this Section provides the procedure for the  disposition  of  abandoned personal property, including found property.

B.	Definitions. As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended:

1.	"Abandoned Property" - is personal property of any type; the owner of which has failed to make satisfactory claim and proof of ownership within 60 days after notice has been provided as described below.

2.	"Finder" - is a person who finds lost or discarded personal property belonging to another and gives the property to an officer.

3.	"Found Property" - is personal property which appears to have been lost or discarded and then subsequently found by another. Found property does not include property left in the care of an individual which is subsequently unclaimed by its owner.

4.	"Officer" - is any officer, agent or employee of the City acting within the scope of his or her employment.

5.	"Unclaimed Property" - is personal property of any type where the owner or his or her whereabouts is unknown, or which is unclaimed
 
for more than seven days.

C.	Notice of Official Possession.

1.	Any officer having  in  his  or  her  official  possession  unclaimed property and wishing to dispose of such property at a public auction or  sale, including an electronic selling process, shall from time  to time  prepare and publish  written  notice  containing  the  information required in Subdivision 2.

2.	The written notice shall contain the following information:

(a)	The name, designation and office address of the officer giving the notice;

(b)	The description of the unclaimed property, individually or by lot, that has come into the possession of the officer since the issuance of the last notice;

(c)	A demand that all owners of the property described in the notice make claim and proof of  ownership  satisfactory  to  the  officer named in the notice within 60 days from the date of the notice;

(d)	A statement that any of the unclaimed property not so claimed within the 60-day period shall be deemed to be abandoned, and that the same may be disposed by the City; and

(e)	The date of the notice.

3.	The notice shall be published in the City's official newspaper at least once, a copy of the notice shall be posted at City Hall, and a copy of the notice shall be mailed to the owner, if the owner's name and address is known.

4.	Nothing in this Section shall prevent an officer from disposing of unclaimed property by a private sale through a nonprofit organization that has a mission of community service after the property has been in the possession of the municipality for a period of at least 60 days.

D.	Claim and Proof of Ownership. Except as  provided  in  Subdivision 2.C.4., if unclaimed property remains in the possession of the officer without any person making satisfactory claim and proof of ownership for a period of 60 days from the date of the notice describing it, the personal property shall be deemed to be abandoned, and title  to  the  property shall be deemed to be in the City  by reason of abandonment by the owner and possession by the City.
 

E.	Found Property.

1.	When dealing with property which is lost and found by a finder, and then turned over to an officer, the finder shall be deemed to have made satisfactory claim and proof of ownership to be entitled to possession of the unclaimed property at the end of 60 days ("the waiting period") from the date of the notice. However, the finder's claim and proof of ownership under this Subdivision shall be inferior to and subject to a satisfactory claim and proof of ownership by any owner of the property.

2.	After the expiration of the waiting  period, the  City  shall  notify the finder, in writing, of the expiration of the waiting period and the disposition of the found property.  If  the  property  has  not  been returned to the owner, the notice shall include the statement that the finder  must take  possession  of the  property within  30 days  of the date of the notification, and that failure to  take  possession  of the property shall result in the title of the property vesting in the City.

3.	In the event that the finder fails to take possession of the property as provided above, or the owner fails to take possession of the property within 30 days of the owner's satisfactory claim and proof of ownership, the property shall be considered abandoned, and title of the property shall vest in the City for disposition according to this Section.

4.	Upon delivery of the unclaimed property to the finder as provided in this Subdivision, the City shall have no further interest or obligations with  respect to the  property.	The  City shall,  however,  provide the name and address of the finder, and the location of the property, if known,  to  any  person  making  a  satisfactory  claim  and  proof  of ownership subsequent to the delivery of the property to the finder.

F.	Disposal.

1.	The City shall have the right to sell or otherwise dispose of abandoned property to the highest bidder at public auction or sale, or by sale to the highest bidder using an electronic selling process. Alternatively, the City may deliver abandoned property at no charge to any community, non-profit organization.

2.	Abandoned property need not be sold for less than the cost  of advertising and selling. The City reserves the right to reject any and all bids.   If abandoned property cannot be disposed of at an amount greater than the cost of advertising and selling, the City may destroy
 
the property or otherwise dispose of it as it sees fit.

3.	The officer or entity conducting the sale  shall maintain a complete and accurate record of the sale, which shall include the description of the abandoned property sold, the name and the address of the purchasers, the sale price of each item sold, and the costs of the sale.

4.	The officer or entity conducting the sale shall execute and deliver a certificate of sale or a receipt to the purchaser of each item of property. The certificate shall describe the item sold, the purchase price, the name and address of the purchaser, and the date of purchase.	The certificate shall pass the title of the item to the purchaser.

5.	The Chief of Police is authorized to administer the disposal of bicycles lawfully coming into the possession of  the  City  and remaining unclaimed by the owner after a 60-day waiting period. In addition to the disposal methods provided herein, disposal  of unclaimed bicycles may be by donation to a nonprofit organization that has a  significant mission of community service or to another public corporation for public use. A notice specifying the date of the donation, the identity of the donor, and a general description of the bicycles shall be published in the official newspaper of the City at least eight months prior to such donation. At any time prior to the donation date, and upon satisfactory proof of ownership, the bicycle shall be returned to its owner.

G.	Disposition of Proceeds.

1.	All  monies  received  from  the  disposal  of abandoned  property,  less the costs of advertising and selling, shall be immediately paid to the Finance Director and retained in a separate fund  for  at  least  six months.

2.	Should any person within six months from the date of disposal of any abandoned property make claim to it and establish ownership,  the sum of money paid over to the Finance Director shall be paid to that person. In no event shall any claim be considered  unless it shall be presented to the Finance Director in writing before the expiration of six months from the date of the disposal of the item claimed.

3.	After  expiration  of six  months from the date of the disposal  of the item claimed, the monies received from the disposal of abandoned property shall be transferred into the City's general fund.
 
H.	Contraband. Personal property which is illegal to possess may not be sold at auction or returned to a finder.

Subd. 3.	Disposal of Excess Property.

A. Declaration of Surplus and Authorizing Sale of Property. The Council Administrator may, from time to time, recommend to the Council  that certain property (chattels) owned by the City is no longer needed for a municipal purpose and should be sold. Pursuant to Section 5.15 of the City Charter, the Council may declare said property to be surplus, estimate	the value of the property, and authorize the Council Administrator to dispose of said property in the manner stated herein.

B.	Surplus Property With a Total Estimated Value of Less than $100. The Council Administrator may authorize the sale of surplus property with a total value of less than $100 through negotiated sale or by an electronic selling process.

C.	Surplus  Property  With  a  Total  Estimated  Value  Between  $100  and
$10,000.	The Council Administrator shall offer for public sale, to the highest bidder, surplus property with a total estimated value of $100 to
$10,000.  Such sale shall be by quotation, competitive bids, or by public
auction, including an electronic selling process. In the event that sale is by competitive bids, notice of such public sale shall be given stating time and place of sale and generally describing the property to be sold at least ten days prior to the date of sale by publication once in the official newspaper.

D.	Surplus Property With a Total Estimated Value Over $10,000.  The Council Administrator shall offer for public sale, to the highest  bidder, surplus property with a total estimated value over $10,000. Notice of such public sale shall be given stating time and place of sale and generally describing property to be sold at least ten days prior to the date of sale by publication once in the official newspaper. Such sale shall be to the person submitting the highest bid by means of publically advertised sealed bids or public auction, including an electronic selling process.

E.	Receipts from Sales of Surplus Property. All receipts from sales  of surplus property under this Section shall be deposited in the Fund disposing of such surplus property.

Subd. 4.	Persons Who May Not Purchase - Exception.

A. No employee of the City who is a member of the administrative staff, department  head, a member of the  Council, or an advisor  serving the
 
City in a professional capacity, may be a purchaser of property under this Section. Other City employees may be purchasers if they are not directly involved in the sale, if they are the highest responsible bidder, and if at least one week's published or posted notice of sale is given.

B. It is unlawful for any person to be a purchaser of property under this Section if such purchase is prohibited by the terms of this Section.

SECTION 2.19.	VACATION OF REAL PROPERTY.

Subd. 1. Purpose. The purpose of this  Section  is  to  clarify  the procedure for vacation of streets, real property, or utility easements by the City Council, set forth at Sections 8.01 and 8.02 of the Red Wing City Charter.

Subd. 2.  Vacation of Real Property by City Council.   The City Council may, by resolution approved by at least a majority of all members of the Council, vacate any street or other interest in real property owned by the City or by the public, and located within the City, except for public utility easements. No vacation shall be made unless it appears in the interest of the public to do so after a hearing preceded by ten days published notice.

After such resolution is adopted, the City Clerk shall file a certified copy of the resolution in the Office of the County Recorder. Any failure to file said certified copy of resolution shall not invalidate any such vacation proceedings. The action shall take effect upon filing.

Subd. 3. Vacation of Public Utility Easements by City Council. The City Council may, by resolution approved by a majority of all members of the Council, vacate any public utility easement owned by the City or by the public, and located within the City.

After such resolution is adopted, the City Clerk shall file a certified copy of the resolution in the Office of the County Auditor and in the Office of the County Recorder. Any failure to file said certified  copy of resolution shall not invalidate any such vacation proceedings.  The action shall take effect upon filing.

Subd. 4.  Vacation  of  Real  Property  Upon  Petition.  The  City  Council may, by resolution approved by a majority of all members of the Council, vacate any street or other interest in real property owned by the City or by the public, and located within the City, upon the following:

A. Filing of a verified petition signed by or on behalf of any and all owners, natural or corporate, of any real estate abutting thereon; and

B. Presentation and filing proof of ownership of said property abutting the real property to be vacated, in a form  subject to approval by the City Attorney.
 

After such resolution is adopted, the City Clerk shall file a certified copy of the resolution in the Office of the County Auditor and in the Office of the County Recorder. Any failure to file said certified  copy of resolution shall not invalidate any such vacation proceedings. The action shall take effect upon filing.

SECTION 2.20.  DEFERRED  SPECIAL   ASSESSMENTS   FOR DISABLED AND SENIOR CITIZENS.

Subd. 1. The council may at its discretion and pursuant to  Minnesota Statutes, Sections 435.193 through 435.195 defer payment of certain special assessments in accordance with the following guidelines and procedures.

Subd. 2.        Qualifications  For Deferment.   Persons seeking deferment of a special assessment  imposed by the City shall meet the following qualifications:
(1)	own  a  homestead;  (2)  be  65  years  of  age  or  older,  retired  by virtue  of  a
permanent and total disability, or a member of the  Minnesota National Guard or other military reserves who is ordered into active military service, as defined in Minnesota Statutes,  Section 190.05, Subds. 5b or 5c, as stated in the person's military orders; (3) demonstrate that payment of the assessment would be a hardship; (4) be obligated to pay an assessment set by Council resolution; and (5) be willing to provide the City with such information as the City may require to make a proper determination as to eligibility.

Subd. 3.	Procedure.

A.	A person seeking deferment must be the owner of the property, which shall have homestead status, and shall make application to the City on forms prescribed by the City. An application shall  be made  not later than 15 days prior to the certification of assessments to the County Auditor.

B.	The application shall be filed with the City Clerk.
