An application shall be dated and shall contain a certification by the applicant  that  the information therein or made a part thereof is true and correct. The application shall contain a financial statement in form customarily used by a lending institution in the City. It shall also contain a copy of the previous year's Minnesota income tax return if one was prepared and/or submitted to the State.

C.	The City Clerk shall consider the application and make a written report.
The City Clerk may interview the applicant and may request additional information from the applicant or others. A report shall be filed on or before October 31. The report shall contain a  recommended  interest rate on any deferred assessment.  A copy of the report shall be mailed to or given to the applicant by the Clerk.
 
D.	Any  unusual  circumstances  pertaining  to  an applicant  not covered  by the standards and guidelines herein set forth may be referred to the City Council for its final determination. The determination shall be made in a nondiscriminatory	manner, and the City Council will not  give  the applicant	an unreasonable preference or  advantage  over  other applicants.

E.	If a deferment is granted, the City Clerk shall make the proper certification to the County Recorder which shall set forth the amount of the assessment and the amount of interest, if  any,  pursuant   to Minnesota Statutes, Section 435.194.

Subd. 4.	Determination of Hardship.

A.  For the purpose of the Section, the word "hardship" means: financial suffering, privation or trouble that is extremely hard to bear.

B.	To determine whether or not there is hardship, the City Clerk shall carefully examine the financial status of the applicant. The Clerk shall determine the applicant's net  income, and consider any relevant and special facts concerning the applicant's financial  condition.  The  City Clerk shall not grant a deferment for a person with a monthly income exceeding the income limits established by the Department of Housing and Urban Development Section 8 Income Guidelines for Goodhue

County, and as approved by Council resolution.  For the  purposes of this Section, net income is the previous year's Minnesota income tax adjusted gross income plus tax exempt income. In the event no income tax form was prepared and/or submitted to the State, the City Clerk shall require the applicant to submit the information which would have been used to determine net income. If the determination of net income does not correctly reflect the present financial status of the applicant, other facts may be considered.

C.	The City Clerk shall include in the report exceptional or unusual circumstances pertaining to hardship together with a recommendation respecting the same.

Subd. 5.	Termination of Deferred Assessments.

A.	The option to defer the payment of Special Assessments shall terminate and all amounts accumulated plus applicable interest and the amount of any recording fees paid by the city in connection with the deferred assessment shall become due upon the occurrence of any one of the following:
 
1.	Death  of  the  owner  when  there  is  no  spouse  who  is  eligible  for deferment.

2.	Sale, transfer or subdivision of all or any part of the property.

3.	Loss of homestead status on the property.

4.	Determination by the Council for any reason that there would be no hardship to require immediate or partial payment.

B. If the eligibility for deferment is lost, the entire amount of the Special Assessment shall be due within 60 days. If the Special Assessment is not paid within 60 days, the City Clerk shall add interest thereto at the rate originally certified from the due date through December 31 of the following year and the total amount of principal and interest shall be certified to the County Auditor for collection with taxes for the following year or equal annual installments for the remaining years of the original special assessment time period, whichever is longer.

 
SECTION 2.21. ACRES.
 
DEFERRED SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS  FOR GREEN
 

Deferrals of special assessments are required for certain agricultural or specialized use property in accordance with Minnesota Statutes, Section 273.111, commonly known as the green acres law.  The City will follow the requirements of that statute.  Deferred assessments governed by this Section shall be subject to an interest rate set by council resolution if allowed by Minnesota Statute, Section
273.111	or other applicable law.  The amount of any recording fees paid by the
City in connection with the deferred assessment will be added to the assessment amount.

 
SECTION 2.22. PROPERTY.
 
DEFERRED ASSESSMENTS  FOR UNIMPROVED
 

Subd. 1. Criteria for Deferment. The City Council  may,  in  its discretion and pursuant to Minnesota  Statutes, Section 429.061, Subd. 2, defer payment of certain special assessments for unimproved property in accordance with the following guidelines.

A.	Assessments on commercial property that is marginally buildable may be deferred for up to ten years.

B.	Assessments on residential property that is unplatted and has undeveloped frontage in excess of 200 feet may be deferred up to a maximum of ten years.
 
Subd. 2. Interest. All  deferred  assessments  shall  be  subject  to  an interest rate set by Council resolution. The interest will be compounded annually until the assessment is activated.

Subd. 3.	Activation of Deferred Assessments.   Deferred assessments pursuant to this Section will be activated when the land is sold, transferred, subdivided, combined, developed, a building permit is issued, utility services are connected, or the deferment period expires, whichever occurs first.  When the assessment becomes active, the term and rate will be as set forth in the original assessment  resolution.

Subd. 4. Recording of Deferred Assessments. The  City  shall  record deferred assessments for unimproved property in accordance with Minnesota Statutes, Section 429.061, Subd. 2. The amount of any recording fees paid by the City in connection with the deferred assessment will be added to the assessment amount.

SECTION 2.23.	PAYMENT OF ASSESSMENTS.

Subd. 1.	Payment of Whole Assessment before Initial Certification. The owner of property assessed may, at any time prior to initial certification of the assessment to the County Auditor, pay the whole of the assessment on such property with interest accrued to the date of payment to the City, except that no interest shall be charged if the entire assessment is paid within 30 days from the adoption of the assessment resolution.

Subd. 2.	Payment of Whole Assessment after Initial Certification.  After the initial certification of the assessment to the County Auditor, prepayment will be accepted for the total amount still owing, with interest accrued to December 31 of the year in which such payment is made.  Such payment must be made by November   15  or  interest  will  be  charged  through  December  31  of  the  next succeeding year.

Subd. 3. Partial Prepayment of Assessment. Within 30 days from the adoption of the assessment resolution, a property owner may make a partial prepayment of the principal to the City interest free. Such partial prepayment must be at least $100.

Subd. 4.	Multiple special assessments.   If a parcel has two or more separate special assessments, payment, as described in the preceding paragraphs of this Section, may be made on one or more assessments.

Subd. 5.	Certification of Assessment.   If the assessment is not paid in its entirety, the City will certify each year's collection of principal and interest to the County Auditor in November.  Certification to the County Auditor will result in the principal and interest appearing on the property tax statements of those assessed.
 

Subd. 6.	This Section is adopted pursuant to the authority of Minnesota Statutes, Section 429.061.

 
SECTION 2.24. SYSTEM.
 
EXPENSE	REIMBURSEMENT	AND	ESCROW
 

Subd. 1. Expense Reimbursement Required.  All  applicants  for  any licenses and permits of any kind and description from the City, along with all applicants for any land use approvals, including, without limitation, rezoning, conditional use permits and variances, subdivision approval, or planned development of all kind and description shall reimburse the City for all expense incurred by the City in processing the application, including, without limitation, reimbursement of staff time and consultant fees.

Subd. 2.	Escrow Deposit Required.  Before any application is accepted by the City for any of the foregoing, the applicant shall pay a minimum base fee and provide an escrow deposit (in a non-interest  bearing account)  in an amount determined  by the City as necessary to  reimburse the City for all staff time and expense and consultant fees that are incurred in the processing of the application. The  City  Council  shall, by ordinance,  set all fees  and  initial escrow  amount for each type of license and permit.   The determination  of the amount of the escrow shall be based upon the wage and benefit rates of staff members anticipated to be involved in the processing and approval process, and anticipated consultant fees. If the applicant fails to make the escrow deposit, the application shall be deemed incomplete and shall not be processed by the City.  In the event the amount in the escrow deposit  is deemed  insufficient, the Finance Director, or a designee,  shall notify the  applicant.		The  applicant  shall  be required to  immediately  deposit  an additional amount deemed sufficient to cover all staff and consultant expense as determined  by the  Finance  Director.	The failure  to  make such  a deposit  upon request shall be grounds for denial of the land use approval  sought.	Upon final disposition of the application, the applicant  shall be reimbursed for any amounts that are not used for reimbursement of expense to the City.  The City shall make said reimbursement within 45 days of final action.

SECTION 2.25.	VIOLATION	A	MISDEMEANOR	OR	A	PETTY
MISDEMEANOR. Upon conviction of violating this Chapter, a person shall be punished for a petty misdemeanor, except for  violations of Section 2.14, which constitute a misdemeanor.

CHAPTER 3

MUNICIPAL UTILITIES - RULES AND REGULATIONS, RATES, CHARGES AND COLLECTIONS

SECTION 3.01.	DEFINITIONS.	As  used in this Chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings stated:

1.	"Utility" - any City-owned utility system that provides, including, but not by way of limitation, water, sanitary sewerage, stormwater, solid waste, and communication service.

2.	"Consumer" or "Customer" - the owner of the property being served by the municipal utility.

3.	"Utility System" - infrastructure that produces, transports, or delivers service from a publicly or city-owned property.

4.	"Service" - providing a particular utility to a customer or consumer.

5.	"Stormwater Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP)" - a National Pollution Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit requirement that describes mandatory Best Management Practices (BMPs) for Municipal Separate Storm Sewer Systems in order to discharge municipal stormwater into the waters of the state.

6.	"Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD)" - the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20° Centigrade expressed in terms of weight and concentration (milligrams per liter (mg/I).

7.	"Suspended Solids (SS)" - the total suspended matter that floats on the surface of, or is suspended in, water, wastewater or other liquids and which is removable by a standard glass fiber filter.

SECTION 3.02.	FIXING RATES AND CHARGES FOR UTILITIES.   All
rates and charges for utilities, including, but not by way of limitation, rates for service, annual area fee, special stormwater sewer  connection  charge,  permit fees, deposit, connection and meter testing fees, service repair charges, disconnection fees, reconnection fees including penalties for non-payment if any, shall be  fixed, determined and amended by the City Council and adopted by ordinance. Such ordinance, containing the effective date thereof, shall be kept on file and open to inspection in the office of the City Clerk and shall be uniformly enforced. For the purpose of fixing such rates and charges, the City Council may categorize  and  classify  under the  various  types  of  service,  provided,  that  such
 
categorization  and classification shall be included  in the ordinance  authorized  by this Section.

SECTION 3.03.  CONTRACTUAL  CONTENTS.   Provisions   of   this Chapter relating to utilities shall constitute portions of the  contract  between the City and all consumers of utility services, and every such consumer shall be deemed to assent to the same.

 
SECTION 3.04. UTILITIES.
 
RULES AND REGULATIONS RELATING TO
 

Subd. 1.  Application,  Connection  and Sale of Service.   Application for utility services shall be made upon forms supplied by the City, and strictly in accordance therewith. No connection shall be made until consent has  been received from the City to make the same, and all fees and charges required by this Chapter have been paid in full. All utilities shall be sold and delivered to consumers under the then applicable rate applied to the amount of such utilities taken as metered or ascertained in connection with such rates.

Subd. 2. Discontinuance of Service.  Utilities  that  do  not  affect  the primary heat source for a residential unit may be shut off or discontinued whenever it is found that:

A. The consumer or customer of the premises served, or any person working on any connection with the utility systems, has violated any requirement of the City Code relative thereto, or any  connection therewith, or,

B.	Any charge for a utility service, or any other financial obligation imposed on the present consumer or customer of the premises served, is unpaid after due notice thereof, or,

C.	There is fraud or misrepresentation by the consumer or customer in connection with any application  for service or delivery or charges therefore.

Subd. 3. Cold  Weather  Rule.  Utilities  that  affect  the  primary  heat source for a  residential unit may not be disconnected between October 15 and April 15 except in accordance with the Cold Weather Rule contained in Minnesota Statutes, Chapter 2168, as it may be amended.

A. The consumer or customer shall be responsible for notifying the City in writing that their primary heat source or residential unit is dependent on City utility connection for operation.
 
Subd. 4.    Right of Entry.  With consent of the owner or occupant or in the event of an emergency, the City has the right to enter in and upon private property, including buildings and dwelling houses, in or upon which is installed a utility, or connection therewith, at all times reasonable  under the circumstances, for the purpose of reading utility meters, for the purpose of inspection and repair of meters or a utility system, or any part thereof, and for the purpose of connecting and disconnecting service.

Subd. 5.	Unlawful Acts.

A. It is unlawful for any person to willfully or carelessly break, injure, mar, deface, disturb, or in any way interfere with any buildings, attachments, machinery, apparatus, equipment, fixture, or appurtenance of any utility or utility system, or commit any act tending to obstruct or impair the use of any utility.

B.	It is unlawful for any person to make any connection with, opening into, use, or alter in any way any utility system without first having applied for and received written permission to do so from the City.

C.	It is unlawful for any person to turn on or connect a utility when the same has been turned off or disconnected by the City for non-payment of a bill, or for any other reason, without first having obtained a permit to do so from the City.

D.	It is unlawful for any person to "jumper" or by any means or device fully or partially circumvent a utility meter, or to knowingly use or consume unmetered utilities or use the services of any utility system, the use of which the proper billing authorities have no knowledge.

Subd. 6.	Utility Services and Charges a Lien.

A. Payment for all utility service and charges shall be the primary responsibility of the consumer or customer of the premises served and shall be billed to the owner of the premises on or after October 1, 2011. The City may collect the same in a civil action or, in the alternative and at the option of the City, as otherwise provided in this Subdivision.

B. Each such charge, including those termed "special" charges, is hereby made a lien upon the premises served by a connection to or utilization of a municipal utility system or service of the City and located within the City.	All such charges not paid and becoming delinquent may be recovered by assessing the property. The unpaid balance shall be placed on the assessment roll as provided by the City Charter  and Statute provisions.
 
SECTION 3.05. SERVICE.
 
RULES AND REGULATIONS RELATING TO WATER
 

Subd. 1. Use Requirements. Where the public water supply system is accessible, no person shall maintain a water distribution system which is not connected to the public water supply system without authorization by the City Council. Where the public water supply system is accessible, no person shall use private well water for domestic use without authorization by the City Council.

 
Subd. 2.
Customers.
 
Additional Application Procedures For Water Consumers or
 

A. When the consumer or customer desires to terminate City water service, five business days written notice to the Public Works Office must  be given.	Said notice shall state therein the date of the requested termination. Unless the notice provision is complied with, the consumer or customer shall continue to be responsible for charges and fees incurred because of the City supplying water to the premises.

B.	After water has been introduced into any building or upon any premises, no  person shall make any tap or connection with the pipes upon such premises, for alteration, extensions or attachments, unless  the  party ordering such tapping  or other works  shall exhibit the proper permit for the same from the City.

C.	All persons taking the water shall keep their own service pipes, service corporations, stopcocks or curb stops and apparatus in good repair and protected from frost, at their own risk and expense.  All water taken or used from the City water system, unless otherwise ordered by the City Council, must be metered and paid for, except water used in putting out fire.

D.	All expenses relating to the introduction of water into buildings or private premises shall be paid by the applicant. No charge, however, shall be made for the services of the City in directing where and in what manner the mains shall be tapped and excavations made in the streets for laying pipe.

E.	It is expressly stipulated by the City that no claim shall be made against it by reason of the breaking or freezing of any service pipe, service cock or curb stop; nor, if from any cause the supply of water should fail; nor from damage arising from shutting off water to repair mains, making connections, or extensions; nor for any other purpose that may be necessary. The right is hereby reserved to cut off the supply of water at any time, for the purpose of repairs or any other necessary purpose, any permit granted, or regulation to the contrary notwithstanding.  Whenever
 
it becomes necessary to shut off the water supply within any area of the City, the City shall, if practicable, give  notice to each and every consumer or customer within said area of the time when such supply will be shut off.

F.	Water will not be turned on to any building or private service pipe except upon the order in writing of the City. When the water has been turned off by the order of the City, no consumer or customer shall turn it on, nor permit it to be turned on, without the written consent of the City.

 
Subd. 3.
and Appliances.
 
Tapping of Main Water Lines and Installation of Service Pipe
 

A. No persons, except those having special permission from the City or persons in their service and approved by them, will be permitted, under any circumstances, to tap the mains or distributing pipes or altering any service of appurtenances. The kind and size of the connection with the mains shall be that specified in the permit or order from the City.

B.	Mains must always be tapped midway (in the upper quadrant) between the horizontal and perpendicular lines drawn through the center of the main, and not, in any case, at or within 14 inches of the hub.

C.	Copper pipe, in size not less than one inch, shall be used from the main to the curb stop near the property line. Any pipe allowed under law may be used from the curb stop to the inside of the building and water meter. If such pipe is not capable of being heated by electrical current,  a warning must be permanently posted by the water meter and point of entry of the pipe into the building stating "warning - frozen - cannot be thawed electrically." The sign shall be of substantial size to be readily noticed and in a form approved by the City. The sign shall be maintained by the property owner and it shall be unlawful to remove the sign. Every pipe shall be laid sufficiently waving and in such manner to prevent rupture by settling. Non-conductive materials used for  water services in lieu of copper pipe shall require that a locator wire be installed for location of utilities. The contractor will furnish and install a coated, solid copper tracer wire on all non-conductive water/sewer service lines in the trench alongside the pipe. Wire color will be blue for water and green for sewer. The tracer wire shall daylight at the point of entry at the foundation of the building through PVC conduit and a blank box as a future contact point to locate the service.

D.	All service pipes must be laid to a depth of eight feet below the surface of  the finished  grade.    In all  cases they  must  be so  protected  as to prevent rupture by settling.
 
E.	Every service pipe must be provided with two stopcocks for each consumer or customer, easily accessible; the one to the consumer or customer, the other to the City, and so situated that the water can be conveniently shut off. Stopcocks must be of the pattern known as the "round water way or full flow."

F.	Unless otherwise permitted, the City stopcocks or curb stops shall be placed on the property line and protected by a box or iron pipe reaching from the stopcock or curb stop to the surface and of suitable size to admit a stop key or curb stop key for turning on and off the stop. Such protecting box or pipe shall have a cover with the letter "W" thereon, visible and even with the pavement of finished grade.

G.	Automatic pressure regulators may be provided by the consumer  or customer	in every service  pipe  entering  buildings  to  reduce  the excessive		pressure from  the  mains.  Stopcocks  and  other appurtenances must be sufficiently strong to bear the pressure and ram of  the water  in the  mains.   All  house boilers shall be constructed  with one  or more air holes near the top of the inlet pipe, and be sufficiently strong to bear the pressure of the atmosphere under the vacuum.

H.	All lateral  or  service  pipes,  for  public  or  private  uses,  and  all necessary fixtures connected therewith shall be subject to the approval and laid under the supervision of the City or the authorized agent; and the  right is reserved to said City to decline to connect with plumbing not done in accordance with the existing rules and regulations, or the orders of the City pertaining thereto.

Subd. 4.	Repair or Replacement of Service Lines or Appurtenances.

A. The City shall have the sole authority to repair or replace, at the owner's expense, any service lines or appurtenances thereto on public property that due to damage or faulty condition are leaking or inoperable. The City need not obtain a property owner's permission to make such repairs.

B. In the event a service line on private property is damaged or in faulty condition resulting in leaks, said private property owner shall have a maximum of 72 hours to repair said leak. In the event said repairs are not made within the 72 hour period, the City shall have the right to turn off the water.
 
Subd. 5.	Water Meters And Meter Appurtenances.

A. All water meters and meter appurtenances used  in the  City  for  City water shall be owned, furnished and kept in ordinary repair by the City. The original installation must be accomplished by a licensed plumber or the City.

B. All such water meters and meter appurtenances must be so set up and maintained that they can be easily examined and read, and be provided with suitable protection so as to make them safe  from frost or other damage; and the consumer or customer of such meter and meter appurtenances, at the consumer or customer's expense, must furnish such	protection. In case any such water meter and/or meter appurtenances are injured, by frost or otherwise damaged by the carelessness	of the consumer or customer, or the consumer or customer's agent or servant, or because the consumer or customer neglects or fails to furnish a safe and suitable place for the meter and/or meter appurtenances or the protection thereof, or such meter  and/or meter appurtenances should be damaged by the consumer or customer, then such meters and/or meter appurtenances may be repaired or replaced by the City at the expense of the consumer or customer, or property owner, as the City may determine. In case of neglect or refusal by the consumer or customer to furnish safe and suitable protection so as to make such meter and/or appurtenances safe from frost or other damage, the City or its authorized agent shall refuse to  turn on  City water, or until the consumer or customer shall have complied with such requirement, said City shall install all such water meters and/or meter appurtenances and replace and keep the same in ordinary repair at the expense of the City, provided such repair or replacement is not caused by the negligence of the consumer or customer, or his refusal to comply with the terms of this Chapter, or the rules of the City.

Subd. 6.	General Provisions.

A. Where City water is used or furnished for purposes not specified in the ordinance adopting rates, the charges shall be fixed by the City Council and where different or larger water meters than are specified are used, such service charges shall be made therefore as the City Council may determine.

B.	Persons wishing to obtain bulk amounts of water must obtain the water from the Public Works Department at designated facilities with loading to be supervised by City personnel.
 
C.	Person(s) shall be charged actual costs of labor and equipment supplied by the City in addition to the water charges. In no event  shall  any person obtain water from any City hydrant other than provided herein.

D.	Any person desiring to use City hydrants for the purpose of filling a swimming pool shall contact the Public Works Department. The Public Works Department shall arrange for the provision of  services  for  the filling of the pool and shall attach a meter to the hydrant to measure the water usage, and certify the meter reading to the Public Works Department office for billing purposes. The charges made therefor to be contained on the regular billing as sent to the consumer or customer.

E.	A consumer or customer who  wishes  to  connect  to  the  City's  water system for the purpose of supplying water to a fire suppression sprinkler system or private fire hydrant for use as firefighting protection, shall be permitted to connect to the street main at the consumer  or customer's own expense upon application to the City and upon approval thereof. Construction of said main to be supervised by an authorized agent of the  City. The  use of such water to be restricted  solely to firefighting purposes. All valves admitting water to such pipes must be sealed. In the event a seal is broken or damaged, the consumer or customer must notify the Public Works Department of such damage or breakage.

F.	All water supplied for emergency firefighting purposes shall be furnished at no cost to the consumer or customer.

G.	All sprinkler and private fire hydrant annual charges  not paid  and becoming delinquent may be recovered by assessing the property. The unpaid  balance shall be placed on the assessment  roll as provided  by the City Charter and Statute provisions.

 
Subd. 7.
Maintenance.
 
Cross Connection Device Installation, Testing and
 

A.  The terms "Administrative Authority," "cross-connection," "backflow preventer," "testable backflow prevention assembly" shall have the same meanings as set forth in the Minnesota Plumbing Code.  The City Council or its designee shall act as the Administrative Authority for purposes of enforcing the provisions of this ordinance.

B.	All plumbing connections to the City's water distribution system shall be installed in accordance with the Minnesota Plumbing Code, as it may be amended.   If in accordance with the Minnesota Plumbing Code, or if in the judgement of the Administrative Authority, an approved backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water system, the Administrative Authority will give notice to the water customer to
 
install such an approved device immediately.  The water customer shall, at his own expense, install such an approved device immediately at a location and in a manner that is compliant with the Minnesota Plumbing Code.

C.	The Administrative Authority must be notified prior to the installation of any testable backflow prevention assembly.

D.	Any cross-connection control devices, including but not limited to Reduced Pressure Backflow Preventers (RPZ) or other testable backflow prevention assemblies, shall be inspected, maintained and overhauled at intervals not exceeding those identified in the Minnesota Plumbing Code.  A test and inspection tag that includes the test date, and tester signature and identification number, shall be affixed to the device.  Written records of testing and maintenance shall be maintained
and submitted to the Administrative Authority.  The City may designate a
process or outside entity to monitor and track reporting requirements.

E.	No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be established, or maintain or permit to be maintained, any connection whereby a private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public water supply of the City may enter the supply or distribution system of the City unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of connection and use of such supply shall be approved by the Administrative Authority and the Minnesota Department of Health.

F.	The Administrative Authority shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution system of the City for the purpose of verifying the presence or absence of cross connections or testing backflow devices
or assemblies or for verifying information submitted by the customer
regarding the required cross-connection control inspection. Such requirement shall be a term and condition related to the privilege of receiving water from the City public water supply.  In the event that the person in ownership or control of the property should refuse or prevent entry or inspection, the City may seek the issuance of an administrative search warrant.  On demand, lessees or occupants of any property served by the City public water supply shall furnish to the Administrative Authority any information requested regarding the piping system or systems or water use on such property. The refusal of such information, when demanded, shall, within the discretion of the Administrative Authority, be deemed evidence of the presence of improper connections as provided by this ordinance and shall require that backflow protection be installed on the service line to the premise.
 
G.	The Administrative Authority after reasonable notice to the property owner and lessee or occupant, if applicable, may discontinue the water service to any property wherein any condition in violation of the cross­ connection control requirements outlined in this ordinance or the Minnesota Plumbing Code is known to exist and to take such other precautionary measures as it may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply distribution mains.
Water service to any property that has been disconnected from the
public water supply shall not be restored until such conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with this section and the reconnection charge identified in the fee schedule is paid to the City. Immediate disconnection with verbal notice can be affected when the Administrative Authority  reasonably believes that imminent danger of harmful contamination of the public water supply exists.  Such action shall be followed by written notification of the cause for disconnection. Immediate disconnection without notice to any party can be affected to prevent actual or anticipated contamination or pollution of the public water supply, provided that, in the opinion of the Administrative Authority or the Minnesota Department of Health, such action is required to prevent contamination or pollution of the public water supply.  Neither
the public water supply, the Administrative Authority, or its agents or assigns shall be liable to any customer for any injury, damages, or lost revenues which may result from termination of said customer water supply in accordance with the terms of this section, whether or not said termination was with or without notice.

H.	Any person who has knowledge of a backflow into any potable water system or to the public water system must report that backflow to the City's Utility Department immediately upon becoming aware of the backflow.  Any person responsible for any substance that enters the potable water system through backpressure or back-siphonage, or contamination of the public water supply system occurs through an illegal cross-connection or an improperly installed, maintained or repaired device or a device that has been bypassed, must bear the cost of the cleanup of the potable water supply system.

Subd. 8.	Regulations governing nonessential water usage upon critical water deficiency as authorized by Minn. Stat.§ 103G.291, Subd. 1. and 2.
A.  This Subd. establishes water conservation restrictions; and the plan will
be in effect at any time the governor declares by executive order a critical water deficiency, pursuant to Minnesota Statutes section 103G.291.

B.	Application
1.	This rule applies to all entities, including residential, commercial, industrial and institutional customers that acquire water from the City
 
of Red Wing's municipal water supply system who own or control water use on any premise.
2.	No person shall make, cause, use, or permit the use of water received from a the City of Red Wing municipal water supply system for residential, commercial, industrial, governmental, or any other purpose in any manner contrary to any provision in this ordinance.
3.	Mandatory emergency conservation measures shall be implemented based upon the declaration of a critical water emergency by the governor.

C.	Declaration of Critical Water Deficiency - Upon the declaration of a critical water deficiency by the governor, the public water supplier shall immediately post notice of the emergency declaration at the usual meeting place of the City Council, or the official city bulletin boards. The city shall provide notification to the public as quickly as possible or through established water supply plans emergency response plans or procedures.

D.	Mandatory Emergency Water Conservation Measures - Upon declaration of a water emergency and notification to the public, the following mandatory restrictions upon nonessential water use shall be enforced:
1.	Outdoor irrigation of yards, gardens, golf courses, parklands, and
other non-agricultural land, except for those areas irrigated with reclaimed water, is prohibited. Reclaimed water means water collected from rooftops, paved surfaces, or other collection devices and all water utilized more than once before re-entering the natural water cycle.
2.	Washing or spraying of sidewalks, driveways, parking areas, tennis
courts, patios, or other paved areas with water from any pressurized source, including garden hoses, except to alleviate immediate health or safety hazards, is prohibited.
3.	The outdoor use of any water-based play apparatus connected to a
pressurized source is prohibited.
4.	Restaurants and other food service establishments are prohibited from serving water to their customers, unless water is specifically requested by the customer.
5.	Operation of outdoor misting systems used to cool public areas is prohibited.
6.	The filling of swimming pools, fountains, spas, or other exterior water features is prohibited.
7.	The washing of automobiles, trucks, trailers, and other types of mobile equipment is prohibited, except at facilities equipped with wash water recirculation systems, and for vehicles requiring frequent washing to protect public health, safety, and welfare.
 
E.	Variances - The Council Administrator or their designee is authorized to grant variances to this ordinance where strict application of its provisions would result in serious hardship to a customer. A variance may be granted only for reasons involving health or safety. An applicant may appeal the denial of a variance within five (5) days of the decision by submitting a written appeal to the City Clerk. The City Council shall hear the appeal at the next City Council meeting. The decision of the City Council is final.

F.	Violation - Violations shall be determined and cited by the Council Administrator or his/her designee. A violator may appeal the citation within five (5) days of its issuance by submitting a written appeal to the City. The City Council shall hear the appeal at the next City Council meeting. The decision of the City Council is final. Violators may be granted an administrative waiver if evidence is provided that equipment failure was the cause of the violation. A letter from a qualified vendor or equipment invoice will be required to show proof of equipment failure.
1.	Upon discovery of a first violation, the violator shall be issued, either
personally or by mail, a warning letter that sets forth the violation and which shall describe the remedy and fines for future violations.
2.	Upon subsequent violations at the same location, the violator shall be issued, either personally or by mail, a citation that sets forth the violation and shall describe the remedy.
3.  Fines shall be invoiced or added to the monthly water bill of the
owner or current occupant of the premises where the violation occurred. The imposition of the fine shall in no way limit the right of the City to pursue other legal remedies.

G.	Enforcement - The Council Administrator or his/her designee is authorized to designate city employees or law enforcement personnel to enforce the provisions of this ordinance.

H.	Severability - If any provision of this ordinance or the application of any provision to a particular situation is held to be invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remaining portions of the ordinance and the application of the ordinance to any other situation shall not be invalidated.

SECTION 3.06.	SPECIAL WATER CONNECTION CHARGES.   In
addition to water service and water installation costs, whenever a connection is made to the public water supply system, the property owner shall pay a special water connection charge in an amount determined from time to time by ordinance of the City Council.  Payment shall be made at the time the building permit is taken out.  Whenever the use of a parcel intensifies from residential to commercial or industrial, the special water connection charge shall be recalculated at the higher
 
rate corresponding to the intensified use, with credit for the previously assessed residential rate.

SECTION 3.07.	RULES AND REGULATIONS RELATING TO SANITARY SEWERAGE SERVICE.

Subd. 1. For the purpose of providing funds to meet  the  cost  of operating and maintaining the sewage disposal system  and  the  facilities connected therewith, the payment of capital charges represented  by bonds, certificates of indebtedness, or otherwise and the payment of reasonable requirements of replacement and obsolescence thereof, there is hereby charged, levied and assessed upon each lot, parcel of land, building or premises having a connection with the sewerage system, or otherwise discharging sewage, industrial wastes, water or other liquids directly or indirectly into the sewerage system and there is hereby charged against the consumer or customer, sewer user charge determined and payable as hereinafter provided.

Subd. 2. The sewer user charge shall be determined by measuring by means of water meters or special sewer metering devices connected at each lot, parcel of land, building or premises, the quantity of water used, and applying the flow rate fee as set forth herein in this Section. In cases where the City requires the installation of suitable measuring, sampling and analyzing devices to measure suspected high levels of BOD, SS, or other pollutants, an additional sewer use surcharge shall be made to cover the additional costs of treatment according to the rates set forth herein in this Section for BOD, SS and other pollutants.

Subd. 3. In the event any lot, parcel of land, building or premises discharging sanitary sewage, industrial wastes, water, or other liquids into the sanitary sewerage system either directly or indirectly, is supplied  in whole  or in part with water not obtained from the City, the consumer or customer shall cause to be installed at their own expense necessary metering equipment as approved by the Public Works Department  to measure the quantity  of water  pumped  or used and the charge shall be based on the quantity of water so measured. Whenever the consumer or customer fails to install such metering equipment, or where it is not practicable to measure the water consumed on any premises by a meter or meters, the City shall cause to be determined in such manner and by such methods as may be practicable, considering conditions and attendant circumstances in each case, the estimated volume of water from private sources which discharge into the sanitary sewerage system, and such estimate shall be used in lieu of the meter volume of water from private sources to determine the sewer user charge therefor.

Subd. 4. The  City  Council  shall  annually  determine  and  fix  the  unit costs for use of the sewerage system on the basis of flow (including Infiltration/Inflow), BOD, SS and any other pollutant, taking into consideration the cost of treatment of such sewage, and may increase or decrease such unit cost as
 
often  and  in such  amounts  as  may  reasonably  be  required  to  accomplish  the purposes of this Subdivision.

Subd. 5. The City shall  compute  the  amount  due  for  charges  and render a statement thereof, at periodic intervals, as directed by the City Council to the consumer or customer.  All amounts due shall be payable to the City.

Subd. 6. The City Finance Department shall once each year provide an internal audit report that will address specific areas of concern including the need to generate sufficient revenue through sewer user charges to cover total operation and management costs, the necessity of maintaining  a proportionate system of sewer user charges pursuant to 40 Code of Federal Rules Regulations Section 35.935-13(b), the need to review the replacement account to determine its proper level of funding.

Subd. 7. Property outside the City which is served by and uses the sewerage system shall pay the same amount of sewer user charge as set forth in the above unit costs for property inside the City. Additional costs may be applied for providing such service to properties outside the City if such extra costs are specifically related to serving those properties. Charges for sewer service  to property outside the City which is served by a collection system maintained by another governmental subdivision shall be the subject of agreements between the City and such other governmental subdivision, such agreement to be approved by the City Council.

Subd. 8. The amounts due to the City for sewer user charges will be computed in accordance with the provisions of this Section and statements will be rendered at the same time and on the same bill with other City services.

Subd. 9.   Nothing in this Section shall be held or construed  as in any way prohibiting the City's right to levy taxes against any premises affected.

Subd. 10. Any charges levied by and pursuant to this Section, not paid and becoming delinquent, may be recovered from the consumer,  customer,  or owner occupant of the premises served in a civil action by the City in any court of competent jurisdiction at the City's election.

Subd. 11. Funds received from the charges herein established for the payment of bond principal and interest shall be transferred to the related debt retirement fund of the City.

Subd. 12.  The costs to  be recovered  pursuant to this Section and the unit cost to be fixed by the City Council as defined hereinbefore, except as otherwise provided herein, shall be determined and allocated  to cover operation and maintenance of the City's wastewater collection, conveyance and treatment facilities.    This  shall  include  the  annual  cost  of  administration,  operation  and
 
maintenance for the City's wastewater collection, conveyance and treatment facilities, including sludge disposal costs, and shall be deposited in the Sanitary Sewer Fund. Funds received for replacement costs of equipment  and  real property shall be deposited in the Sanitary Sewer Replacement Fund. Replacement costs shall  be defined as expenditures  for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories or appurtenances which are necessary during the  useful life of the treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance  for which such works were designed and constructed.

Subd. 13. Monitored User Charges. For those  users  that  the  City requires installation of suitable measuring, sampling and analyzing devices to measure BOD, SS, or other pollutants, the unit costs for Flow, BOD, SS, or other pollutants shall be calculated by apportioning each cost to Flow, BOD, SS, or other pollutants, and then dividing each cost so apportioned by the total estimated Flow, BOD, SS, or other pollutants to be received from the users at the wastewater treatment plant in that year.

A. Monitored user charges shall be the sum of the products obtained by multiplying the unit costs as determined above by the user's actual flow volume in cubic feet, BOD per 100 pounds, SS per 100 pounds or other pollutants during the billing period; however, in no case shall the charge be less than that determined by applying the prevailing flow rate charge to the user's actual flow volume measured in cubic feet.

B		In addition to the sewer user charge set  forth  herein,  the  City  may impose  a  sewer   user  surcharge  for  other  pollutants  which require special  treatment at any of the City's wastewater   conveyance   or treatment	facilities.   The  surcharge   may   consist   of   unit charges, reimbursement of documented expenses or a combination thereof.

C. The sewer user surcharge may also include the annual interest and principal	cost necessary to retire any bonds issued to pay for construction to the sewage treatment facilities made necessary to provide special treatment, with such debt retirement costs to be determined and allocated in the same manner as described for annual operation and maintenance costs.

Subd. 14.  Monitoring  of Strength  and Volume.  When  required  by the City, a user shall install suitable measuring, sampling and analyzing devices in compliance with this Section.

A. The City shall not require installation of such devices where the City determines that such user has concentrations of BOD, and suspended solids no greater than the concentration of such constituents in the general municipal flow and a satisfactory method and access exist for sampling and determining the total daily sewage  flow.    In such cases,
 
the charges to those users shall be based on the flow rate as determined and on BOD and SS loads equal to the average load of the general municipal flow.

B.	Each user required by the City to install and maintain sewerage monitoring facilities shall submit to the City a  monthly  report  of flow, BOD and SS or other pollutants on a form approved by the City. This report shall be used for billing purposes and shall be submitted prior to the 15th day of the subsequent month.

C.	The City shall have the right to periodically or continuously  inspect the monitoring facilities, to  measure,  sample  and  analyze  the  monitored user's flow, and to analyze the samples obtained by the monitored user.

D.	In the event of any discrepancy between the flows or loads determined by the City and the monitored user, the values determined by the City shall be used for billing purposes.

E.	All measurements, tests, and analysis of the characteristics of sewage concentration	shall be determined in accordance with procedures established by  United  States  Environmental  Protection  Agency  in 40 Code of Federal Regulations, Part 136 or the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," published  by the American Public Health Association, and shall be determined at the control   manhole  provided  or  upon  suitable   samples  taken  at  said manhole.   In the event that no special manhole is available, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected.

F.	A 24-hour composite sample of the sewage shall be taken by the City at least twice each year on those customers being assessed a surcharge. Additional sampling by the City will be taken upon written request by the user, with one-half of the cost of said sampling to be borne by the user.

Subd. 15. Charges for Non-Monitored Users. The charge for  non­ monitored users for this Section shall be set by determining the total annual cost of the operation and maintenance of the system and subtracting therefrom the total fees collected from other municipalities, contract users and monitored users which are applied to such costs. The balance remaining divided by the total annual estimated volume of wastewater less the estimated volume for municipalities, contract users, and monitored users shall be the unit cost per volume of wastewater.
 
A. The charges to non-monitored users shall be the product of the unit cost obtained in accordance with this Subdivision and the quantity of water used by such user as measured by the City water meter on the premises; provided, however, that in determining the charge to be paid for premises used exclusively for residential purposes, the water meter readings from the first quarter of each year may be used as the basis for the computation of such user charges for each billing  period  for  that year.

B.	In the event a non-monitored user is not supplied with City water or the water so used is not measured, the user charge shall be fixed and determined by the City in such methods as it may find just, equitable and practicable.

C.	In the event sewer service is disconnected by the City during  any quarter for any reason, the sewer service charge shall be reduced proportionately in the same manner  that water service rates   are reduced.

D.	If a substantial portion of the water utilized by any user is not discharged into the sewerage system, the volume of water shall be deducted in computing the sewer use charge provided a separate meter is installed to measure each volume. The user desiring to install  such  separate meter shall make application and payment for the meter to the City and engage, at his own expense, a plumber to effect the necessary piping changes and install the couplings so the meter can be serviced.

Subd. 16. Availability Charge.  Administrative costs, insurance and contingencies shall be recovered by an availability  charge  which  shall  be computed in the following manner: The total cost of administrative expenses, insurance, contingencies and other fixed costs as may be determined by  City Council are to be divided by the number of users and the resulting figure would be the availability costs charged to each user having a service connection.

Subd. 17. Expenses. All expenses relating to installation, repair, or maintenance of lateral sewer service lines shall be paid by the applicant for such improvements and services.



SECTION 3.08. CONTROLS ON USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS AND PRETREATMENT OF INDUSTRIAL WASTEWATER.

Subd. 1.	General Provisions.
 
A. Purpose and Policy. This Section sets forth uniform requirements for discharges into the wastewater disposal system and enables the City to comply with all State and Federal laws.

B.	The objectives of this Section are: (1) to prevent the introduction of pollutants into the wastewater disposal system which will  interfere with the operation of the system or the use or disposal of the sludge; (2) to prevent the introduction of pollutants into the wastewater  disposal system which will pass through the system inadequately treated into receiving waters or the atmosphere or otherwise be incompatible with the system; and, (3) to improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewater and sludge from the system.

C.	This Section provides for the regulation of discharges into  the wastewater disposal system through the issuance of permits to certain users and through enforcement of the general requirements for the other users, authorizes monitoring and enforcement activities, requires user reporting, and provides for the setting of fees for   the  equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program established herein.

D.	This Section shall apply to the City and to persons outside the City who are, by contract or agreement with the City, users of the wastewater disposal	system. That wastewater system includes all structure, connections, and processes used in the treatment of municipal sanitary and industrial wastewater. This Section is also applicable to the Bench Street	Industrial WWTP, which is an integral component of the wastewater disposal system.

Subd. 2.	Definitions Related to Pretreatment.	The following terms, as used in this Section, shall have the meanings hereinafter designated:

1.	"Clean Water Act" - the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, as amended, 33. U.S.C. 1251, et seq.

2.	"Bench Street Wastewater Pretreatment Facility" - an industrial wastewater treatment works located at 1877  Bench  Street  owned and operated by the City whose purpose is to treat industrial wastewater before that waste is pumped into the general collection system for transport and further treatment.  This facility is considered a part of the "Wastewater Disposal System."

3.	"Director/Superintendent" - the director/superintendent of wastewater disposal system/of water pollution control/of public works or the person's duly authorized representative.
 
4.	"Industrial User" - a person who discharges to the wastewater disposal system liquid wastes resulting from the processes employed in industrial, manufacturing, trade, or business establishments,  or from the development of any natural resource.

5.	"Interference" - the inhibition or disruption of the wastewater disposal system	processes or operations which causes or significantly contributes to a violation of any requirement of the City's NPDES or State Disposal System Permit. The term includes prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal by the City in accordance with published regulations providing guidelines under Section 405 of the Clean Water Act (33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq.) or any regulations developed pursuant to the Solid Waste Disposal Act, the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substances  Control Act, or more stringent State criteria applicable to the method of disposal or use employed by the City.

6.	"National  Pollutant  Discharge  Elimination  System   (NPDES) Permit" - any permit or requirements issued by the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency (MPCA) pursuant to the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, as amended (33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq.); for the purpose of regulating the discharge of sewage, industrial wastes, or other wastes under the authority of Section 402 of the Clean Water Act.

7.	"Non Contact Cooling Water" - the water discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, or during which the only pollutant added to the water is heat.

8.	"pH" - the logarithm of the  reciprocal  of  the  concentration  of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution.

9.	"Pretreatment" - the process of reducing the amount of pollutants, eliminating pollutants, or altering the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater to a less harmful state prior to or in lieu of discharging or otherwise introducing such pollutants into the wastewater disposal system. The reduction, elimination, or alteration may be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes, process changes or other means, except as prohibited by this Section.

10.	"Significant Industrial User" - any industrial user of the wastewater disposal system which (i) has a discharge flow of 25,000 gallons or more per average work day, or (ii) has a flow greater than  five percent of the flow in the wastewater disposal system, or (iii) has in its wastes toxic pollutants as defined pursuant to Section 307 of the Clean  Water  Act  or  Minnesota  Statutes  and  Rules,  or  (iv)  has  a
 
significant impact, either singly or in combination with other contributing industries, on the wastewater disposal system, the quality of sludge, the system's effluent quality, or air emissions generated by the system.

11.	"State Disposal System Permit" - any permit (including any terms, conditions and requirements thereof), issued by the MPCA pursuant to Minnesota Statutes, Section 115.07 for a disposal system as defined by Minnesota Statutes, Section 115.01, Subd. 8.

12.	"Stormwater" -  any flow  occurring  during  or following  any  form  of natural precipitation and resulting therefrom.

13.	"User" - any person who discharges, causes  or  permits  the discharge of wastewater  into the wastewater disposal system.

14.	"Wastewater" - the liquid and water-carried industrial or domestic wastes from dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial facilities, and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water, and stormwater that may be present, whether treated or untreated, which is discharged into or permitted to enter the wastewater disposal system.

15.	"Wastewater Disposal System" or "System" - any devices, facilities, structures, equipment or works owned or used by the City for the purpose of the transmission, storage, treatment, recycling, and reclamation of industrial and domestic wastewater or necessary to recycle or reuse water, including intercepting sewers, outfall sewers, sewage collection systems, pumping, power, and other equipment, and their appurtenances; extensions, improvements, remodeling, additions, and alterations thereof; elements essential to provide a reliable recycled water supply such as standby treatment units and clear well facilities; and any works, including land that will be an integral part of the treatment process or is used for ultimate disposal of residues resulting from such treatment.

16.	"Waters of the State" - all streams, lakes, ponds, marshes, aquifers, irrigation	systems, drainage systems and all other bodies or accumulations of water, surface or underground, natural or artificial, public or private, which are contained within, flow through or border upon the State or any portion thereof.

17.	"Best Management Practices (BMPs)" - Activities, prohibition of practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices that reduce the discharge of fat, oil and grease (FOG) to the wastewater disposal system.
 

18.	"FOG" - Acronym for Fats, Oils and Grease.  These include any substance, such as a vegetable or animal product, that is used in or is a byproduct of, the cooking or food preparation process, and that turns or may turn viscous or solidify with a change in temperature or as a result of the conditions found in a sanitary sewer.


19.	"FOG Control Program Manager" - The individual designated by the Director of Public Works to administer the FOG Control Program.
The FOG Control Program Manager is responsible for all
determinations of compliance with the program, including approval of discretionary variances and waivers.


20.	"Food Service Establishment (FSE)" - All food service facilities including, but not limited to: full-service restaurants, fast food establishments, delicatessens, cafeterias, school cafeterias, church kitchens, hospitals and medical facilities, boarding houses, clubhouses, adult daycare facilities, assisted living facilities, convalescent homes, meat distributors and processing facilities, food processing facilities, grocery stores with food preparation/service areas, bakeries, caterers, and/or other similar types of operations with commercial kitchen equipment.


21.	"FSE Grease Control Responsible Party" - The entity named on the sewer account for the FSE.


22.	"Grease Interceptor" -A device designed to separate and retain FOG from normal wastes while permitting sewage or liquid wastes to  discharge into the drainage system.


23.	"Gravity grease interceptor'' - Grease interceptor identified by volume, detention time and gravity separation.  For purposes of this ordinance, a gravity grease inceptor shall have a minimum volume of 1000 gallons, minimum 2-compartment tank, and typically located underground, usually outside of a building, that reduces the amount of FOG in wastewater prior to its discharge into the sewer.


24.	Hydro-mechanical grease interceptor'' - A grease inceptor that ncorporates air entrainment, hydro-mechanical separation, interior baffling, and.for barriers in combination or separately. For purposes
 
of this ordinance, a hydro-mechanical grease interceptor is a small grease capturing device, usually located within a building.


25.	"Non-routine Inspection" - Impromptu, unscheduled inspection of an FSE made without prior notification or arrangement.


26.	"Routine Inspection" - Inspection of an FSE which is scheduled in advance or according to a pre-arranged schedule.


27.	Terms not otherwise defined shall be as given in Minnesota Statutes, chapters 115 and 116 as amended.



Subd. 3.	Regulations and Effluent Limitations.

A.	General Discharge Prohibitions. No user shall discharge or cause to be discharged, directly or indirectly, any of the following substances into the wastewater disposal system or to any public sewer:

1.	Any liquids, solids or gases which by  reason  of  their  nature  or quantity are, or may be, sufficient either alone or by interaction with other substances to  cause fire  or explosion  or be injurious  in any other way to the wastewater  disposal  system or to the operation of the system. At no time, shall waste streams  with  a  closed  cup flashpoint of less than 140 degrees Fahrenheit or 60  degrees Centigrade be introduced  into the wastewater disposal system. Prohibited	materials include, but  are  not  limited  to,  gasoline, kerosene,	naphtha, benzene,  toluene,  xylene,  ethers,  alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, peroxides, chlorates, perchlorates, bromates, carbides, hydrides and sulfides.

2.	Solid or viscous substances which will or may cause obstruction to the flow in a sewer or other interference with the operation of the wastewater treatment facilities such as, but not limited to, grease, garbage with particles greater than one-half inch in any dimension, animal guts or tissues, paunch manure, bones,  hair, hides or fleshings, entrails, whole blood, feathers, ashes, cinders, sand, spent lime, stone or marble dust, metal, glass, straw, shavings, grass clippings, rags, spent grains, spent hops, waste paper, wood, plastic, gas tar, asphalt residues, residues from refining or processing of fuel or lubricating oil, mud or glass grinding or polishing wastes.

3.	Any wastewater having a pH  less  than  6.0  or  more  than  9.0  or having any other corrosive  property  capable  of causing damage  or
 
hazard  to  structures,  equipment,  and  personnel  of the wastewater disposal system.

4.	Any  wastewater  containing  toxic  pollutants  in  sufficient  quantity, either singly or by  interaction  with  other  pollutants,  to  inhibit  or disrupt any wastewater treatment process, constitute  a  hazard  to humans or animals, or create a toxic effect in the receiving waters of the wastewater disposal system. A toxic pollutant shall include, but not be limited to, any pollutant identified pursuant to Section 307(a) of the   Clean Water Act. Prescription drugs and other over-the­ counter pharmaceuticals shall be considered toxic pollutants.

5.	Any noxious or  malodorous  liquids,  gases,  or  solids  which  either singly or by interaction with other wastes are capable of creating a public nuisance or hazard to life or are sufficient to prevent entry into the sewers for their maintenance and repair.

6.	Any  wastewater  with  objectionable  color  not  removed  in  the treatment process, such as, but not limited to, dye wastes  and vegetable tanning solutions.

7.	Any wastewater which creates conditions at or near the wastewater disposal system which violate any statute or any rule, regulation or ordinance of any public agency or State or Federal regulatory body.

8.	Any wastewater having a temperature greater than 150°F (65.6°C), or causing, individually or in combination with other wastewater, the influent at the wastewater treatment plant  to have a temperature exceeding  104°F (40°C).

9.	Any slug load, which shall mean any pollutant, including oxygen demanding pollutants, released in a discharge of such  volume  or strength as to cause inhibition  or  disruption  in  the  wastewater disposal system. In no case shall a slug load have a flow rate or contain concentrations or quantities of pollutants that exceed for any time period longer than 15 minutes more than 5 times the average 24  hour concentrations, quantities, or flow of the user during normal operation.

10.	Non-contact cooling water or unpolluted storm or groundwater.

11.	Any wastewater containing fats, wax, grease, or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of +150 mg/I or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures  between 32°F and 150°F (0°C and 65.6°C); and any wastewater containing oil and
 
grease  concentrations  of mineral  origin  of greater than  +100 mg/I, whether emulsified or not.

Introduction of any additives into the wastewater disposal system for the purpose of emulsifying FOG or biologically or chemically treating any substance introduced into any wastewater facility for purpose of treatment or pretreatment of wastewater unless a specific written authorization by the FOG Control Program Manager is obtained.

Discharge of any FOG or any other solid materials removed from the grease control device to the wastewater disposal system.



12.	Wastewater containing inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, Fullers earth, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate) in such quantities that they would cause disruption with the wastewater disposal system.

13.	Any wastewater  following  pretreatment  or  directly  discharged containing	the  following  described   elements   in   concentrations greater than those included in the following list:

Maximum Daily Concentrations Cd	0.20 mg/I
Cr	2.80 mg/I
Cu	3.38 mg/I
Pb	0.40 mg/I
Hg	0.10 mg/I
Ni	2.98 mg/I
Ag	0.43 mg/I
Zn	2.61 mg/I

All discharge shall comply with the above limits unless the City has applied for a pollutant removal credit or exception and a pollutant removal credit or exception has been granted to a user or category of users that permits discharge in excess of the  Maximum  Daily Limits referenced in this Subdivision This exception shall only apply so long as the removal credit remains valid, and only so long as the discharge subject to the pollution removal credit or exception does not interfere with the operation of the System or pass through the System inadequately treated contrary to the purpose statement in Subdivision 1(B) of this Section.

B.	In addition to these  prohibitions,  no user shall discharge to any public sewer  any  discharge  which  causes  interference,  as  defined,  with  the
 
wastewater disposal system. Pollutants in the effluent from an industrial user shall not be considered to cause interference where the industrial user is in compliance with specific prohibitions or standards developed by Federal, State, or local governments. Where the industrial user is in compliance with such specific prohibitions or standards and pollutants in the effluent from the industrial user's facility nevertheless are determined to have caused or significantly contributed to a violation of any requirement of the City's NPDES or State Disposal System Permit, and are likely to cause such a violation in the future, the City must take appropriate action to develop and enforce specific effluent limits for that industrial user to ensure renewed and continued compliance with  the City's NPDES or State Disposal System Permit.

C.	It is unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the City limits or City jurisdiction any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this Section.

D.	It is unlawful to either construct, maintain, use, or permit to be used any cesspool, privy, or privy vault on any part of any lot or parcel of land in the City abutting both on a public sanitary sewer and a water main with which water and  sewer connections may  be made, if said privy, privy vault or cesspool be within 500 feet of said public sanitary sewer and also within 500 feet of said water mains. The City shall have power whenever there is both a public sewer and a water main in the public highways or grounds upon which any premises in the City abuts  to cause the owner or occupant of such parcel of land to connect said premises with said public sewer by sufficient sanitary sewer whenever, in the City's opinion, the same may be necessary for the preservation of the public health. The City shall serve upon such owner or occupant ten days' notice in writing specifying the time when such sewer connection or connections must be made and completed and if the said owner or occupant neglects to complete the same  within the time specified, in addition to the penalties imposed for a violation of any of the provisions of this Section, the City may cause it to be done and shall either recover the whole amount of the expense thereof by an action  against  the owner, in the name of the City, before any court having jurisdiction thereof,	or assess the same against said premises pursuant  to Minnesota State Statutes. Nothing in this Section shall be interpreted to require the service of sewage wastes at published sewer  rates when such waste may  impair the sewer or cause a higher-than-normal expense in operation of the sewerage system. Nor shall this Section be interpreted to prohibit the handling of deleterious wastes, requirements for pretreatment, or sewer service  rates higher than published rates on an agreement  basis.   Such agreements  may be approved  by the  City
 
after considering  the  problems  in handling the  effect  on the  sewerage system and the cost of handling the waste.

E.	New connections to the City's sewer system may be restricted and/or not allowed in the event that such connection would increase  flows and/or loads above available capacity existing in either the collection or treatment system.

F.	Duly authorized City employees bearing proper identification shall, at reasonable times, be permitted to enter upon properties served by sanitary sewers for the purpose of inspection, measurement, sampling, and testing in connection with operation of the sewer system.

G.	Persons engaged in construction or maintenance activity where there is connection to or danger of damage to the sewer system shall exercise particular care to protect the sewer system, and shall at all times protect, keep foreign materials out, and accomplish  construction or connections in a neat and workmanlike manner.  Failure to do so shall be a violation of this Section and shall not stop the City from correcting the damage or removing the foreign material, if necessary on an overtime basis, and collecting the costs therefor.  For other than immediate necessary repair or removal, a five-day written notice shall be deemed adequate notice to the party to repair damage, correct faulty construction or remove material from the sewerage system.

H.	Roof, groundwater or surface drain connections to the sanitary sewer system	are prohibited. All sewer service connections shall be constructed in accordance with requirements of the Minnesota Plumbing Code in effect at the time of construction and such work shall only be done by a contractor licensed to perform such connection. Prior to construction of any sewer connection, the proper  permit shall be obtained from the Building Official.

Subd. 4.	Limitations on Wastewater Strength.

A. National Categorical Pretreatment Standards. National categorical pretreatment	standards promulgated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) pursuant to the Clean Water Act shall be met by all users which are subject to such standards in any instance where they are more stringent than the limitations in this Section unless the Director has applied for and obtained from the MPCA approval to modify the specific limits in the national categorical pretreatment standards. When	requested, an application for modification of the national categorical pretreatment standards will be considered  for  submittal  by the Director when the wastewater treatment system achieves consistent removal of the pollutants.  "Consistent removal" shall be defined as in 40
 
CFR 403.7 (a) (1) of the "General Pretreatment Regulations for Existing and New Sources of Pollution." Conditional revisions of national categorical pretreatment standards may be made by the City in accordance with 403.7 (b) (2) (i-iv) of the "General Pretreatment Regulations for Existing and New Sources of Pollution" if requested by the industry(ies) in accordance with requirements of 403.7 (b) (1) (i).

B.	State Requirements. State requirements and limitations on discharges shall be met by all users which are subject to such standards in any instance in which they are more  stringent  than  Federal  requirements and limitations or those in the City Code.

C.	Right of Revision. The City reserves the right to  establish  more stringent limitations or requirements on discharges to the wastewater disposal system if deemed necessary to comply with the objectives of this Section.

D.	Dilution. No user shall increase the use of process water or, in any way, attempt to dilute a discharge as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment to achieve compliance with the limitations in this Section, in the national categorical pretreatment standards, or in any State requirements.

E.	Accidental Discharges. Each user shall  provide  protection  from accidental	discharge of prohibited materials or other substances regulated by this Section. Where necessary, facilities to prevent accidental discharge of prohibited materials shall be provided and maintained at the owner or user's  own  cost  and  expense.  Detailed plans showing facilities and operating procedures to  provide  this protection shall be submitted to the Director for review, and shall be approved by the Director before construction of the facility. Review and approval of such plans and operating procedures shall not relieve the industrial user from the responsibility to modify the user's facility as necessary to meet the requirements of this Section. Users shall notify the Director immediately upon having a slug or accidental  discharge of substances or wastewater in violation of this Section in order to enable countermeasures to be taken by the Director to minimize damage to the wastewater disposal system and the receiving waters. Such notification will not relieve users of liability for any expense, loss or damage to the wastewater disposal system or treatment process, or for any fines imposed on the City on account thereof under any State or Federal law. A notice shall be permanently posted on the user's bulletin  board  or other prominent place advising new employees whom to  call  in  the event of a slug or accidental discharge. Employers shall insure that all employees who may cause or discover such a discharge are advised of the emergency  notification procedure.
 

Subd. 5.	Fees.

A.	Purpose. It is the purpose of this Section to provide for the recovery of costs	from users of the wastewater disposal system for the implementation of the program established herein. The applicable charges or fees shall be set forth in the Schedule of Charges and Fees, to be prepared, from time to time, by the Director and approved by the City Council.

B. Charges and Fees. The City Council  shall  adopt  charges  and  fees which may include: (1) fees for monitoring, inspections and surveillance procedures; (2) fees for permit applications; (3) appeal fees; and,  (4) other fees as the Director may deem necessary to carry out the requirements contained in this Section.

Subd. 6.  Administration-General  User  Reports.   The   Director   may require that any person discharging or proposing to discharge wastewater to the wastewater disposal system file a period discharge report. The discharge report may include, but not be limited to, nature of process, rates of flow, mass discharge rate, raw material and production quantities, hours of operation, number and classification of employees, compliance status with any State or Federal pretreatment standards, or other information which relates to the generation  of waste, including wastewater constituents and concentrations in the wastewater discharge. Such reports may also include sludge disposal practices and the chemical constituents and quantity of liquid or gaseous materials stored on site, even though they may not normally be discharged.
