Minnesota Department of Transportation in accordance with Minnesota Statutes section 221.0252.

D.	The carrying of passengers as a business for compensation by a vehicle other than a vehicle duly licensed under and operating in accordance with the provisions of this ordinance, or by a vehicle contracted through a Transportation Network Company, or by a motor carrier operating under Minnesota Statutes, is hereby forbidden.

E.	This Ordinance applies in equal force to all small passenger vehicle services, motor carriers of passengers, and special transportation services operating within the City, regardless of whether the service's principal place of business is located outside of the City.
 
SECTION 6.15.	TOBACCO.

Subd. 1.	Definitions.  As used in this section, the terms used shall have the following meanings:

1.	"Tobacco" - cigarettes and any product containing, made, or derived from tobacco that is intended for human consumption, whether chewed, smoked, absorbed, dissolved, inhaled, snorted, sniffed, or ingested by other means, or any component, part, or accessory of a tobacco product including, but not limited  to,  cigars;  cheroots; stogies; perique; granulated, plug cut, crimp cut, ready rubbed, and other smoking tobacco, snuff,  snuff flour; cavendish; plug and twist tobacco; fine cut and other chewing tobaccos; shorts; refuse scraps; clippings, cuttings and sweepings of tobacco; and other kinds and forms of tobacco.

2.	"Tobacco-Related Device" - cigarette papers or pipes for smoking or other devices intentionally designed or intended to be used in a manner that enables the chewing, sniffing, smoking, or inhalation of vapors of tobacco or tobacco products, including components of tobacco-related devices marketed or sold separately.

3.	"Electronic-Delivery Device" - any product containing or delivering nicotine,	lobelia, or any other substance intended for human consumption that can be used by a person to simulate smoking in the delivery of nicotine or any other substance through inhalation of vapor from the product, including any component part of a product marketed or sold separately.

4.	"Nicotine or Lobelia Delivery Device" - any product containing or delivering nicotine or lobelia intended for human consumption, or any component part of such a product, that is not tobacco or an electronic-delivery  device.

5.	"Adult" - a person 18 years of age, or over.

6.	"Licensee" - any person lawfully possessing a license to sell, dispense, or give away tobacco, tobacco-related devices, electronic­ delivery devices, or nicotine or lobelia delivery devices and shall include any employee, agent, or representative of any person having such a license.

7.	"Person" - any individual, corporation, partnership, or other entity.

8.	Daycare Facility" - a daycare center as defined in Minnesota Rules 9503.0005, subpart 5, as amended.
 

9.	"Vending Machine" - any mechanical, electrical or electronic, or other type of device which dispenses tobacco, or tobacco-related devices, electronic-delivery devices, or nicotine or lobelia delivery devices upon the insertion of money, tokens, or other form of payment directly or into the machine by the person seeking to purchase the tobacco, or tobacco-related device, electronic-delivery device, or nicotine or lobelia delivery device.

Subd. 2.	License Required.

A		License. It is unlawful for any person, directly or indirectly, to keep for retail sale, sell at retail, or otherwise furnish for profit or benefit any tobacco,obacco-related	devices,	electronic-delivery	devices,	or nicotine or  lobelia delivery  devices without  a valid  license obtained from the City.  Application for the license shall be on a form approved and provided by the City.

B.	Amended Definitions. Any amendments to the definitions of the terms   "tobacco,"  "tobacco  related  device,"   or  "electronic  delivery device"  found in Minnesota Statutes, section 609.685, or to "nicotine or lobelia  delivery device" as addressed in Minnesota Statutes, section 609.6855,  shall be considered amendments to the definition of the terms  found   herein. Any license issued pursuant to this Section shall  entitle  the   Licensee to sell  all  "tobacco,"  "tobacco related devices," "electronic  delivery devices," or "nicotine or lobelia delivery devices," as defined   herein,  while  that   license  remains active.

C.	License Fee. The license fee shall be set from time-to-time by City Council ordinance. All tobacco licenses shall be valid for one calendar year, from January 1 to December 31. Licenses may be issued anytime after January 1, but shall expire on December 31 of the year of issuance, and the license fee shall not be pro-rated.

Subd. 3.	Restrictions.

A Separate licenses shall be issued for the sale of tobacco at each fixed place of business, and no license shall be issued for a movable place of business.		No license shall be transferred  to the  new owner should a licensed	establishment be sold. The new owner of any such establishment must apply for a new license.

B.	It is unlawful for any person to sell, dispense, or give away any tobacco, tobacco-related device, electronic-delivery device, or nicotine or lobelia delivery  device to any person without first  having the person provide a
 
valid form of identification  providing proof that the individual is at least 18 years of age.

C.	It is unlawful for any Licensee to manufacture, advertise, deliver, or sell any drug paraphernalia, as that term is defined in Section 10.27 of the City Code. A violation of this restriction may be punished as a misdemeanor, as provided in Red Wing City Code Section 10.27, and/or be grounds for the suspension, revocation, denial,  or non-renewal of a license issued pursuant to this Section.  Any suspension or revocation of a license shall be done in conformance with Red Wing City Code Section 6.03, subd. 5. Notice of the hearing and the final decision shall be in writing. Any such suspension, revocation, denial or non-renewal shall also conform with Subdivision 10 of this Section.

D.	No tobacco license shall be issued to any establishment within 1000 feet of any school property or daycare facility, as measured by the shortest line between the property to be occupied by the proposed Licensee and the property occupied by the school or daycare facility, unless the Licensee continuously holds a tobacco license predating the enactment of this provision or the date that the school or daycare facility occupied the property.

E. It is unlawful for the Licensee to sell any liquid, whether or not such liquid contains nicotine, intended for human consumption and use in an electronic-delivery device that is not contained in packaging that is child­ resistant packaging as set forth in 16 C.F.R. § 1700.15(b)(1).

Subd. 4. Compliance Checks. Law enforcement officials or persons as designated by the City shall conduct periodic compliance checks of the premises of all holders of licenses for the sale of tobacco products. Compliance checks will be held at least two times per year. These compliance checks may include, but shall not be limited to surveillance, including minors under the age of 18 who attempt to purchase tobacco products.

A law enforcement official or persons as designated by the City shall issue  a license violation citation to any license holder found violating any provision of this code or the laws of the State of Minnesota. License suspension or revocation may be instituted following the issuance of a citation or criminal  conviction  of  any officer, director, manager, or other agent, employee, or representative of any licensee.

Subd. 5.       Responsibility.  Licensees shall be responsible for the conduct of their employees, agents, and representatives while on the  licensed premises. Any violation of this section by an employee, agent, or representative shall also be considered a violation by the licensee for the purposes of imposing a civil penalty, license suspension, revocation, denial or non-renewal.
 

Subd. 6. Vending  Machines.  No  sale  of  tobacco,  tobacco-related devices, electronic-delivery devices, or nicotine or lobelia delivery devices  may occur through vending machines.

Subd. 7.  Self-service  Merchandising.  No  sale  of  tobacco,  tobacco- related devices, electronic-delivery devices, or nicotine or lobelia delivery devices shall occur from open displays which are accessible to the public without the intervention of the Licensee. This subdivision shall not apply to the sale of cartons of cigarettes by a  Licensee who derives at least 90 percent of its revenue from tobacco, tobacco-related devices, electronic-delivery devices, or nicotine or lobelia delivery devices and where the Licensee ensures that no person younger than 18 years of age is present, or permitted to enter, at any time.

Subd. 8. Use and Sampling. Nothing in this Section shall prohibit the sampling of tobacco as provided for in the Minnesota Clean Indoor Air Act, Minnesota Statutes Section 144.4167, subdivision 4, provided that the Licensee ensures that  no person younger than 18 years of age is present or permitted to enter the premises at any time.  This  provision  shall  extend  to  allow  sampling using electronic-delivery devices or nicotine or lobelia delivery devices at licensed establishments deriving at least 90 percent of revenue from electronic-delivery devices or nicotine or lobelia delivery devices according to the same restrictions and limitations. It is prohibited for licensed establishments to provide access to seating in exchange for a fee or any other consideration, including, but not limited to, the purchase of tobacco, tobacco-related  devices, electronic-delivery  devices, or nicotine or lobelia delivery devices.

Subd. 9.	Penalties.

A Licensees. Any violation of the restrictions attached  to  the  tobacco license, including, but not limited to sale of tobacco, tobacco-related devices,	electronic-delivery devices, or nicotine or lobelia delivery devices to any person under 18 years of age, shall be cause for Administrative penalty,  suspension,  revocation,  denial,  or  non-renewal of such license, as well as any civil or criminal remedy available at law. Any suspension or revocation of a license shall be done in conformance with Red Wing City Code Section 6.03, Subd. 5. Notice of the hearing and the final decision shall be in writing.

License violations shall carry the following minimum administrative penalties: $75 for the first violation; $200 for a second violation at the same location within 24 months of the initial violation, and $250 and a minimum 7-day suspension for the third violation within 24 months of the initial violation. Nothing in this section prohibits the City from imposing additional penalties based upon the circumstances of violation, and the history of license violations at the same location.
 

In the case of a license suspension or revocation, there shall be no license fee refund. Any person whose license has been revoked shall not be eligible for another tobacco license for one year from the date of the license revocation. The City Council reserves the right to attach reasonable conditions to the reinstatement of a suspended or revoked license.

B.	Individuals.

1.	First offense. Any person who sells or furnishes tobacco, tobacco­ related devices, electronic-delivery devices, or nicotine or lobelia delivery devices to a person under 18 years of age shall be charged with a misdemeanor for the first violation. The  notice and hearing requirements for a licensee shall also apply to any person accused of violating this provision.

2.	Subsequent offenses. (a) Any person who sells tobacco, tobacco­ related devices, electronic-delivery devices, or nicotine or lobelia delivery devices to a person under 18 years of  age a subsequent time within five years of a previous conviction for the same offense is guilty of a gross misdemeanor. (b) Any person who furnishes tobacco, tobacco-related devices, electronic-delivery devices, or nicotine or lobelia delivery devices to a person under 18 years of age after conviction for the same offense shall be guilty of a gross misdemeanor for each subsequent violation.

3.	Administrative  fine.   Each offense committed  by an individual under this section shall carry a fine of $50 per offense.

4.	Affirmative  defense.    It is an affirmative defense to a charge  under this section if the defendant proves by a  preponderance  of  the evidence that the defendant reasonably and in good faith relied upon representative of  proof of age as described  in Minnesota Statutes, Section 340A.503, Subd. 6, as it may be amended from time to time.

C.	Minors.

1.	Misdemeanor. A person under the age of  18 years who purchases or attempts to purchase tobacco, tobacco-related devices, electronic­ delivery devices, or nicotine or lobelia delivery devices and who uses a driver's license, permit, Minnesota identification card, or any type of false identification to misrepresent the person's age, is guilty of a misdemeanor.

2.	Petty  misdemeanor.    A  person  under  the  age  of  18  years  who
 
possesses, smokes, chews, otherwise ingests, or purchases or attempts to purchase tobacco, tobacco-related devices, electronic­ delivery devices, or nicotine or lobelia delivery devices is guilty of a petty misdemeanor.

3.	Any person under the age of 18 years who purchases, possesses or uses tobacco, tobacco-related devices, electronic-delivery devices, or   nicotine or  lobelia  delivery  devices  shall  be  referred  to  an alternative juvenile justice  system.  If  no  alternative  system  is available or suitable to the juvenile's situation, the juvenile shall be subject to a $25 administrative penalty. The notice and hearing requirements for a licensee shall also apply to any person accused of violating this provision.

Subd. 10.	Appeal of Suspension,  Revocation,  Denial, or Nonrenewal of License.

A In the event the City suspends, revokes, denies, or determines not to renew a tobacco license, the City shall send to the licensee, by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of the action, and the right to appeal. The aggrieved party may appeal  the  decision  of  the  City within 10 days of receiving notice of the City's action. Filing of an appeal shall stay the action of the City in suspending or revoking a license until the City Council makes a final decision. Failure to file an appeal within the 10-day period shall be deemed a waiver of appeal.

B. The City Council may appoint a committee or an independent hearing officer to hear an appeal hereunder, report findings of fact, and provide a recommendation for disposition to the Council.  Hearings  on  the appeal shall be open to the public and the licensee  or applicant shall have the right to appear and be represented by legal counsel and to offer evidence on its behalf. At the conclusion of the hearing, the City Council shall make a final decision.

SECTION 6.16.	SIDEWALK CAFES.

Subd. 1.	Authorized;  license required.

A Any person authorized to operate a restaurant on designated premises within the City of Red Wing may apply to the City Council for a license to conduct a portion of the restaurant's authorized business in a sidewalk cafe on a part of the public way immediately adjoining the designated premises. Application shall be made on forms provided by the City and shall be accompanied by the fee required by City ordinance. A restaurant, if licensed under Chapter 5 of the Red Wing City Code for the on-sale of alcoholic beverages, may also request an amendment to
 
that  license  to  allow  the  sidewalk  cafe  to  be  a  part  of  the  licensed premises.

B.	A  scaled diagram  must be submitted with  information as requested on the application, including but not limited to the following:

•	width of the building or the  leased  premises  including  the dimension of the street frontage where the sidewalk cafe will be located;
•	layout for the sidewalk cafe furnishings (tables, chairs, umbrellas, fencing and anything else to be placed on the sidewalk) including the dimensions of the seating area;
•	width of the sidewalk remaining for pedestrian use;
•	the property lines; and,
•	location of trees (including tree grates), boulevard areas, other landscaping,	trash containers, bike racks, fire hydrants, mailboxes, street signs, utility poles and  boxes, and other obstacles.

In the case of a restaurant that holds a license under Chapter 5 of the Red Wing City Code and wishes to serve alcohol in the sidewalk cafe, this diagram shall be considered a description of the extended premises for purposes of the request to amend the on-sale alcohol license.

C.	To the extent authorized in any license granted under the provisions of this section, the licensee may conduct licensed business on the public way, notwithstanding the provisions of Section  7.07 of the  Red Wing City Code.

Subd. 2.	Restrictions.

A Each sidewalk cafe license shall specify the area in which the cafe may be operated. Cafe seating shall be allowed on the public sidewalk or hard-surfaced public walkway directly abutting the building housing the restaurant's premises. No sidewalk cafe seating, sale, or service shall be permitted on any unpaved or uneven surface or in any portion of the street designated for vehicular travel.

B.	No license shall authorize any permanent installation of any tables, chairs, furnishings, fencing, or other equipment on the public way. Only metal cafe style tables and chairs shall be allowed in the licensed sidewalk cafe area; no glass, plastic, or picnic style tables will be permitted. Umbrellas will be allowed if they do not create an obstacle for pedestrians or pose a safety hazard. It shall be the duty of the licensed restaurant to maintain sidewalk cafe furnishings,  such as chairs, tables,
 
and fencing in a neat, clean, safe, and sanitary condition and to inspect each item periodically.

C.	No license shall authorize placing any cafe fixtures on  the  sidewalk closer than 70 inches from any tree, boulevard,  landscaping,  public trash can, bike rack, fire hydrant, mailbox, street sign, utility pole or box, or other obstacle before 10:00 a.m., measured from the obstacle perpendicular from the curb toward the cafe fixtures. After 10:00 a.m., the sidewalk cafe must maintain a minimum of 44 inches of clearance from all obstacles for pedestrians, as measured from the obstacle perpendicular from the curb toward the cafe fixtures.

D.	No license shall authorize a sidewalk cafe at any location prohibited by state law or this section, except as herein provided.

E. Except as specifically provided herein, the ownership, operation and maintenance of a sidewalk cafe shall be subject to all applicable laws, ordinances, and regulations.

F.	No sidewalk cafe that is part of the licensed premises under Chapter 5 of the Red Wing City Code may be located within 200 feet of a residentially zoned district. The measurement will be  taken from the nearest portion of the sidewalk cafe to the nearest boundary of the residentially zoned district. This subsection shall not apply to any such restaurant whose gross sales revenue during the preceding fiscal year from the sale of food and beverages not containing alcohol was in an amount of not less than 70 percent of the total gross revenue for the sale of food and beverages.

G.	A restaurant holding a license under  Chapter  5 of the  Red Wing  City Code that includes a sidewalk cafe in the licensed premises may allow consumption of alcohol in the sidewalk cafe area until 10:00 p.m. only. The license holder shall comply with all requirements of law, and must take all reasonable  steps  to  insure  that  alcoholic  beverages  are consumed only by patrons of the restaurant who are of age and not by passersby or persons who are not of age or who are obviously intoxicated, and ensure that alcoholic  beverages  served  to  patrons remain on the licensed premises.

H.	Each sidewalk cafe seating area that is part of the licensed premises under Chapter 5 of the Red Wing City Code shall be delineated with a continuous, stable barrier, with one egress onto the public way. The barrier will be a minimum of 36 inches and a maximum of 48 inches above the sidewalk surface.
 
I.	The location of a sidewalk cafe shall in  no way  obstruct  any  of  the existing, required means of egress from the restaurant.

J. The occupant load within the interior of the restaurant, as established by the fire marshal, shall be reduced by the allowable occupant load in the sidewalk cafe so that all patrons can be accommodated indoors should the need arise due to inclement weather or other circumstances.

Subd. 3.	Indemnification  and  Insurance.	Before  a  license  is  issued pursuant to this section, the applicant shall:

A Execute and deliver to the Permits and License Manager, on a form prescribed by the City, an agreement in which the applicant agrees to indemnify, defend and hold the City harmless from any personal injury or property damage resulting from, or in any way related to, operation of the sidewalk cafe.

B. File with the Permits and License Manager evidence of Commercial General Liability insurance protecting the applicant against liability imposed by law arising out of the ownership, maintenance, or operation of such sidewalk cafe with limits in an amount of at least $1,000,000 per occurrence;	$2,000,000 general aggregate limit (coverage limit requirement may be satisfied by a General Liability policy in combination with an Excess Liability or Umbrella Liability policy). The insurance coverage must be primary, written on an "Occurrence" basis, and must list the City of Red Wing as an additional insured. All Certificates shall provide	for 30  days  written  notice  to  the  City  prior  to cancellation.	Restaurants licensed under Chapter 5 of the  Red Wing City	Code must extend Liquor Liability coverage, with  minimum coverage of $1,000,000 per occurrence and $1,000,000 aggregate to include the sidewalk cafe area if the sidewalk cafe is included in the licensed premises.

No license issued pursuant to this section shall be valid at any time the insurance required herein is not maintained and evidence of its continuance filed with the Permits and License Manager.

Subd. 4.	Suspension and Revocation.

A Any license authorized by this section may be revoked at any time by the City Council for violations of this section or the license terms. The license may also be suspended by the City Council for a period as the Council shall determine.

B. Upon conviction of the licensee, or the licensee's agent, or employee for the violation  of any City ordinance  or state law in connection with the
 
ownership, maintenance, or operation of a sidewalk cafe,  the  license shall automatically become suspended. The suspension shall continue until the Council acts to reinstate the license upon petition by the licensee.

Subd. 5.  Separability.  Every  prov1s1on  of  this  section  shall  be separable from every other provision, to the extent that if any provision shall be held invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, it shall not invalidate any other provision.

SECTION 6.17.	FOOD WAGONS.

Subd. 1. Purpose. The purpose of this section is  to  regulate  the operations of "Food Wagon" within the City.

Subd. 2.  Definition.   Food Wagon  shall  be  defined  as  any  vehicle, stand or device used for the purpose of selling food and/or drink ready to be consumed while parked on public property or right of way.

Subd. 3.  License Required.  It is unlawful for any person to operate a Food Wagon without a license from the City.   Operations meeting the definition of a Food Wagon and operating under a valid Food Wagon license do not need a solicitor's license under Section 6.22 of the City Code.

Subd. 4.  License  Issuance  Fee  and   Display.   Licenses,   including number and dates for which issued, shall be plainly visible on the outside of the Food Wagon. Licenses may be issued on an annual or per event basis. An application on the form prescribed by the City shall be completed by the applicant and shall be accompanied by a fee as established by ordinance.

Subd. 5.    Indemnification.    Before a Food Wagon  license is issued by the City, the licensee shall execute and deliver to the Permits and License Manager, on a form prescribed by the City, an Indemnification Agreement holding the City harmless for any personal injury or property damage resulting from operation of the Food Wagon.

Subd. 6.	Restrictions.

A Food Wagons shall be  allowed only at  approved  locations  within  the City, and shall not travel from point to point around the City, unless specifically authorized to do so by Council action.

B.	No Food Wagon shall be allowed to dispense food on public property when there is a permit issued for another food or similar wagon in association with an organized and permitted event, festival, celebration or tournament at the same location.  No Food Wagon shall be allowed to
 
dispense food at Colvill Park during the pool season unless it is part of an organized and permitted event, festival or celebration.

C.	A person operating a Food Wagon may apply for and receive an annual license for different sites in the City  at  various  times  throughout  the license period,  provided that  the  Food Wagon  is only operated  in one site at a time and provided that the operator notifies the Permits and License Manager of the location of the Food Wagon in advance of each specific time that food is sold from the wagon.

Subd. 7.	Food Wagon  Regulations.

A   No food shall be sold except directly from the Food Wagon.

B.	Radios and other audio devices shall be permitted only inside the Food Wagon.	No music or noise shall be permitted that is audible 30 feet from the Food Wagon. No amplification device shall be permitted on the exterior of any Food Wagon.

C.	Food Wagon sales shall be permitted only between the hours of sunrise and 10:30 p.m., unless  the City Council gives express permission to deviate from these hours.

D.	Food Wagon owners shall clean up around their Food Wagons at the end of each business day.

E. All Food Wagons shall be kept in good repair and order and shall have a neat appearance.

F.	There shall be no drainage of liquids allowed from the Food Wagon onto public property.

G.	In the event that a Food Wagon is not used to dispense food for a period of 21 consecutive days (excluding days when food dispensation is not allowed under Subdivision 6 of this Section) the permit may be forfeited.

H.	No license shall be issued to any food wagon until proof of any appropriate and necessary licensure by the State of Minnesota and/or Goodhue County is provided.

Subd. 8. Forfeiture and Revocation. A Food Wagon  license  may  be revoked or forfeited for violation of any of the provisions of this Section or any other violation of the  City Code or other applicable laws and regulations. Food Wagon licenses are not transferable.
 
SECTION 6.18.	LODGING TAX.

Subd. 1.  Definitions.  For  the  purpose  of  this  Section,  the  following terms, phrases and words, and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein.

1.	"Lodger" - the person obtaining lodging from an operator.

2.	"Lodging" - the furnishing of accommodation for a fee by a retreat center/vacation home, hotel, bed & breakfast, motel, or rooming house, except where the accommodation shall be for a continuous period of 30 days or more to the same lodger(s). The furnishing of rooms by religious, educational or non-profit organizations shall not constitute "lodging" for purposes of this Section.

3.	"Operator" - a person who provides lodging to others or any officer, agent or employee of such person.

4.	"Person" - any individual, corporation,  partnership,  association, estate,	receiver, trustee, executor, administrator,  assignee, syndicate, or any other combination of  individuals.  Whenever  the term "person" is used in any provision of this Section prescribing and imposing		a penalty, the terms as applied to a corporation, association or partnership,  shall mean two officers, or partners thereof as the case may be.

5.	"Rent" - the total fee charged for lodging whether paid in money or otherwise, not including any fees for services rendered in connection with furnishing lodging other than the room fee itself.

Subd. 2.  Imposition of Tax.  The City shall impose and collect a tax of three percent on the rent charged by an operator for providing lodging to any person . The tax shall be stated and charged separately and collected by the operator from the lodger.  The tax collected shall be a debt owed by the operator to the City and shall be extinguished only by payment to the City. In no case shall the tax imposed by this section upon an operator exceed the amount of tax which the operator is authorized and required by this Section to collect from a lodger.

Subd. 3.    Collections.    Each operator  shall collect the tax  imposed by this Section at the time the rent is paid. The tax collections shall be deemed to be held in trust by the operator for the City. The amount of tax shall be separately stated from the rent charged for the lodging and those persons paying the tax shall receive a receipt of payment from the operator.

Subd. 4.	Exceptions and Exemptions.
 
A Exceptions. No tax shall be imposed on rent for lodging paid by any officer or employee of a foreign government who  is exempt due to the express provisions of federal law or international treaty.

B. Exemptions. An exemption shall be granted to any person whose occupancy is beyond the power of the City to tax. No exemption shall be granted except upon a claim made at the time the rent is collected. The claim shall be made in writing and under penalty of perjury on forms provided by the City Finance Director. All exemption claims shall be forwarded to the Finance Director when the returns and collections are submitted as required by this Section.

Subd. 5. Advertising No Tax Prohibited. It shall  be unlawful for  any operator to advertise or hold out or state to the public or any customer, directly or indirectly, that the tax or  any part thereof will be assumed or absorbed by the operator, that it will not be added to the rent, or that, if added, it or any part thereof will be refunded. In computing the tax to be collected, amounts of tax less than one cent shall be rounded up to one additional cent.

Subd. 6.  Payment  and  Returns.    The  taxes  imposed  by this  Section shall be paid by the operator to the Finance Director monthly not less than 15 days after the end of the month in which the  taxes were collected. At the time of payment, the operator shall submit a return upon forms supplied by the Finance Director.  The return shall contain the following minimum information:

A The total amount of rent collected for lodging during the period covered by the return.

B.	The amount of tax required to be collected and due for the period.

C.	The signature of the person filing the return or that of the person's agent duly authorized in writing.

D.	The period covered by the return.
E.  The amount of uncollectible rental charges subject to the lodging tax. The operator may offset against the taxes payable from any reporting period, the
amount of taxes imposed by this Section previously paid as a result of any transaction the consideration for which became uncollectible  during the reporting period, but only in proportion to the portion of consideration which became uncollectible.

Subd. 7.    Examination of  Return, Adjustments,  Notices and Demands. The Finance Director shall, after the return is filed, review the return and make any investigation or examination of the records and accounts of the person making the
 
return as needed to determine its accuracy. The tax computed by the Finance Director on the basis of the examination shall be the tax due. If the tax due is found to be greater than the tax paid, the  excess shall be paid to the Finance Director on behalf of the City ten days after receipt of a notice given either personally to the operator or sent by registered mail to the address shown on the return. If the tax paid is greater than the tax due, the excess shall be refunded to the person who paid the tax ten days after determination of the refund.

Subd. 8. Refunds. Any person may apply to the Finance Director for a refund of taxes paid for a prescribed period in excess of the amount legally due for that period, provided that no application for refund shall be considered unless filed within one year after the tax was paid, or within one year from the filing  of the return, whichever period is longer. The Finance Director shall examine the claim and file written findings denying or allowing the claim in whole or in part, and shall mail a notice by registered mail to the address stated on the return. If the claim is allowed in whole or in part, the Finance Director shall credit the amount of the allowance against any  taxes due under this Section from the claimant and the balance of the allowance, if any, shall be paid to the claimant.

Subd. 9.	Failure to File a Return.

A If any operator required by this Section to file a return fails  to  do so within the time prescribed, or makes a willfully incorrect, false or fraudulent return, the operator shall, upon written notice and demand by the City, file the return or corrected return within five days of receipt of the notice and shall at the same time pay any tax due. If the operator fails to file a return or corrected return within five days, the Finance Director shall make a return or corrected return, for the operator from the information that the Finance Director can obtain, and shall assess a tax on that basis. This tax (less any payments previously  made  on account of the tax for the taxable period covered by the return) shall be paid within five days of the receipt of written notice and demand for payment. Any return or assessment made by the Finance Director shall be on its face correct and valid. The operator shall have the burden of establishing incorrectness or invalidity of the return or assessment.

B.	If any portion of a tax imposed by this Section, including penalties, is not paid within 30 days after it is due, the City may institute any legal action needed to recover the amount due plus  interest,  penalties,  and costs and disbursements of the action.

C.	Upon good cause shown, the Finance Director may grant an operator one 30 day extension of time within which to file a return and make payment of taxes due, provided that interest during the extension shall be added to the taxes due at the rate of 10 percent per year.
 
Subd. 10.	Penalties.

A If any tax imposed by this Section is not paid within the prescribed period for payment, or any extension approved by the Finance Director, a penalty equal to 10 percent of the amount remaining unpaid shall be added.

B.	In case of any failure to file a return within the time prescribed by this Section, unless it is shown that the failure is not due to willful neglect, there shall be added to the 10 percent specific penalty provided in Subparagraph A of this Subdivision, 10 percent if the failure is for  not more than 30 days with an additional five percent for each additional 30 days or fraction thereof during which such failure continues, not exceeding 25 percent in the aggregate. If the penalty as computed does not exceed $10, a minimum penalty of $10 shall be assessed.  The penalty added to any tax shall be collected at the same time and in the same manner and as a part of the tax unless the tax has been paid before the discovery of the negligence, in which case the amount added shall be collected in the same manner as the tax.

C.	If any person willfully fails to file any return or make any payment required by this Section, willfully files a false or fraudulent return, or willfully attempts in any manner to evade or defeat payment of the tax due, there shall also be imposed as a penalty an amount equal to 50 percent of any tax (less any amounts paid on the basis of the false or fraudulent return) found due for the period to which the return related. The penalty imposed by this Subdivision shall be collected as part of the tax, and shall be in addition to any other penalties provided by this Section.

D.	All payments received shall be credited first to penalties, next to interest, and then to tax due.

E.	The amount of tax not timely paid, together with any penalty provided by this section, shall bear interest at the maximum rate per year as prescribed by Minnesota Statutes, Section 270.75, as it  may  be amended from time to time, from the time the tax should have been paid until it is paid.

Any interest and penalty shall be added to the tax and be collected as a part thereof.

Subd. 11.  Administration  of Tax.  The Finance Director shall administer and enforce the assessment and collection of taxes imposed by this Section. The Finance Director shall furnish blank forms for the returns and other documents required by this Section and distribute them throughout the City and provide them
 
on request. Failure to receive or secure the forms,  however, shall not relieve any person from any obligation required under this Section.

Subd. 12. Examine Records.  The  Finance  Director  and  persons authorized in writing to act on behalf of the Finance Director may examine the books, papers and records of any operator in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return was made, to ascertain the tax as provided in this Section. Every operator is directed and required to give the person authorized to examine the books, papers and records, the means, facilities and opportunity for these examinations and investigations.

Subd. 13. Violations. It is a violation of this Chapter for any person to willfully fail to file a return required by this Section, fail to pay the tax due after written demand for payment, fail to remit the taxes collected or any penalty or interest imposed by this Section after written demand for payment, refuse to permit the Finance Director or any duly authorized agents or employees of the City to examine the books, records and papers pertaining to the tax due, or willfully file an incomplete, false or fraudulent return.

Subd. 14.  Use  of  Proceeds.  Ninety-five  percent  of  the  proceeds obtained from the collection of taxes pursuant to this Section shall be used by the City to fund a local tourism or convention bureau for marketing the City as a tourist destination or convention center. The remaining five percent  shall  be  used to defray the City's costs in administering this tax.

Subd. 15.	The tourism or convention bureau which is selected to receive the proceeds referenced in Subdivision 14 of this Section shall provide the City with an audited financial statement of its operations once every three years.  The year selected for audit will be determined by the auditor by means of a random sample, or as otherwise determined in the auditor's work plan.  Additionally, the tourism or convention bureau shall provide the City with an annual fiscal report.

SECTION 6.19.	FARMERS MARKET.

Subd. 1.      Purpose.  The purpose of this section is to set forth the policy of the City with regard to vendors operating at the Red Wing Farmers Market (hereinafter "vendors").

Subd. 2.	Definitions.  "Market Goods" shall include:

1.	"Vendor" - a person or agent who sells market goods to the public.

2.	"Market Goods" - vendor-grown fresh fruits and vegetables;

(a)	Vendor-grown herbs and spices;
 
(b)	Vendor-produced farmstead products such as cheese,  meats, fish,	poultry, eggs, baked goods, honey, maple syrup and preserves, if prepared and labeled in accordance with rules established by the Minnesota Department of Agriculture;

(c)	Vendor-grown bedding plants, hanging and potted plants, and cut flowers;

(d)	Vendor-grown dried flowers and plants; and

(e)	Arts, crafts, and other locally produced hand-made products.

3.	"Market Food Wagons" - any vehicle, stand, or device used for the purpose of selling food and/or drink ready to be consumed while parked at the Saturday Market. Market Food Wagons are only allowed	at the Saturday Farmers Market and are considered "vendors" as defined in this subdivision.

4.	"Satellite Market" - a farmers' market that is not located in front of City Hall and instead is located at a  different  private  or  public location.

Subd. 3. Permit Required. It is unlawful for any person to operate as a vendor without obtaining a permit for the Farmers Market. Permits may be issued by the Farmers' Market Association Manager or at City offices upon application by vendors on forms furnished by the City or the Association on a first-come, first­ served, basis. Daily permits (with the exception of Saturday permits) shall be purchased at City offices between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:30 p.m. each weekday. Daily permits may be issued for any number or configuration of days, excluding Saturdays. Permits needed for Sunday shall be purchased by Friday of that week. Seasonal and Saturday permits shall be purchased through  the Farmer's Market Association. Seasonal permits shall also be available  for purchase with a limit of seven permits being issued per season.

The City Council, at its discretion, may enter into a Management Agreement with any Farmers Market Association to manage the Farmers Market, (including satellite markets) collect fees, and ensure compliance with the City Code requirements.

Subd. 4. Indemnification. Before receiving a permit, the vendor shall execute and deliver to the Permits and License Manager an Indemnification Agreement upon a form to be furnished by the City, holding the City harmless for any personal injury or property damage resulting from the vendor's activities.

Subd. 5. Fee. All permit applications  shall  be  accompanied  by  a payment of a fee to be established by ordinance
 

Subd. 6.   On  Sunday  through  Friday,  permits  shall  allow  Vendors  to park only on the south side of Fourth Street, between Bush Street and Plum Street (except for satellite markets as described  below).  On Saturdays,  permits shall also allow Vendors to park in the west City Hall parking lot fronting Bush Street and to use the front lawn of City Hall facing Bush Street. A valid permit under this section exempts the Vendor from the two-hour parking limit generally enforced on this block. Each Vendor is entitled to only one permit per day and each permit is good for only one vehicle and one stall. A maximum limit of ten permits per day will be issued for each day of the week except Saturday for Fourth Street. This limitation of ten permits for each day except Saturday does not apply to satellite markets. For the Saturday Farmers Market, a maximum limit of fourteen permits shall be issued for Fourth Street and an additional six permits may be issued specifically for the west City Hall parking lot. A permit shall be nontransferable between Vendors and shall be nonrefundable. If  there  is  an  approved Management Agreement with a Farmers Market Association, the Farmers Market Association shall have the option of conducting the Saturday market  on Fourth Street, between Bush Street and Plum Street and use the west City Hall Parking lot fronting Bush Street and the front lawn of City Hall facing Bush Street (a maximum of 20 vendor stalls); or the Saturday market may be conducted on the north side of Levee Street, from Broad Street (east of the first seven parking stalls) to Bush Street, and the west side of Bush Street north of Levee Street, and the east side of Bush Street north of Levee Street (a maximum of 30 vendor stalls). In addition, if  approved by the Permits and License Manager, a Farmers Market Association may manage satellite farmers markets at other privately and publicly owned locations.

Subd. 7.	Vendor Regulations.

A Tables shall be allowed on the sidewalk adjacent to the motor vehicle from which the market goods are being sold, but shall not exceed the width of the parking stall space and must maintain a minimum of  40 inches clearance from all obstacles for pedestrians. No tables shall be allowed in the street. Food items must be kept at least six inches above the ground.

B.	No music or noise shall be permitted that is audible within 30 feet of the vendor's vehicle.

C.	No sales shall be permitted before sunrise or after sunset.

D.	No pets or other live animals shall be allowed in the vendor area.

E. All vendors shall clean up around their vehicles when they have completed their sales for each day.
 
F. All vendors agree to abide by the Operational Guidelines of the Farmers Market Association. Said Operational Guidelines  shall  require  review and approval by the Permits and License Manager.

Subd. 8.	Market Food Wagon Regulations.

A No food shall be sold except directly from the Market Food Wagon or Market Food Wagon setup.

B.	All Market Food Wagons and Market Food Wagon setups shall be kept in good repair and order and shall have a neat appearance.

C.	There shall be no drainage of liquids allowed from the Market  Food Wagon or Market Food Wagon setup onto public property.

D.	No permit shall be issued on any Market Food Wagon until proof of appropriate	and necessary licensure by the State of Minnesota (Department of Health or Department of Agriculture) is provided.

E. All Vendor regulations listed in Subd. 7 also apply to Market Food Wagons.

Subd. 9.    Signage.    The  Association  shall  be  allowed  to  place  A- frame style, Swinger Signs or Sandwich Signs on City right-of-way for the purpose of directing visitors to the Saturday Farmers Market  location.  This  is a  device which is ordinarily in the shape of an "A" or some variation thereof, located on the ground, easily moveable, not permanently attached thereto  and which  is usually two sided.  A-Frame/Swinger/Sandwich  Signs must meet the following regulations:

A   Such signs shall be no larger than 10 square feet in sign area per side.

B.	Such signs shall not be taller than 4 feet or wider than 2-1/2 feet.

C.	Such signs shall only be displayed during Saturday Farmers Market hours.

D.	Such signs may be placed on private property (with permission) or on the public sidewalk near the Saturday Farmers Market but must provide at	least 60 inches of clearance on the sidewalk for  pedestrian movement.

E. Such signs shall be placed no closer than 48 inches from the face of the public street curb.

F.  Only one such sign shall be allowed per Zoned Lot.
 
Subd. 10. Revocation. The Permits  and  License  Manager  may,  in writing, revoke any permit issued under this section, or refuse to grant or renew the permit of any vendor in violation of this section, of any other City Code provision, or of any regulations adopted by the City.

SECTION 6.20.	TATTOOING AND BODY PIERCING.

Subd. 1.	Purpose and Applicability.   Due to the inherent risk to the health and safety of persons associated with tattooing, body piercing, and other body art procedures, the purpose and intent of this Section is to establish rules, regulations, and standards for tattooing, body piercing, and other body art procedures performed within the City of Red Wing.  This Section shall apply to all body art establishments,  including tattoo parlors and establishments at which body piercing is performed, body art technicians, and operators of body art establishments,  including tattoo parlors and establishments at which body piercing is performed.

Subd. 2.	Definitions.

A   For the purpose of this Section, the following words and phrases have the meanings given to them in Minnesota Statutes, Section 146B.01, as amended:

1.	"Body art" or "body art procedure;"

2.	"Body art establishment;"

3.	"Body piercing;"

4.	"Department"

5.	"Guest artist;"

6.	"Operator;"

7.	"Tattooing;"

8.	"Technician" or "body art technician;" and

9.	"Temporary body art establishment."

B.  For the purpose of this Section, the term "License" means a license issued by the Minnesota Department of Health in accordance with the procedures and standards identified in Minnesota Statutes, Chapter 146B, as amended.
 
Subd. 3.	Body Art Procedures.

A No tattooing, body piercing, or other body art procedure shall be performed	within the City of Red Wing except at a body art establishment or temporary body art establishment that is the subject of a valid establishment license, or at a temporary  event  in accordance with a temporary event permit issued by the Department of Health pursuant to Minnesota Statutes, Chapter 1468.

B.	No tattooing shall be performed within the City of Red Wing, except by a technician or guest artist holding a valid tattoo technician license.

C.	No body piercing, or other body art procedure, other than tattooing, shall be performed within the City of Red Wing, except by a technician or guest artist holding a valid body piercing technician license.

D.	No tattooing, body piercing, or other body art procedure shall be performed in the City of Red Wing in any manner which deviates from Minnesota Statutes, Chapter 1468, as amended.

Subd. 4.     Unlawful Conduct.  Any person who violates this Section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, which shall be punishable by the payment of a fine, not to exceed $1,000, and/or imprisonment for a period not to exceed 90 days.

Subd. 5. Professional Standards. All technicians shall comply with the provisions of Minnesota Statutes, Section 1468.07, as amended.

Subd. 6. Reporting. The City of Red Wing  shall  report  all  known violations of any health, safety,  professional standards,  and/or other requirement of Minnesota Statutes, Chapter 1468, as amended, to the Minnesota Department of Health, and may request that the Department take appropriate remedial action, including, but not limited to, the revocation of any license or permit issued pursuant to Minnesota Statutes, Chapter 1468, as amended.

Subd. 7. Proof of Licensure. All  technician,  guest  artist,  and establishment licenses, as well as all temporary event permits issued by the Department of Health pursuant to Minnesota Statutes, Chapter 1468, must be prominently displayed and available for inspection at all times while any tattooing, body piercing, or other body art procedure is being conducted.

SECTION 6.21.	JUNK DEALERS.

Subd. 1. Definition. The term "junk" as used in this section means and includes, but is not limited to, scrap of all kinds such as metal, paper, rags and wood.
 
Subd. 2. License Required. It is unlawful for any person to deal in junk without having a license from the City.

Subd. 3.     Bond Requirement.   Before receiving a junk  dealer's license, the applicant shall execute and deliver to the  Permits  and  License  Manager  a bond in the penal sum of $10,000 with sufficient sureties approved by the Council and conditioned that the applicant will in every particular conform with the requirements of any law relating to junk dealers.

Subd. 4. Restriction. No license shall be granted to  any  person for operation upon premises contrary to any zoning provision of the City Code or other law.

 
SECTION 6.22. MERCHANTS.
 
PEDDLERS,	SOLICITORS	AND	TRANSIENT
 

Subd. 1. Definitions. Except as may otherwise be provided or clearly implied by context, all terms shall be given their commonly accepted definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply.

1.	"Door-To-Door Advocacy" - includes door-to-door canvassing and pamphleteering as a method for the  dissemination  of  religious, political and other ideas.

2.	"Peddler" - a person who goes from house-to-house, door-to-door, business-to-business, street-to-street, or any other type of place-to­ place, for the purpose of offering for sale, displaying or exposing for sale, selling or attempting to sell, and delivering immediately upon sale, the goods, wares, products, merchandise or other personal property that the person is carrying or otherwise transporting. The term peddler shall have the same meaning as the term hawker.

3.	"Person" - any natural individual, group, organization, corporation, partnership or association. As applied to groups, organizations, corporations, partnerships and associations, the term shall include each member, officer, partner, associate, agent or employee.

4.	"Regular Business Day" - any day during which  the  City  Hall  is normally  open  for  the  purpose   of  conducting  public  business. Holidays defined by state law shall not be  counted  as  regular business days.

5.	"Solicitor" - a person who goes from house-to-house, door-to-door, business-to-business, street-to-street, or any other type of place-to­ place, for the purpose of obtaining or attempting to obtain orders for goods,  wares,  products,  merchandise,  other  personal  property  or
 
services of which the person may be carrying or  transporting samples, or that may be described in a catalog or by other means, and for which delivery or performance shall  occur  at a  later time. The absence of samples or catalogs shall not remove a person from the scope of this section if the actual purpose of the person's activity is to obtain or attempt to obtain orders as discussed above.  The term shall have the same meaning as the term "canvasser."

6.	"Transient Merchant" - a person who temporarily sets up business to sell or purchase out of a vehicle, trailer, boxcar, tent, hotel/motel, other portable shelter, or empty storefront for the  purpose   of exposing or displaying for sale, selling or attempting to sell, and delivering, goods, wares, products, merchandise or other personal property, and who does not remain or intend to remain in any one location for more than 14 consecutive days.

Subd. 2.	Exceptions to Definitions.

A For the purpose of the requirements  of  this  Section,  the  terms PEDDLER, SOLICITOR,  and TRANSIENT  MERCHANT shall not apply to any person selling or attempting to sell at wholesale  any  goods, wares, products, merchandise or other personal property to a retailer of the items being sold by the wholesale. The terms also shall not apply to any person who is personally known by the person being solicited  or who is first contacted by the person being solicited.

B.	Persons conducting the type of sales commonly known as garage sales, rummage sales, or estate sales, as well as those persons participating in an organized multi-person bazaar, flea market, or festival, shall be exempt	from the definitions of PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, and TRANSIENT MERCHANTS, as shall any person conducting an auction as a properly licensed auctioneer,  or any officer of the court conducting a court-ordered sale. Exemption from the definitions for the scope of this Section shall not excuse any person from complying with any other applicable statutory provision or local ordinance.

C.	Nothing  in  this  section  prohibits  or  restricts  door-to-door   advocacy.
Persons engaging in door-to-door  advocacy are not required to register as solicitors under Subdivision 6 of this Section.

Subd. 3.	Licensing; Exemptions.

A County License Required. No person shall conduct business  as  a peddler, solicitor or transient  merchant within the city limits without first obtaining  the  appropriate   license  from  the   County  as  required  by
 
Minnesota  Statutes,  Chapter  329 as  it may be amended from time to time, if the County issues a license for the activity.

B.	City License Required. Except as otherwise provided for by this section, no person shall conduct business as either a peddler or a transient merchant without first obtaining a license from the City. This license is nontransferable.	Solicitors need not be licensed, but are required to register under Subdivision 6 of this Section.

C.	Application. Application for a city license to conduct business as  a peddler or transient merchant shall be made at least 14 regular business days	before the applicant wishes to begin conducting business. Application for a license shall be made on a form approved by the City Council and available from the office of the Permits and License Manager.	All applications shall be signed by the applicant and shall include the following information:

1.	Applicant's full legal name and date of birth;

2.	All other names under which the applicant conducts business or to which the applicant officially answers;

3.	A physical description of the applicant (hair color, eye color, height, weight, and distinguishing marks and features);

4.	Full address and telephone number of applicant's permanent residence;

5.	Full legal name of any and all business operations owned, managed or operated by applicant, or for which the applicant is an employee or agent;

6.	Full address and telephone number of applicant's regular place of business (if any);

7.	The type of business for which the applicant is applying for a license and a general description of the items to be sold or services to be provided;

8.	Whether the applicant is applying for an annual or daily license;

9.	The dates during which the applicant intends to conduct business, and if the applicant is applying for a daily license, the number of days the applicant will be conducting business in the City (maximum 14 consecutive days);
 
10.	Any and all addresses and telephone  numbers where the applicant can be reached while conducting business within the City, including the location where a transient merchant intends to set up business;

11.	Written  permission  of  the  property  owner  or  the  property  owner's agent for any property to be used by a transient merchant;

12.	A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted within the last five years of any felony, gross misdemeanor, or misdemeanor for violation of any state or federal statute or any local ordinance, other than traffic offenses;

13.	A list of the three most recent locations where the applicant has conducted business as a peddler or transient merchant;

14.	Proof of any required county license;

15.	A general description of the items  to  be  sold  or  services  to  be provided;

16.	The applicant's driver's license number or other acceptable form of identification;

17.	The license plate number, registration information and vehicle identification number for any vehicle  to be used in conjunction with the licensed business and a description of the vehicle;

18.	All additional information deemed necessary by the City Council.

D.	Fee. All applications for a license under this Section  shall  be accompanied by the fee established by ordinance.

E. Procedure. Upon receipt of the completed application and payment of the license fee, the Permits and License Manager, within two regular business days, shall determine if the application is complete. An application is determined to be complete only if all required information is provided. If the Permits and License Manager determines that the application is incomplete, the Permits and License Manager shall inform the applicant what  required information is missing. If the application is complete,	the Permits and License Manager shall order any investigation, including background checks, necessary to verify the information provided with the application. Within  10 regular  business days of receiving a complete application, the Permits and License Manager shall issue the license unless there are grounds  for  denying the license under Subdivision 4 of this Section, in which case the Permits and License Manager must deny the license.   If the Permits and
 
License Manager denies the license, the applicant must  be notified in writing of the decision, the reason for denial, and of the applicant's right to appeal the denial by requesting, within 20 days of receiving notice of rejection, a public hearing before the City  Council.  The  City  Council shall hear the appeal within 20 days of the date of the request. The decision of the City Council following the public hearing can be appealed by petitioning the Minnesota Court of Appeals for a Writ of Certiorari.

F.	Duration. An annual license granted under this Section shall be valid for one calendar year from the date  of issue. All other licenses granted under this Section shall be valid only during the time period indicated on the license.

G.	License Exemptions.

1.	No license shall be required of any person going from house-to­ house, door-to-door, business-to-business, street-to-street, or other type of place-to-place when the activity is for the purpose of exercising that person's State or  Federal  Constitutional  rights such as the freedom of speech, press, and religion, except that this exemption may be lost if the person's exercise  of  Constitutional rights is merely incidental to a commercial activity.

2.	Professional fundraisers working on behalf of an otherwise exempt person or group shall not be exempt from the licensing requirements of this Section.

3.	No license shall be required of any person or group that is a tax exempt, transient merchant when it operates in an area of the City zoned as Central Business District (B-3) for one period, up to three days in length, per calendar year. Registration is still required pursuant to Subdivision 6 of this Section.

4.	Any person claiming to be exempt from the licensing or registration requirements of this section shall, when requested, present to the Permits and License Manager  proof  of  qualification  for  such exemption.

Subd. 4.	License   Ineligibility.	The  following   shall   be  grounds   for denying a license under this Section:

A The failure of the applicant to obtain and show proof of having obtained any required county license.

B.	The failure of the applicant to truthfully provide any of the information requested by the City as a part of the application, or the failure to sign
 
the  application,  or  the  failure  to  pay  the  required  fee  at  the  time  of application.

C.	The conviction of the applicant within the past five years from the date of application for any violation of any federal or state statute or regulation, or of any local ordinance, which adversely reflects on the person's ability to conduct the business for which the license is being sought  in an honest and legal manner. Those violations shall include  but  not  be limited to burglary, theft, larceny, swindling, fraud, unlawful business practices, and any form of actual  or threatened physical harm against another person.

D.	The revocation within  the past five years of any license issued to the applicant for the purpose of conducting business as a peddler, solicitor or transient merchant.

Subd. 5.	Suspension and Revocation.

A Generally. Any license or Certificate of Registration issued under this section may be suspended or revoked at the discretion of the City Council for violation of any of the following:

1.	Fraud, misrepresentation  or incorrect statements  on the application form.

2.	Fraud,   misrepresentation	or  false   statements	made   during   the course of the licensed activity.

3.	Failure  to  exhibit  the  license  or  Certificate  of  Registration  when requested to do so by any prospective customer or city employee.

4.	Conviction of any offense for which granting of a license could have been denied under Subdivision 4 of this Section.

5.	Violation of any provision of this section.

B.	Multiple Persons Under One License. The suspension or revocation of any license issued for the purpose of authorizing multiple persons  to conduct business as peddlers or transient merchants on behalf of the licensee shall serve as a suspension or revocation of each authorized person's authority to conduct business as a peddler  or  transient merchant on behalf of the licensee whose license is suspended or revoked.

C.	Notice. Prior to revoking or suspending any license issued under this Section, the City shall provide the  license holder with written  notice of
 
the alleged violations and inform the licensee of the right to a hearing on the alleged violation. Notice shall be delivered in person or by mail to the permanent residential address listed on the license application, or if no residential address is listed, to the business address provided on the license application.

D.	Public Hearing. Upon receiving the notice provided in section (C) of this Subdivision, the licensee shall have the right to request a public hearing. If no request for a hearing is received by the Permits and License Manager within 10 regular business days following the service of  the notice, the City may proceed with the suspension or revocation. For the purpose of mailed notices,  service shall  be considered complete as of the date the notice is placed in the mail.  If a public hearing is requested within the stated timeframe, a hearing shall be scheduled within 20 days from the date of the request. Within three regular business days of the hearing, the City Council shall notify the licensee of its decision.

E. Emergency. If, in the discretion of the City Council, imminent harm to the health or safety of the public may occur because of the actions of a peddler or transient merchant licensed under this Section, the City Council may immediately suspend the person's license and provide notice of the right to hold a subsequent public hearing as prescribed in Subparagraph D. of this Subdivision.

F. Appeals. Any person whose license is suspended or revoked under this section shall have the right to appeal that decision in court.

Subd. 6. Registration. All solicitors, and any person exempt from the licensing requirements under Subdivision 3 of this Section, shall be required to register with the City. Persons engaging in DOOR-TO-DOOR ADVOCACY shall not be required to register. Registration shall be made on the same form required for a license application, but no fee shall be required. Immediately upon completion of the registration form, the Permits and License Manager shall issue to the registrant a Certificate of Registration as  proof  of  the  registration. Certificates of Registration are nontransferable.

Subd. 7.  Prohibited  Activities.  No  peddler,  solicitor   or   transient merchant shall conduct business or otherwise behave in any of the following manners:

A Calling attention to the business or items to be sold by means of blowing any horn or whistle, ringing any bell, crying out, or by any other noise, so as to be unreasonably audible within an enclosed structure.

B.	Obstructing the free flow of either vehicular or pedestrian traffic on any street, alley, sidewalk or other public right-of-way.
 

C.	Conducting business in a way as to create a threat to the health, safety and welfare of any individual or the general public.

D.	Conducting business before 8:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m.

E. Failing to provide proof of identification and license or Certificate of Registration, when requested; or using the license or Certificate of Registration of another person.

F.	Making any false or misleading statements about the product or service being sold, including untrue statements of endorsement. No peddler or transient merchant shall claim to have the endorsement of  the  City solely based on the City having issued a license to that person.

G.	Remaining on the property of another when requested to leave, or to otherwise conduct business in a manner a reasonable person would find obscene, threatening, intimidating or abusive.

Subd. 8. Exclusion by Placard. No  peddler,  solicitor  or  transient merchant, unless invited to do so by the property owner or tenant, shall enter the property of another for the purpose of conducting business as a peddler, solicitor or transient merchant when the property is marked with a sign or placard with print of at least 48 point in size stating "No Peddlers," "No Solicitors," "No Transient Merchants," "Peddlers and Solicitors Prohibited,"  or other comparable statement. No person other than the property owner or tenant shall remove, deface or otherwise tamper with any sign or placard under this section.

Subd. 9.	Penalties.

A A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during which a violation occurs or continues.

SECTION 6.23.	CHARITABLE GAMBLING.

Subd. 1. Purpose.  The  purpose  of  this  section  is  to  regulate  and control the conduct of lawful gambling (gambling) and to ensure that profits derived therefrom in the City of Red Wing provide direct benefits to the City's citizens.

Subd. 2. Statutes Incorporated. The provisions of Minnesota Statutes relating to gambling and providing penalties for violations thereof are hereby adopted and made a part of this section. The provisions of this Code  are additional restrictions placed on gambling by the City.
 
Subd. 3.    Definitions.  The terms defined in Minnesota Statutes, Chapter 349 have the meanings assigned therein unless the text of this section expressly provides otherwise. In addition the following terms shall have the following meanings:

1.	"Resident Manager or Agent" - at the time of application to the City, the applicant shall appoint in writing a natural person as its gambling manager or agent. The manager or agent shall consent in writing to:
(1)	take full responsibility for the conduct of the  licensed premises; and (2) serve as agent for service of notices and other  process relating to the permit or license. The manager or agent must be a person who, by reason of age, character, reputation, and other attributes, could qualify as a gambling manager. The manager or agent, however, need not be or trained to be the organization's gambling manager as that term is defined in state statute. If the manager or agent ceases to act in that capacity for the licensee without appointment of a successor, the permit or license issued pursuant to the appointment shall be subject to revocation or suspension.

2.	"Trade Area" - the City's trade area includes all of Goodhue County in Minnesota and Trenton and Isabelle Townships of Pierce County, Wisconsin.

Subd. 4.	Gambling Prohibited; Exemption.

A No person, except an organization which is licensed by or has a valid exemption permit from the State or has a permit from the City, shall conduct lawful gambling within the City. A City permit shall be obtained each time an exemption permit is sought from the Gambling Control Board	(Board). All permits required by this section or State  Statutes shall be prominently displayed during the permit  year at the premises licensed to conduct gambling.

B. All gambling activities exempt from licensure by statute shall require a City permit for the conduct of exempt gambling.

 
Subd. 5.
Inspections.
 
Filing  of   Records   and   Reports;  Access   to   Records  and
 

A Every organization permitted to conduct lawful gambling in the City shall file with the Permits and License Manager copies of all records  and reports required to be filed with the Board. The  records  and  reports shall be due to the City at the same time they are due to the Board.
 
B. Every organization shall file an additional report with  the City proving compliance with the Trade Area spending restrictions imposed by this section.	The report shall be on a form prescribed by the Permits and License Manager and shall be submitted annually and in advance of application for renewal.

C. All licensed or permitted gambling operations are deemed to have consented to inspection of the licensed or permitted premises  by the City.

D. Authorized employees or agents of the City may inspect, at any reasonable time without notice or search warrant, all records, including gambling accounts and other bank records required by the Board to be maintained and preserved.

Subd. 6.	Application.

A An organization shall make application for a premises permit on a form prescribed by the Board. The applicant shall provide a complete copy of the State application to the City.

B. An organization holding a premises permit must notify the Permits and License Manager in writing within ten days of any material change in the information contained in the application.

C.  The Council shall act on the application within 60 days from the date complete materials are submitted,  but shall not approve  an application to the Board for a new premises permit until at least 30 days after the date of the application.

Subd. 7.	General Conditions.

A The City Council may require a copy of the financial audit or financial review required by the State of any organization that conducts lawful gambling in the City at the organization's expense. The audit  shall include information on all gross receipts, profits, and expenses incurred by the organization in the conduct of gambling as well as information on uses of profits and  trade area limitations. The audit report shall be submitted to the City Council upon timely completion, or at  the application for  renewal but no later than 180 days after the end of the gambling license year.

B. Gambling Manager Required. Each  licensed  organization  must designate a gambling manager. The gambling manager designated by an organization shall be responsible for the lawful conduct  of  all gambling	in compliance with all laws and state rules.  An organization
 
may not conduct gambling without a gambling manager.  Any organization changing gambling managers, or adding or removing gambling managers, must notify the City in writing within ten days of the change.

C. Hours of Operation.  Unless specifically  permitted by the City Council, no gambling shall be conducted between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. Monday, 1:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. daily Tuesday through Saturday and 1:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. Sunday.

Subd. 8.	Conditions for Allowing Premises to Be Used for Gambling.

A No organization or person shall, directly or indirectly, conduct, allow or permit gambling without a license issued by the Board, or an exemption from the Board and license from the City.

B. No person, organization or business entity shall suffer or permit  any gaming table or gambling equipment to be used for the purpose of gambling in any house, lot, yard, or garden owned, occupied  or controlled by that person, organization or business entity,  except  for those organizations licensed by the Board and issued permits pursuant to this  Section, unless the person, organization or business entity is a lessor of premises leased to an organization issued the license or permit for gambling.

Subd. 9.	Leased Premises; General Restrictions on Use.

A Lease/Ownership Required. An organization may conduct licensed gambling only on premises it owns or leases. Leases must be for  a period of at  least one year and must be on a form prescribed by the Board. Copies of all leases must accompany an application to the City. A lease may be a conditional lease based on granting of the permit. No lease agreement payments may exceed limitations established by the Board as set forth in Minnesota Statutes, Section 349.18, Subd. 1, as it may be amended from time to time.

No person, distributor, manufacturer, lessor, or organization other than the licensed organization leasing or owning the space may conduct any gambling activity on the leased/owned premises while gambling is being conducted on the premises.

B.	No lessor shall permit more than one organization to conduct gambling at the leased premises at the same time.

C.	No person, organization or business licensed to conduct gambling at a leased location shall sell or solicit beyond the limits of leased space as
 
indicated on  the lease agreement.

Subd. 10. Establishments Applying for or Holding Liquor Licenses. No licensed liquor establishment shall keep, possess, operate or permit the keeping, possession or operation of any video games of chance, or gambling device including slot machines, roulette wheels, punch Boards and  pinball  machines which return coins or slugs, chips or tokens of any kind which are redeemable for merchandise, cash or other item of value on the licensed premises. In addition no dice or playing card gambling is allowed in any licensed establishment.

Only gambling licensed by the Board and conducted pursuant to state statute and this Section is permitted on licensed establishments. Personal gambling  for nominal consideration is allowed in a licensed establishment  when  allowed  by state statute.

Subd. 11.	Investigations; Permit Fees and Local Contributions.

A All organizations exempt from state licensing requirements, which are applying for a permit to conduct gambling in the City, shall pay a permit fee to the City established by ordinance.

B.	Any  organization  applying  for  or  renewing  a premises  permit  or  bingo hall license must pay an investigation fee at the time of application established by ordinance.
C.	All permit applications must be referred to the Police Department and to other departments as necessary for verification and investigation of the facts set forth in the application. The investigation shall include, but not be limited to, a criminal history background check. A written report of the findings, along with a recommendation of the Police Department regarding the license application, shall be forwarded to the Council with the application.

D.	Designated Trade Area. Any organization licensed to conduct gambling within the City shall expend at least 50 percent of its expenditures on lawful purposes conducted or located within the Trade Area. A licensed organization may request relief from this  provision.  The  City  Council may in its sole discretion grant such relief when the circumstances warrant.

Subd. 12.	Granting of Premises Permits and Bingo Hall Licenses.

A The City may deny an application to the Board for a premises permit or bingo hall license if:

1.	The  liquor  licensee,   owner,   or  manager  of  the  site  has  been convicted of a violation of any gambling or liquor license laws;
 

2.	The   City's   investigation   indicates   that   the   organization   or gambling  manager failed to comply with the terms  or conditions  of any other license or indicates a history of noncompliance with state or local law regulating the conduct of gambling;

3.	Noncompliance with any applicable zoning, building, fire and health codes of the City or other regulations in this section; or

4.	Noncompliance with requirements of this section or other stated factors including, but not limited to, the health, safety and welfare of the City.

B.	An application made to the Board for a premises permit or bingo hall license to conduct lawful gambling in the City may be  denied  by resolution of the City Council if notification of such resolution is made to the  Board within 60 days of the receipt of the complete application by the Permits and License Manager.

Subd. 13. Violations. Violations of this Section may result in penalties imposed by Section 6.26 or civil sanctions imposed by the City Council.

SECTION 6.24.	PAWNBROKERS.
