ARTICLE IV - REGULATIONS APPLYING TO ALL DISTRICTS DIVISION 70:  NONCONFORMING USES AND STRUCTURES
70-0 I 0 Applicability and Intent.  Any use ofland or structures, or any lot or structure which
existed at the effective date of adoption or amendment of this Chapter which would not be permitted or permissible by the provisions of this Chapter as adopted or amended, shall be deemed non-conforming. It is the intent of this Chapter to permit such nonconformities to continue, subject to certain restrictions.  Private or public property which was conforming at the effective date of adoption or amendment of this Chapter which is subdivided as part of a public taking for a project benefitting the public good or welfare and which results in a lot or structure that would not normally be dimensionally permitted or permissible by the provisions of this Chapter as adopted or amended, shall be deemed conforming.

70-20	Nonconforming Uses of Land (Or Land With Accessory Structures Only).  Where, at the effective date of adoption or amendment of this Chapter, a use ofland exists which would not be permitted or permissible in the district in which it is located, or where such use involves an accessory structure or structures, such use may be continued subject to the following restrictions:

A)	Such use shall not be enlarged, increased, nor extended to occupy a greater area of the lot than was occupied at the effective date of adoption or amendment of this Chapter.

B)	Such use shall not be moved in whole or part to any other portion of the lot other than the portion occupied by such use at the effective date of adoption or amendment of this Chapter.

C)	When such use is discontinued for a period of more than one year for any reason whatsoever, or when such use is replaced by a permitted or permissible use, a nonconforming use shall not thereafter be resumed. For the purposes of this section, a use shall be considered replaced by a permitted or permissible use when an existing nonconforming use has been terminated and the permissible use has commenced and continued for a period of one month or more.

D)	No additional structure in connection with such use shall be erected.


70-30	Nonconforming Uses of Structures.  Where, at the effective date of adoption or amendment of this Chapter, the use of a principal structure(s) exists which would not be permitted or permissible in the district in which it is located, such use may be continued subject to the following restrictions:

A)	No existing structure devoted to a use not permitted or permissible shall be enlarged, extended, constructed, reconstructed, moved, or structurally altered except in
 
changing the use of the structure to a use permitted or permissible in the district in which it is located.

B)	Any nonconforming use may be extended throughout any parts of a building which were manifestly arranged or designed for such use at the effective date of adoption or amendment of this Chapter. Any nonconforming use, which occupied a portion of a building not originally designed or intended for such use, shall not be extended to any other part of the building. No nonconforming use shall be extended to occupy any land outside the building, nor any other building not used for such nonconforming
use.

C)	There may be a change in tenancy, ownership, or management of a nonconforming
use provided there is no change in the nature or character of such nonconforming use.


D)	When such use of a structure is discontinued for a period of more than 12 consecutive months for any reason whatsoever, or when such use is replaced by a permitted or permissible use, a nonconforming use shall not thereafter be resumed.

E)	If a structure occupied by a nonconforming use is removed or destroyed or damaged to an extent of more than 50 percent of its estimated market value, as indicated in the records of the county assessor at the time of damage, the nonconforming use shall not be resumed, except as described in Section 70-050 below.

70-40	Preservation of Nonconforming Uses.  Except as hereinafter provided in this Section, the lawful use of land or the lawful use of a building or structure existing on the effective date of this Chapter or on the effective date of any amendment thereto may be continued although such use does not conform to the provisions of this Chapter; provided,  however:

A)	Any future use of such land, building, or structure shall conform to the provisions of this Chapter.

B)	Any such use may be extended throughout the building, but no structural alterations, except those required by law, shall be made therein.

C)	Preexisting uses, which under this Chapter would require a conditional use permit, shall automatically be considered an approved conditional use on the effective date of this Chapter or any amendment thereto.  Future alterations, enlargements, or intensifications of such use shall require a public hearing and amendment of the conditional use permit.

70-50	Preservation of Nonconforming Buildings or Structures.
A)	Nonconforming buildings or structures lawfully existing on the effective date of this Chapter or any amendment thereto may be repaired, replaced, restored, maintained,
 
or improved, but not expanded although such building or structures do not conform to the dimensional standards of this Chapter.

B)	Any building or structure, which is considered nonconforming only because it cannot meet the setback requirements of the zoning district, may be expanded provided such expansion shall not increase any existing substandard dimensions.

C)	If a nonconforming building or structure is destroyed or damaged by fire or other peril to the extent of 50 percent or less of its estimated market value, as indicated in the records  of the county assessor at the time of damage, it may be reconstructed
provided reconstruction shall substantially reflect the prior structural arrangement and shall not increase the degree of nonconformity. If such structure is destroyed or damaged to the extent of more than 50 percent of its estimated market value as indicated in the records of the county assessor at the time of damage, it shall not be reconstructed except in conformity with the provisions of the district in which it is located, unless a building permit has been applied for within 180 days of when the property is damaged. In this instance, the structure may be repaired or reconstructed, provided that the repairs or reconstruction begin and are diligently pursued to completion within one year of the date of such damage and the reconstruction shall substantially reflect the prior structural arrangement and not increase the degree of nonconformity.

D)	When a nonconforming structure in the shoreland district as provided for in Division 50 of this Chapter with less than 50 percent of the required setback from the water is destroyed by fire or other peril to greater than 50 percent of its estimated market value, as indicated in the records of the county assessor at the time of damage, the structure setback may be increased if practicable and reasonable conditions are placed upon a zoning or building permit to mitigate created impacts on the adjacent property or water body.

70-060  Nonconforming Characteristic of Use.  If characteristics of use such as lighting,  parking, noise or other matters pertaining to the use of land, structures and premises are made nonconforming by the provisions of this Chapter as adopted or amended, no change shall thereafter be made in such characteristics of use which increases the nonconformity; provided, however, that changes may be made which do not increase, or which decrease, such nonconformity.

70-70	Nonconforming Lots of Record. An existing vacant lot having less than the minimum frontage, depth, or area required by the provisions of this Chapter may be developed for all uses in the appropriate zone, provided:

A)	All other provisions of this Chapter are satisfied.
 
B)	Such lots are serviced by public water supply and public sanitary sewer disposal facilities or alternatively meet the requirements of the authority having jurisdiction for private sewerage disposal.

C)	Such lots have a minimum lot frontage of 25 feet on a road or street; frontage on an alley does not constitute frontage on a road or street.

70-080  Unlawful Uses, Buildings, or Structures.  No unlawful use of property existing on the effective date of this Chapter or any amendment thereto nor any building or structure which unlawfully exists on such date shall be deemed a nonconforming use or a nonconforming building or structure.

70-090  Permit Holders and Permit Applicants.  Any nonconforming structure that is ready for or under construction on the effective date of this Chapter or any amendment thereto may be completed and occupied in accordance with the requirements of any valid building permit issued therefor prior to such effective date.

70-100	Change From One Nonconforming Use to Another.


A)	A nonconforming use may be changed to a use permitted in the district in which it is located; except that if no structural alterations are made, a nonconforming use of a building may be changed to another nonconforming use of the same or a more restrictive classification, and provided such change is approved by the Board of Adjustments as hereinafter provided.  Once changed to a conforming use, no building or land shall be permitted to revert to a nonconforming use.

B)	Change of use with approval of the Board of Adjustments: A nonconforming use all  or partially conducted in a building or buildings may be changed to another nonconforming use only upon determination by the Board of Adjustments, after a public hearing, that the proposed new use will be no more detrimental to its neighborhood and surroundings than is the use it is to replace.  In determining relative "detriment", the Board of Adjustments shall take into consideration, among other things: traffic generated; nuisance characteristics such as emission of noise, dust, and smoke; fire hazards; and hours and manner of operation.
 
ARTICLE  V -ADMINISTRATION  AND ENFORCEMENT DIVISION 75:  GENERAL ADMINISTRATIVE  PROVISIONS
75-010  Purpose.  This Division is established to set forth the procedures required for the
administration of this Chapter, to outline the powers and duties of the officials and bodies charged with such administration, to establish standards for required zoning approvals, and to provide for its enforcement in a manner which adds to the quality of land use and development and protects the public health, safety and welfare.

75-020  Concurrent Review.  In order to provide for the efficient administration of this Chapter, whenever a project or proposal requires more than one land use review, including but not limited to a conditional use permit, zoning amendment, expansion or change of a nonconforming use, variance, subdivision, or vacation of public right-of-way, all applications shall be processed concurrently.

75-030  Period of Decision.  No decision of the Zoning Administrator, Advisory Planning Commission, Board of Adjustments, or City Council, except zoning amendments, shall be valid for a period longer than one year from the date of such decision unless a required building permit is obtained within such period and the permitted activity is substantially begun and proceeds on a continuous basis toward completion, or the use is established within such period by actual operation pursuant to the applicable conditions and requirements of such approval. The Zoning Administrator, upon written request, may for good cause shown grant up to a one year extension to this time limit.

75-040  Plan Consistency.  The City shall withhold any building permit, demolition permit, grading permit, utility connection, license or other approval required for a use if the proposed plan is inconsistent with the final plan approved by the Zoning Administrator, Advisory Planning Commission, Board of Adjustments, or City Council.

75-050 Pending Applications. No new applications for zoning approval for the same project or proposal shall be submitted or accepted until all previous applications for such project or proposals have been fully acted upon or withdrawn.

75-060  Substantially Similar Uses.  Whenever an application contains a use not included in this Chapter, the Zoning Administrator shall issue a statement of clarification finding that the use either is substantially similar in character and impact to a use regulated in this Chapter or that the use is not sufficiently similar to any other use regulated in this oChapter. Such statement of clarification shall include the findings that led to such conclusion and shall be filed in the office of the Zoning Administrator. If said use is not sufficiently similar to any other use regulated in this Chapter, the use shall be prohibited.
 
ARTICLE V -ADMINISTRATION  AND ENFORCEMENT DIVISION 80: DUTIES AND DECISION MAKING BODIES AND OFFICIALS
80-10	Zoning Administrator.


A)	Establishment.  There is hereby created the office of the Zoning Administrator. The City Council Administrator shall appoint an individual to act in the capacity of Zoning Administrator for the City of Red Wing.

B)	Jurisdiction and Authority.  The Zoning Administrator (and the Zoning Administrator's designee) shall have the following powers and duties in connection with the administration of this Chapter:

I)	To interpret the provisions of this Chapter and maintain records of such interpretations.

2)	To issue certificates of compliance permits, sign permits, grading permits, certificates of design review, and maintain records of such permits.

3)	To maintain permanent and current records of this Chapter, including but not limited to all maps, amendments, conditional use permits, variances, appeals, site plan reviews, and expansions or changes of nonconforming use.

4)	To provide information relative to all matters arising out of this Chapter.


5)	To receive, review, file, and forward all complete land use applications to their respective review bodies, as herein provided.

6)	To review and make recommendations concerning conditional use permits, interim uses, variance requests, and zoning amendments.

7)	To coordinate the review of other agencies and departments related to applications and proposed land use development projects.

8)	To enforce this Chapter by commencement of appropriate administrative and legal remedies but not limited to issuance of citation or written orders, or reference to the city attorney for issuance of a formal complaint.

9)	To provide staff support to the Red Wing Advisory Planning Commission and Board of Adjustments.

I 0) To establish and administer rules and regulations relating to the administration of this Chapter, including application forms.
 
11) To take such other actions as reasonable and necessary for the administration and enforcement of this Chapter.

80-20	Building Inspection.


A)	Establishment.  The City of Red Wing shall create a Building Inspection service that is responsible to perform the building official duties as required in the administration and enforcement of the City's Building and Housing Codes.

B)	Building Inspection shall coordinate with the Zoning Administrator as to the administration and enforcement of this Chapter. In particular, Building Inspection shall have the following powers and duties in connection with the administration of this Chapter:

1)	Make inspections, file reports, and enforce the provisions of this Chapter to insure compliance on site.

2)	To refer questions of compliance with this Chapter to the Zoning Administrator prior to issuance of any building permit.

3)	To issue certificates of occupancy for any project involving a zoning permit after determining that all requirements of this Chapter have been met and that all conditions of approval of a zoning permit have been met.

80-30	City Planning Commission.


A)	Establishment.  The Advisory Planning Commission is established by Chapter 2 of the Red Wing City Code, and shall perform the duties and exercise its powers as provided therein.

B)	Jurisdiction and Authority. The Advisory Planning Commission shall have the following powers and duties in connection with the administration of this Chapter:

1)	To initiate amendments to the text of this Chapter and to the zoning map.


2)	To hear and make recommendations to the City Council on proposed amendments to this Chapter, including amendments to the zoning map.
3)	To initiate amendments to the comprehensive plan.


4)	To hear and make recommendations to the City Council on proposed amendments to the comprehensive plan.

5)	To hear and make recommendations to the City Council on proposed conditional use permits.
 
6)	To hear and make recommendations to the Board of Adjustments on zoning appeals and variance requests.

7)	To hear and make recommendations to the City Council on proposed interim uses.

8)	To make recommendations to the City Council concerning projects that require environmental assessments and whether environmental impact statements should be required.

C)	Public Hearings.  The Advisory Planning Commission shall schedule public hearings at least once per month, if necessary, and may schedule additional public hearings as required. Such public hearings shall be noticed and conducted pursuant to the provisions of Section 85-020 of this Chapter.

D)	Rules and Procedures.  The Advisory Planning Commission shall adopt policies and procedures for the conduct of its meetings, the processing of applications, and for any other purposes considered necessary for its proper functioning, and select or appoint officers as it deems necessary.  Such policies and procedures shall be consistent with the Minnesota State Statutes, City Charter, the City Code, and this Chapter.

80-40	Board of Adjustments.


A)	Establishment.  There is hereby established a Board of Adjustments, which shall perform its duties and exercise its powers as provided by law in such way as the objectives of this Chapter shall be observed.

B)	Jurisdiction and Authority.  The Board of Adjustments shall have the following powers and duties in connection with the administration of this Chapter:

1)	To hear and decide applications for variances from the provisions of this Chapter pursuant to the provisions and standards set forth in Section 90-110.

2)	To hear and decide appeals from any order, requirement, decision, determination, or interpretation made by the Zoning Administrator or other official in the administration or the enforcement of this Chapter.

C)	Finality of Decisions.  All decisions and findings of the Board of Adjustments shall be final.

D)	Membership. The Board of Adjustments shall consist of the members of the City Council. The officers of the Board of Adjustments shall be the same as the officers for the City Council.
 
E)	Public Hearings.  The Advisory Planning Commission shall schedule public hearings for variance requests and zoning appeals at least once per month, if necessary, and may schedule additional public hearings as required.  Such public hearings shall be noticed and conducted pursuant to the provisions of Section 85-020 of this Chapter. The Board of Adjustments shall schedule meetings to review and act on the recommendations of the city planning commission at least once per month, if necessary, and may schedule additional meetings as required.

F)	Rules and Procedures.  The Board of Adjustments shall adopt the same policies and procedures for the conduct of its meetings as those adopted by the City Council.

80-50	City Council.  The City Council shall have the following powers and duties in connection with the administration of this Chapter:

A)	To initiate amendments to this Chapter.


B)	To adopt amendments of this Chapter.


C)	To deny an application to amend this Chapter.


D)	To initiate or adopt and amend a comprehensive plan for the city or a portion thereof.


E)	To deny an application to amend the comprehensive plan or a portion thereof.


F)	To act as the Board of Adjustments and decide zoning appeals and variances.


G)	To adopt or amend interim ordinances.


H.  To deny an application to adopt or amend an interim ordinance.


I)	To approve or deny interim uses.


J)	To approve or deny conditional use permits.


K)	To decide on the need for Environmental Impact Statements or other actions related to projects that require an environmental assessment.

L)	To take such other actions not delegated to other bodies that may be desirable and necessary to implement the provisions of this Chapter.
 
ARTICLE V -ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT DIVISION 85: GENERAL APPLICATION PROCEDURES
85-10	Application Procedures.


A)	In General.  All applications submitted shall be processed by the Zoning Administrator who shall make a preliminary investigation in accordance with the procedures set forth in this Division.

B)	Determination of Completeness.  The Zoning Administrator shall review all applications and determine whether such applications are complete.  Applications shall not be accepted complete until the applicant has complied with all of the following:

1)	A pre-application meeting with city staff during which the appropriate application procedures, requirements and applicable Zoning Code provisions are reviewed and explained.

2)	Submittal of all required application forms relating to the application, including all additional applications for concurrent review as outlined in Section 75-020.

3)	Submittal of all supporting information required by the Chapter and application form.  At a minimum, the supporting information shall consist of that submission material required for the specific zoning permit as provided for in this Chapter.

4)	Submittal of all fees.


5)	Submission of all required environmental reviews pursuant to Minnesota Statutes and Rules.

C)	Incomplete Applications. If, after the application has been received, the Zoning Administrator determines that the application is not complete, the Zoning Administrator shall notify the applicant in writing within 15 business days of receipt, specifying any deficiencies of the application, including any additional information which must be supplied, and that no further action shall be taken by the city on the application until the deficiencies are corrected.

D)	Remedy of Deficiencies.  If the applicant fails to correct the specific deficiencies within 30 days of the notification of deficiency, the application shall be deemed withdrawn and will be returned to the applicant, including all application fees.

E)	Extension of Time.  Upon written request by the applicant, the Zoning Administrator may, for good cause shown and without any notice or hearing, grant extensions of any time limit imposed on an applicant by these application procedures.
 

F)	Re-Application.  No application for a conditional use permit, interim use, variance, zoning appeal, and zoning amendment shall be resubmitted for a period of 12 months from the date of the denial of a previous application.

85-20	Public Hearings.


A)	Notice.


I)	Land Use Applications. For all land use applications that require a public hearing as set forth in this Chapter, notice of the public hearing shall be given in the following manner.  The failure to give mailed notice to individual property owners, or defects in the notice, shall not invalidate the proceedings, provided a bona fide attempt to comply with this Section has been made.

a)	Newspaper of General Circulation. The Zoning Administrator shall publish notice of the time and purpose of the public hearing at least once, not less
than I 0 calendar days prior to the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation.

b)  Affected Property Owners. The Zoning Administrator shall mail notice, not less than I 0 calendar days prior to the hearing, to all owners of record of property located in whole or in part within 500 feet of the boundaries of the subject property, as identified by the appropriate records.

2)	Zoning Text Amendments.  For all applications for zoning text amendments, including those initiated by the City Council or Advisory Planning Commission as set forth in this Chapter, except interim ordinances, notice of the public hearing shall be given in the following manner:

a)	Newspaper of General Circulation. The Zoning Administrator shall publish notice of the time and purpose of the public hearing at least once, not less
than I 0 calendar days prior to the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation.

b)  Property Owners.  Notice to property owners shall not be required.


B)	Procedures.  All hearings conducted shall be open to the public.  Any person may appear and provide written or verbal comment at a hearing, either in person or by duly appointed agent or attorney.  Upon conclusion of the hearing, the review body shall announce its decision or recommendation or shall lay the matter over to a subsequent meeting.  The review body shall keep minutes of its public hearings, and shall also keep records of its official actions.  Decisions of the review body shall be filed in the office of the Zoning Administrator or in the office of the city clerk.
 
85-30	Fees.


A)	Established.  In recognition of the cost of services performed and work and materials furnished, persons who desire to avail themselves of the privileges granted them
under this Chapter shall pay certain fees depending on the type of permit required and the administrative services associated with the permit.

B)	Fee Ordinance.  The City Council shall set the fee schedule for all permits associated with this Chapter by ordinance.  Said fee schedule shall be updated from time to time at the discretion of the City Council.

C)	Forms and Payment of Fees.  The Zoning Administrator shall provide applicants with forms and other information designating the amount of fees to be paid.  All fees shall be payable to the City of Red Wing.
 
ARTICLE  V -ADMINISTRATION  AND ENFORCEMENT DIVISION 90:  PERMITS, AMENDMENTS, APPEALS, AND VARIANCES
90-10	Building Permits and the Building Code.


A)	No improvement or structural alteration to any land, building, or structures shall be made without first obtaining a building permit as required by Chapter 4 of the City Code.  Any necessary building permits are required in addition to any zoning permit required by this Chapter.

B)	No site preparation work, including rough grading, driveway construction, footing excavation, intensive vegetative clearing, or other physical changes to the site shall occur prior to issuance of a building permit and any other required zoning permit as established by this Chapter.

C)	No building permit shall be issued for any improvement, which would result in a use, building, or structure in violation of this Chapter, or any other City Code provisions.

D)	Building inspections shall refer any project to the Zoning Administrator to determine if a building permit application also requires any zoning permit and to clarify any questions concerning any regulation or requirement of this Chapter prior to issuance of a building permit.

90-20	Certificate of Occupancy.


A)	No building or structure or parts thereof, erected after the effective date of this Chapter, shall be occupied or used unless and until a certificate of occupancy shall have been issued for such building or structure.

B)	A certificate of occupancy shall be approved only when the use and the new or altered structure are in compliance with this Chapter and the Building Code.

C)	Building inspections shall be responsible for issuance of the certificate of occupancy.


D)	Pending the issuance of said certificate of occupancy, a temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued, subject to the Building Code, by Building Inspections at Building Inspections' discretion, for a period not to exceed 12 months during the completion of the erection or the alteration of a building.  The temporary certificate of occupancy shall not be construed as in any way altering the respective rights, duties, or obligations or any other matter except under such restrictions and provisions as will adequately insure the safety of the occupants.

E)	Building inspections shall keep records of all certificates of occupancy.
 
90-30	Certificate of Compliance.


A)	Purpose of Certificates of Compliance.  A certificate of compliance permit (CC) is a zoning permit that is intended as a means of administratively reviewing uses and activities which, because of their unique characteristics or because of special zoning requirements, cannot be permitted as a right in a particular zoning district, but can be permitted upon meeting specific requirements of this Chapter.

B)	Initiation of a Certificate of Compliance.  Any person having a legal or equitable interest in land may file an application to use such land for the use that requires a certificate of compliance permit.  Uses and activities that require a certificate of compliance permit are provided for in the district regulations for the underlying
zoning district in which the property is located and in other provisions and regulations of this Chapter.

C)	Submission Requirements.  Certificate of compliance permit applications shall be submitted to the Zoning Administrator on such form and accompanied by such information as required by the Zoning Administrator, as specified in Section 85-010. In addition, the Zoning Administrator may require some or all of the following specific submission information:

I)	Site plan drawn to scale showing parcel and building dimensions.


2)	Location of all buildings and their size, including square footage.


3)	Curb cuts, driveways, access roads, parking spaces, off-street loading areas, and sidewalks.

4)	Landscape plans meeting the requirements of this Chapter.


5)	Grading and Erosion Control Plans meeting the requirements of this Chapter and the requirements listed in Section 90-060.

6)	When required a Stormwater Management plan meeting the requirements of this Chapter and Section 90-070 of this Chapter.

7)	Type or types of business or activity and proposed number of employees.


8)	Proposed floor plan of any building with use indicated.


9)	Building elevation drawings of any new construction or building renovation proposed.
 
10)	The Zoning Administrator may require that the applicant supply proof of ownership of the property for which the certificate of compliance permit is requested.

11) Any other submission material required for the certificate of compliance as provided for in this Chapter.

D) Action by the Zoning Administrator.   The Zoning Administrator shall issue or deny the application for a certificate of compliance after all information has been submitted. The Zoning Administrator may issue the certificate of compliance permit and apply such conditions that are deemed necessary to protect the public health, safety, and welfare and such conditions may include a time limit for the use to exist or operate, or the Zoning Administrator may deny the issuance of a certificate of compliance permit.

E)	No Action.  Ifno action on the application for a certificate of compliance permit is taken within 10 days of the receipt of a complete application, the application shall be considered denied.

F)	Appeal. If the request for a certificate of compliance permit is denied or if conditions are imposed, the applicant may appeal the decision to the Board of Adjustments. The procedure for an appeal is provided for in Section 90-120.

G)	Discontinuance of Certificate of Compliance Permit.  Where a certificate of compliance use has been established and is discontinued for any reason, for a period of 12 months or longer, the certificate of compliance permit shall become null and void.

90-40	Conditional Use Permit.


A)	Purpose of Conditional Use Permits.  A conditional use permit (C.U.P.) is a zoning permit that is intended as a means of reviewing uses or activities which, because of their unique characteristics, cannot be permitted as a right in a particular zoning district, but can be permitted upon showing that such use or activity in a specific location meets the standards specified in this Chapter.

B)	Initiation of a Conditional Use Permit.  Any person having a legal or equitable interest in land may file an application to use such land for the conditional uses or activities provided for in the district regulations for the underlying zoning district in which the property is located and in other provisions and regulations of this Chapter.

C)	Submission Requirements.  Conditional use permit applications shall be submitted to the Zoning Administrator on such form and accompanied by such information as required by the Zoning Administrator, as specified in Section 85-010 and with the following specific submission information:
 
1)	Site plan drawn to scale showing parcel and building dimensions.


2)	Location of all buildings and their size, including square footage.


3)	Curb cuts, driveways, access roads, parking spaces, off-street loading areas, and sidewalks.

4)	Landscape plans meeting the requirements of this Chapter.


5)	Grading and erosion control plans meeting the requirements of this Chapter and the requirements listed in Section 90-060.

6)	When required, a stormwater management plan meeting the requirements of this Chapter and Section 90-070.

7)	Type or types of business or activity and proposed number of employees.


8)	Proposed floor plan of any building with use indicated.


9)	Building elevation drawings of any new construction or building renovation proposed.

10)	The Zoning Administrator may require that the applicant supply proof of ownership of the property for which the conditional use permit is requested.

11) The Zoning Administrator may require traffic generation information to determine the adequacy of existing transportation infrastructure.

D) Hearing on Application for Conditional Use Permit.  The Advisory Planning Commission shall hold a public hearing on each complete application for a conditional use permit as provided in Section 85-020 of this Chapter.  After the close of the hearing on a proposed conditional use permit, the Advisory Planning Commission  shall consider findings and shall submit the same together with its recommendation to the City Council.

E)	Required Findings for Conditional Use Permits.  The Advisory Planning Commission shall consider the following before making its recommendation to the City Council:

1)	The establishment, maintenance, or operation of the conditional use will not be detrimental to or endanger the public health, safety, morals, comfort, or general welfare.

2)	The conditional use will not be injurious to the use and enjoyment of other property in the vicinity and will not impede the normal and orderly development
 
and improvement or surrounding property for uses permitted in the district, or substantially diminish property values.

3)	Adequate utilities, access roads, drainage, or other necessary facilities have been or will be provided.

4)	Adequate measures have been or will be taken to minimize traffic congestion in public streets.

5)	The conditional use permit is consistent with the applicable policies of the Comprehensive Plan.

6)	The conditional use shall, in all other respects, conform to the applicable regulations or the district in which it is located.

F)	Council Action.  The City Council shall consider the report of the Advisory Planning Commission and any other information provided.  The City Council shall make findings of fact before granting the conditional use permit based on the findings listed above.  The City Council may impose such conditions on any proposed conditional use permit and require such guarantees as it deems reasonable and necessary to protect the public interest and to ensure compliance with the standards and purposes of this Chapter and policies of the Comprehensive Plan.

G)	Discontinuance of Conditional Use Permits.  Where a conditional use has been established and is discontinued for any reason for a period of 12 months or longer, or where a conditional use has been changed to a permitted use or to any other conditional use, the conditional use permit shall become null and void.

H)	Review.  If a review is imposed as a condition of the granting of a conditional use permit, the permit shall be reviewed by the Advisory Planning Commission at a public hearing within 30 days of the date established for the review period.  Notice of the public hearing shall be distributed as provided for in Section 85-020 of this Chapter and the permit holder shall be notified at least I 0 days prior to the hearing.

90-50	Public Improvements and Services.


A)	A number of public improvements and services are often required by developments and applications affected by this Chapter.  Development projects may require the need to install driveway access onto public streets, curb and gutter, street repairs, sidewalks, street extensions, sewer extensions and connections, stormwater extensions and connections, and water service extensions and connections.  In addition, city services may be required in connection with a development including
such services as tree removal, snow removal, and other similar services.  When public improvements and services listed above are required and not petitioned for through
 
Chapter 429 of Minnesota State Statutes, the applicant shall be required to receive approval from the city for such public improvements or services.

B)	An application for improvements and services shall be available from the engineering and public works offices.  Said application form shall be filled out by the applicant indicating the type of work requested.  The application form shall be referred to the offices of engineering or public works who shall estimate the cost of improvements and services identified.  Once the charges are estimated, the owner shall sign said application form indicating that they agree to pay all costs and charges for said improvements and services and conform to the rules, regulations, and ordinances of the city in the installation of said improvements.  The office of the engineering and/or the office of public works shall be responsible for approving all applications for improvements and services.

90-60	Grading and Erosion Control Permit.


A)	Applicability. Grading and erosion control permits are required for the following projects, or a series of projects, that involve more than 50 cubic yards of earthen material:
•	The raising or lowering of ground elevations.
•	The removal of topsoil.
•	The alteration of the contours of land.
•	The utilization, disturbance, or removal of earthen material.


Single Family residential construction shall be exempt from the requirement of obtaining a grading and erosion control permit, except that said development shall follow any requirements for grading and erosion control set forth in the approval process for the subdivision or conditional use permit or if the area to be graded with a single family residential construction is one acre or more.

B)	Initiation of Grading and Erosion Control Permit.  Any person having a legal or equitable interest in land may file an application for a grading permit.

C)	Permit Process.  Grading and erosion control projects that are not part of another permit requiring a conditional use permit shall follow the procedures for a certificate of compliance as listed in Section 90-030 of this Chapter.

D)	Submission Requirements.  Applicants shall submit materials as listed for a certificate of compliance as listed in Section 90-030 of this Chapter.  In addition, the city engineer shall review the grading plan and said plan shall address erosion control and sediment control as follows:

1)	If the area to be graded is less than one acre, the project proposer will be required to install temporary erosion and sediment controls at locations as directed by the city engineer or designee.
 

2)	If the area to be graded is one acre or more, the project proposer must obtain an NPDES construction stormwater permit from the MPCA.

E)	Exceptions.  The provisions of this section shall not apply to farming or agricultural activities.

90-70	Stormwater Management Plan.


A)	Purpose of a Stormwater Management Plan.  The purpose of a stormwater management plan is to protect, preserve and enhance the natural resources within the City of Red Wing by providing regulations that control stormwater rates/volumes and protect water quality.  When any land disturbance project or a series of projects will disturb less than one acre of land, the city engineer and the Zoning Administrator shall determine if a stormwater management plan is required, and what submittals, if any, are required.  When any disturbance project or a series of projects will disturb one
acre or more of land, submittal requirements shall include a stormwater management plan, in accordance with Division 57 of this Chapter, provided by a Minnesota licensed professional.

B)	Plan Review Procedure.  The procedure for the review of a stormwater management plan is listed in Section 57-070 of this Chapter.

C)	Submission Requirements.   The submission requirements for a stormwater management plan are listed in Section 57-060 of this Chapter.

D)	General Standards.  Standards for a stormwater management plan are listed in Section 57-080.

90-80	Environmental Assessment and Impact Statements.


A)	Purpose.  The purpose of the environmental review process is to determine whether a proposed action is a major action with the potential for significant environmental impact.

B)	Initiation of Environmental Review Process.  Minnesota State Statutes and Rules provide for the requirements for an environmental assessment worksheet or environmental impact statement.

C)	Process.  The process for environmental assessment worksheets and environmental impact statements are provided for in Minnesota State Statutes and Rules.  When the City of Red Wing acts as the Responsible Government Unit, the City shall follow all state laws and rules in the processing of the environmental review.  At any time that the City Council is required to make an official determination in its role as the Responsible Government Unit, the following process shall be followed:
 

1)	Advisory Planning Commission Review.  The Advisory Planning Commission shall review the matter and forward a recommendation to the City Council for consideration.

2)  City Council Action.  The City Council shall consider the recommendation of the Advisory Planning Commission, make findings of fact, and make a final decision in terms of any official determination that must be made by the city in its role as the Responsible Government Unit.

90-90	Certificate of Design Review.


A)	Purpose.  These regulations shall apply to Division 45 of this Chapter pertaining to the Design Review Regulations.

B)	Process.  A Certificate of Design Review shall be processed in accordance with Section 45-050 of this Chapter.

1)	Prior to issuance of a grading permit, parking lot permit, certificate of compliance, sign permit, or building permit for a project listed in Section 45-040, an applicant shall provide information to the Zoning Administrator in accordance with Section 45-060 of this Chapter.  The Zoning Administrator shall approve, approve with conditions, or deny the Certificate of Design Review based upon compliance with the site plan criteria, design review standards, conformance with the City of Red Wing Comprehensive Plan and all City laws, rules and regulations.

2)	Prior to issuance of a conditional use permit, planned unit development, zoning amendment, or variance for a project listed in Section 45-030 of this Chapter, an applicant shall receive a Certificate of Design Review.  Approval from the review authority (in this case the review authority shall be the Red Wing City Council). The city planning commission shall recommend approval, approval with conditions, or denial of an application based upon compliance with the site plan criteria, design review standards, conformance with the City of Red Wing Comprehensive Plan and all City laws, rules and regulations.

90-100	Septic Permits


A)	Purpose.  These regulations shall apply to individual sewage treatment systems serving a dwelling, other establishment, or group thereof that uses subsurface soil treatment and disposal.

B)	County Ordinance Applies. Goodhue County has adopted ordinances that comply with Minnesota Statutes 115.55 and Minnesota Rules 7080. These ordinances apply to all areas located within the City of Red Wing.
 

C)	Septic Permit Prior to Issuance of Building Permit.  In any area located within the City of Red Wing and where no public sewer facilities are available, no building
permit shall be issued for any use requiring an individual sewage treatment system until a septic permit has first been issued by Goodhue County.  In addition, special regulations and lot requirements related to the use of individual sewage treatment systems may be in place depending upon the specific zoning district classification.

90-110	Variance


A)	Purpose.  Variances are intended to provide a means of departure from the literal requirements of this Chapter where strict adherence would cause practical difficulties due to special conditions or circumstances unique to the property not created by the landowner.  Variances shall only be permitted when they are in harmony with the general purposes and intent of this Chapter and when the variances are consistent with the Comprehensive Plan.

B)	Initiation of Variance.  Any person having a legal or equitable interest in land may file an application for a variance of a dimensional requirement of this Chapter.  No variance may be granted that would allow any use that is not allowed in the zoning district in which the subject property is located.

C)	Application for Variance.  An application for a variance shall be filed on a form approved by the Zoning Administrator, as specified in Section 85-010.  Submission materials may include the following information as determined necessary by the Zoning Administrator:

1)	Site plan drawn to scale showing parcel and building dimensions.


2)	Location of all buildings and their size, including square footage.


3)	Curb cuts, driveways, access roads, parking spaces, off-street loading areas, and sidewalks.

4)	Landscape plans meeting the requirements of this Chapter.


5)	Grading and Erosion Control Plans meeting the requirements of this Chapter and the requirements listed in Section 90-060.

6)	When required by Division 57, a Stormwater Management Plan meeting the requirements of said Division and Section 90-070 of this Chapter.

7)	The Zoning Administrator may require that the applicant supply proof of ownership of the property for which the variance is requested.
 
8)	The variance requested and the reasons for it.


9)	A letter of acknowledgment signed by a majority of the owners of property lying adjacent to the parcel on which a variance is sought.  Ifproperty owners of adjacent property are unable or unwilling to sign a letter of acknowledgment, the applicant may submit a letter indicating the effort made to contact adjacent property owners.

D)	Process for Variance.  The city planning commission shall hold a public hearing on each complete application for a variance as provided in Section 85-020.  Once the city planning commission has conducted the public hearing and has gathered all necessary information it shall make a recommendation to the Board of Adjustments. The Board of Adjustments shall place the matter on the next agenda and consider the variance and recommendation of the city planning commission.  The Board of Adjustments shall have the exclusive power to order the issuance of variances from
the requirements of this Chapter including restrictions placed on nonconformities.  All findings and decisions of the Board of Adjustments concerning variances shall be
final.


E)	Finding of Facts.  The Board of Adjustments shall not vary the regulations of this Chapter unless it makes each of the following findings based on the evidence presented to it in each specific case:

I)  Because of the particular physical surroundings, or the shape, configuration, topography or other conditions of the specific parcel of land involved, strict adherence to the regulations of this Chapter would cause practical difficulties. Economic considerations alone do not constitute practical difficulties.

2)	The conditions upon which a petition for variance is based are unique to the parcel ofland for which the variance is sought and are not applicable, generally, to other property within the same zoning classification.

3)	The alleged practical difficulty is caused by this Chapter and has not been created by any persons presently having an interest in the parcel of land.

4)	The granting of the variance will not alter the essential character of the locality or be injurious to other property in the vicinity in which the parcel of land is located or substantially diminish property values.

5)	The proposed variance will not substantially increase the congestion of the public streets, or increase the danger of fire, or be detrimental to the public welfare or endanger the public safety.
6)	It has been demonstrated that the granting of the variance will be in keeping with the spirit and intent of this Chapter and is consistent with the Comprehensive Plan.
 

F)	Variance Conditions.  The Board of Adjustments may impose such conditions on any proposed variance and require such guarantees, as it deems reasonable and necessary to protect the public interest and to ensure compliance with the standards and purposes of this Chapter and policies of the Comprehensive Plan. A condition must be directly related to and must bear a rough proportionality to the impact created by the variance.

90-120	Zoning Appeal


A)	Appeals of Decisions of the Zoning Administrator.  All findings and decisions of the Zoning Administrator or other official involved in the administration or enforcement of this Chapter shall be final subject to appeal to the Board of Adjustments, except as otherwise provided by this Chapter.  All appeals shall be filed within 20 calendar days of the date of the decision and shall be accompanied at the time of filing with payment of the application fee as specified in Section 85-030. Timely filing of an appeal shall stay all proceedings in the action appealed from unless the Zoning Administrator certifies to the Board of Adjustment, with service of a copy on the applicant, that by reasons of fact stated, a stay would, in the opinion of the Zoning Administrator, cause imminent peril to life or property, in which case the proceedings shall not be stayed.  The city planning commission shall hold a public hearing on each complete application for an appeal as provided in Section 85-020. Once the city planning commission has conducted the public hearing and has gathered all necessary information it shall make a recommendation to the Board of Adjustments.  The Board of Adjustments shall place the matter on the next agenda and consider the appeal and recommendation of the city planning commission.  All findings and decisions of the Board of Adjustments concerning appeals shall be final.

B)	Lake and Shoreland Management Overlay Regulations, Flood Plain
Regulations and Cannon River Management Overlay Districts.  When the appeal is of a decision relating to the Shoreland Management Overlay Regulations (Section 50); Flood Plain Regulations Overlay District (Section 52); or Cannon River Management Overlay District (Section 53); as established in this Chapter, the Zoning Administrator shall submit to the Minnesota Commissioner of Natural Resources the notice of appeal at least ten days before the hearing.

90-130	Zoning Amendment


A)	Purpose of Zoning Amendments.  Amendments to the text of this Chapter and the zoning maps are made for the purpose of promoting the public health, safety and general welfare, and in consideration of changing conditions, conservation of property values, changes in the City's Comprehensive Plan, the trend of development, and the current and anticipated future uses of property.
 
B)	Initiation of Zoning Amendments.  Amendments shall be initiated by the City Council, Planning Commission or by application of any person with a legal or equitable interest in a property.

1)	Amendments Initiated by Application.  An application for an amendment to the zoning classification of a particular property shall be filed with the Zoning Administrator on such form and accompanied by such information as required by the Zoning Administrator, as specified in Section 85-010 and with the following specific submission information:

a)	Conceptual site plan drawn to scale showing all affected parcels and general concept for development.

b)	General location of all buildings and their approximate size and square footage.

c)	Approximate location of all curb cuts, driveways, access roads, parking areas, off-street loading areas, and sidewalks.

d)	Preliminary landscape plan indicating general planting areas for trees, shrubs, and lawns.

e)	Preliminary grading, erosion control, and Stormwater Management Plan as specified in Section 57 of this Chapter.

f)	Preliminary Sewer and Water Utility Plan for the development.


g)	Narrative indicating the types of uses or business that is contemplated for the development, number of employees, parking and traffic impacts, and other pertinent information about the proposed development.

h)	The Zoning Administrator may require the applicant to supply proof of ownership of the property for which the amendment is requested that illustrate legal or equitable interest in the property.

2)   Amendments Initiated by the City Council or the City Planning  Commission. The City Council or the city planning commission may initiate amendments to the text of this Chapter or to the zoning classification of specific properties. Amendments initiated by the City Council or city planning commission shall be referred to the city planning commission by the Zoning Administrator for study.

C)	Hearing on Zoning Amendments.  The city planning commission shall hold a public hearing on each completed application for zoning amendment and all amendments
 
initiated by the City Council or city planning commission, as provided for in Section
85-020.


D)	Findings and Recommendation of the City Planning Commission.  After the close of the hearing on a proposed amendment, the city planning commission shall make findings with respect to the following and shall submit the same together with its recommendation to the City Council:

1)	Whether the amendment is consistent with the Comprehensive Plan.


2)	Whether the amendment is in the public interest and is not solely for the interest of a single property owner.

3)	Whether the existing uses of property and the zoning classification of property within the general area of the property in question are compatible with the proposed zoning classification, where the amendment is to change the zoning classification of particular property.

4)	Whether there has been a change in the character or trend of development in the general area of the property in question, which has taken place since such property was placed in its present zoning classification, where the amendment is to change the zoning classification of particular property.

E)	Action by City Council on Zoning Amendments.  The City Council shall make the final decision regarding all zoning amendments.  Approval of a zoning amendment shall require a two-thirds vote of all its members.
 
ARTICLE  V -ADMINISTRATION  AND ENFORCEMENT DIVISION 95:  ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES
95-010  Complaints Regarding Violations.  The Zoning Administrator shall have the authority
to investigate any complaint alleging a violation of this Chapter or the conditions of any zoning approval and to take such action as is warranted in accordance with the procedures set forth in this Chapter.

95-20	Procedures Upon Discovery of a Violation.


A)	Notice of Violations.  The Zoning Administrator shall provide a written notice to any person responsible for such violation, identifying the property in question, indicating the nature of the violation, and ordering the action necessary to correct it, including a reasonable time period to remedy the violation.  The written notice shall advise that the Zoning Administrator's decision or order may be appealed to the Board of Adjustments in accordance with the provisions of Section 90-100. Additional written notices may be provided at the Zoning Administrator's discretion.

B)	Enforcement Without Notice.  Whenever the Zoning Administrator finds that an emergency exists in relation to the enforcement of the provisions of this Chapter which requires immediate action to protect the health, safety, or welfare of occupants of any dwelling or the public, the Zoning Administrator may seek immediate enforcement without prior written notice, notwithstanding any other provision of this Chapter.

95-30	Fees for Reinspection.


A)	Initial Inspection and First Reinspection.   There shall be no fee charged for an initial inspection to determine the existence of a zoning violation, nor any fee for the first reinspection to determine compliance with an order to correct a zoning violation.

B)	Subsequent Reinspections.  The City Council shall set a fee by ordinance to be charged for each subsequent reinspection occurring after the due date for compliance with an order.

C)	Notice of Reinspection Fee.  Every notice of violation and order to correct zoning violations shall contain a clear and conspicuous explanation of the policy in this section requiring reinspection fees for subsequent reinspection.

D)	Waiver.  Upon written request by the applicant, the Zoning Administrator may, for good cause shown and without notice or hearing, waive a reinspection fee.



95-40	Penalties and Remedies For Violations.
 

A)	Violations of the provisions of this Chapter or the conditions of any zoning approval granted, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as for a misdemeanor except as otherwise stated in specific provisions of this Chapter.

B)	This Chapter may also be enforced by injunction, abatement, mandamus, or any other appropriate remedy in any court of competent jurisdiction.

C)	Each day that any violation continues after notification by the Zoning Administrator that such violation exists shall be considered a separate offense for purpose of the penalties and remedies specified in this section.

D)	Any one, all, or any combination of the forgoing penalties and remedies may be used to enforce this Chapter.
